Published in Journal of Mormon History 41.4 (2015): 209-220.

Refiner’s Fire and the Yates Thesis: Hermeticism, Esotericism, and the History of

Christianity

Stephen J. Fleming, Egil Asprem, and Ann Taves

In his award winning book, Refiner’s Fire, John Brooke identified “striking parallels

between the Mormon concepts of the coequality of matter and spirit, of the covenant of celestial

marriage, and of an ultimate goal of human godhood and the philosophical traditions of alchemy

and hermeticism, drawn from the ancient world and fused with Christianity in the Italian

Renaissance.”1 Building on Frances Yates’s highly influential Giordano Bruno and the Hermetic

Tradition (1964) and her follow up The Occult Philosophy in the Elizabethan Age (1979),

Brooke traced the spread of these ideas from the radical sectarians of the English Civil War to

the American colonies to Joseph Smith. In doing so, Brooke defined “hermeticism”2 the way

other scholars had — as a fusion of “Platonism, Gnosticism, and Egyptian theology” — and

located its full flowering, following Yates’s lead, in the Renaissance with Marsilio Ficino’s

translation of the Corpus Hermeticum.3

Linking Mormonism to Yates’s thesis was a great advance in contextualizing Smith’s

radical ideas, but it also introduced problems. Yates’ work was already controversial when The

Refiner’s Fire came out, and her view of a “Hermetic Tradition” has by now been completely


1
Brooke, Refiner’s Fire, xiii-xvi.

2
While Frances Yates used the terms “hermetism” and “Hermetic Tradition”, it has since become conventional to

use “hermeticism” to refer to Renaissance interest in the Corpus Hermeticum and Hermes Trismegistus, reserving

“hermetism” for the original Alexandrian context which gave rise to these texts in late antiquity. This article follows

current conventions.
3
Brooke, Refiner’s Fire, xvi, 8-11. The major tenets of hermetism, Brooke argues, were human divine potential and

the rejection of creation ex nihilo.

2

discarded by intellectual historians. Critiques of Yates’s understanding of “hermeticism” and

“magic” are particularly relevant to Brooke’s thesis. Situating both concepts within the history of

Christian polemics undercuts the dichotomization of Christianity, on the one hand, and

hermeticism and magic, on the other, and allows us to situate Mormonism and Smith’s sources

within a richer understanding of the history of Christianity.

The Critique of Yates

The overarching problem with the Yates thesis is that the traits that she (and Brooke,

following her lead) characterized as “hermetic” did not suddenly emerge in the Renaissance as a

response to the discovery and translation of the Corpus Hermeticum; many of these ideas had

already been integrated in Christianity by church fathers influenced by Neoplatonism. Origen,

for example, was central to the early modern developments that Brook sought to trace.

Moreover, what Renaissance thinkers borrowed from the Church fathers and other Neoplatonic

theologians (such as Iamblichus and Proclus) was not so much a “Hermetic” position, as a

broader Platonic Orientalism that traced the origin of pagan philosophy in a distant and universal

ancient wisdom of the Orient, a prisca theologia.4 Thus, Neoplatonism, Christian Platonism, and

even “Platonic Orientalism” are better terms for the movement that Yates described than

hermeticism.

D. P. Walker recognized this, as did other, before Yates’s work appeared.5 Walker’s

Spiritual and Demonic Magic (1958) preceded Yates's Giordano Bruno and his The Decline of


4
Cf. Hanegraaff, Esotericism and the Academy; cf. Dylan Burns, ”The Chaldean Oracles of Zoroaster, Hekate’s

Couch, and Platonic Orientalism in Psellos and Plethon,” Aries 6.2 (2006): 158-179.
5
In addition to Walker, the meticulously researched works of Lynn Thorndike, Will‐Erich Peuckert, Paul Oskar 

Kristeller and others, published in the first half of the twentieth century, mean that what Yates called the 

“hermetic tradition” (adopting , in fact, the category from Kristeller, who first invented it in 1938) was far 

better known by existing scholarship than her readers were led to believe. On this, see Hanegraaff, 

Esotericism in the Academy, 322‐334.

3

Hell (1964) came out in the same year. The Decline of Hell focused on a particular aspect of

Christian Platonism, namely the early modern revival of interest in the early Christian fathers,

Origen in particular. In a later work, Walker went on to explain the crucial notion of prisca

theologia, or the belief in a primal ancient wisdom that was so important to Christian Platonists

of the era.6 Brooke cited Spiritual and Demonic Magic and The Ancient Theology, but following

Yates (who was also indebted to her close friend Walker) he preferred “hermetic” to “Christian

Platonic” and made no mention of the early fathers.

Brian Copenhaver initiated the systematic critique of Yates’s use of “hermetism” in

1988.7 He noted that the practices of Ficino and Agrippa – two of Yates’ prototype “hermetic

magi” – did not in fact derive from the Hermetica at all, but rather from the theurgy of the

Neoplatonist Proclus.8 Ficino was interested in what he called “natural magic,” but he drew upon

Neoplatonism rather than the hermetic corpus, for the simple reason that “the Hermetica say

rather little about magic.” As Copenhaver concluded, “[t]he works of [Neoplatonists] Plotinus,

Porphyry, Iamblichus, Synesius, and Proclus are the most important ancient philosophical

sources for the theory of magic in the Renaissance. Research on magic in the Renaissance should

shift its attention to these text and to their interpretation in the early modern period.”9

Copenhaver followed up these critiques two years later with his article, “Natural Magic,

Hermeticism, and Occultism in Early Modern Science” (1990). Copenhaver again asserted the

importance of Proclus and critiqued Yates’s used of the term “hermetic.” Copenhaver noted that

early modern people did use the term “hermetic” to describe a particular attitude toward nature


6
Walker, The Ancient Theology: Studies in Christian Platonism from the Fifteenth to the Eighteenth Century (1972)

7
The earliest critique was in Allen G. Debus’ review of Giordano Bruno and the Hermetic Tradition in Isis 55, no.3

(1964): 389-91.
8
The Hermetica are the Corpus Hermeticum and the hermetic text called the Asclepius, which had been translated

earlier.
9
Brian Copenhaver, “Hermes Trismegistus, Proclus, and the Question of a Philosophy of Magic in the

Renaissance,” in Hermeticism and the Renaissance: Intellectual History and the Occult in Early Modern Europe,

ed. by Ingrid Merkel and Allen G. Debus (Washington: Folger Shakespeare Library, 1988), 79-110.

4

but argued that Yates “sometimes used this term as if it meant the same thing a ‘magical’ or

‘occultist’ broadly understood.” Copenhaver argued that “the term ‘hermetic’ should be used

primarily to name a [specific] set of texts,” i.e., the Corpus Hermeticum. A more general

understanding of the term, he argued, “can lead only to more confusion.” Finally, Copenhaver

noted, “In ordinary modern English, ‘magic’ is a vague term,” which can mean practices that

“from the point of view of orthodox religion or philosophy or, more recently, science … seemed

illegitimate, erroneous, somehow marginal.” This lack of clarity made “magic” a problematic

term.10 Four years later Brooke, following Yates, lumped a number of practices and ideas

including astrology, alchemy, and Kabbalah under the hermetic umbrella; made almost no

mention of Plato and Neoplatonism; and associated a vaguely defined “magic” with

“hermeticism.”11 Over reliance on Yates, thus, obscured the Neoplatonic origins of many of these

ideas, as well as their appropriation by the early church fathers.

Esotericism and Anti-Platonic Polemics

Since Refiner’s Fire, scholars have extended Copenhaver’s critiques and embraced

Walker’s arguments. A paradigmatic example of this line of scholarship is Wouter Hanegraaff’s

Esotericism and the Academy: Rejected Knowledge in Western Culture (2012),12 which

INTRODUCTION

I

The Italian Renaissance is a phenomenon so complex and
ambiguous that it eludes attempts at definition. The most
obvious meaning of renaissance is rebirth, or more particularly,
the revival of classical antiquity. But though many celebrated
wOIks of Renaissance architecture, sculpture, or literature are
plainly inspired by classical models, they are not mere repeti­
tions of classic prototypes, and in many fields, such as painting,
Renaissance works are not imitated from ancient ones at all.
Thus the revival of the ancient world seems to be only one aspect
of the Renaissance. The persistence of medieval forms, tech­
niques, and ideas is equally evident. But the culture of the Ren­
aissance cannot be reduced either to an imitation of antiquity or
to a prolongation of the Middle Ages, for the fifteenth-century
Italian artists and writers created a new style in which a great
variety of elements, derived from both ancient and medieval
sources, are utilized in a new and original way.

Philosophy in fifteenth-century Italy displays characteristics.
parallel to those of art and letters. Philosophers exhibit a sim­
ilar enthusiasm for classical antiquity, a zeal for the discovery
of hitherto unnoticed ancient source material, a continuing
interest in traditional problems formulated in a new manner.
Furthermore, Renaissance thinkers could master and associate·
a great range of ideas in several different fields. All of these traits
can be observed in the philosophy of one of the foremost in­
tellects of the time, Giovanni Pico della Mirandola. His thought
is not only of the greatest intrinsic interest, but discloses,.
through one individual, the spirit of the Italian Renaissance.

The vast scope and variety of Pico's intellectual curiosity and
learning indicate the complexity of his philosophy. The list of
books in his personal library, on which he spent much of his,

vii

viii INTRODUCTION

inherited wealth, has fortunately been preserved, and although
he perhaps had not read all the books he owned, they provide
an excellent idea of the sources of his philosophy. Literature,
science, philosophy, and theology are represented in Greek,
Latin, and Hebrew, with a few volumes in Arabic and Aramaic.
Pico boasts, quite justifiably, that he has studied all schools of
philosophy, and that his knowledge is not limited to anyone
tradition. The range of his erudition is also seen in the list of
nine hundred theses which, at the age of twenty-four, he pro­
posed for public disputation; the propositions are drawn from
the most disparate sources. Further, Pico's studies at Ferrara,
Padua, and Paris, and his later residence in Florence made him
acquainted with all the chief philosophic currents of the time.
These included Aristotle, the Neoplatonic philosophers, the
Greek and Latin Church Fathers, the principal scholastic doc­
tors of the thirteenth and fourteenth centuries, and through his
Florentine friends, the works of Plato in the original. Pico had
considerable knowledge of Hebrew, and some slight acquain­
tance with Arabic and Aramaic, which gave him access to Jewish
theology, philosophy, and science. His eclectic erudition was
the wonder of his contemporaries.

A closer look at the contents of Pico's library suggests that his
learning had a definite form and center. Almost nine-tenths of
his books are in Latin, the language in which Pico did prac­
tically all of his reading and writing, and the majority of them
deal with philosophy and theology. Greek philosophy is repre­
sented in the original language, but Pico seems to have read
most of the Greeks in Latin translations. Of his philosophic
works in Latin, the greater number are by medieval authors.
The subject matter and authors of the nine hundred theses that
Pico proposed for discussion also reveal the great predominance
of the medieval Latin tradition. Greek and Hebrew texts played
an altogether peripheral role in his intellectual life. Thus, al­
though the source material of Pico's thought is exceptionally
rich, varied, and independent of the limitations of anyone
philosophical school, the composition of his library already sug­
gests a basic characteristic of his thinking; namely; that he saw

INTRODUCTION IX

his new classical or Hebrew learning in terms of a definite frame
of reference provided by the Christian Latin tradition. The va­
riety of his library reflects his conviction that truth is not re­
stricted to anyone philosopher or theologian; yet, although the
material of his thought is frequently new and eclectic, the form,
or point of view which dominates this learning, is in many ways
medieval.

II

Pi co utilized this great mass of philosophical and theological
material in accord with certain very curious views about the
history of ideas. It is a commonplace of medieval thought that
the philosophical conclusions reached by reason, and the con­
tent of religious revelation, are in agreement. For Pico, this
concord of truth is embodied in the actual history of thought.
He considers Greek philosophy and the Judeo-Christian scrip­
tural tradition both as unfoldings of a single pious philosophy.
Pico thinks that he is rediscovering the unity of a sacred
theology revealed through both Greek reason and Christian
revelation.

Greek philosophy, in this view, contains an occult, secret
tradition of theological wisdom, running from Hermes Tris­
megistus, Orpheus, Pythagoras, down to Socrates, Plato, Aris­
totle, and later thinkers.l (Pico even had some misinfOl;mation
on the "Egyptian" source of Greek thought.) A sacred religious
truth was presented by these thinkers in allegorical form,
hidden under mythological fables. Even Homer conceals a pro­
found moral and religious doctrine in epic images. The Her­
metic tradition had recently been put back into circulation by
Pico's older friend Marsilio Ficino, who translated the entire
Corpus Hermeticum into Latin. These Hermetic and Orphic
writings, which are now known to be forgeries dating from late
antiquity (mainly the first few centuries of the Christian era),
were thought by the Florentine philosophers to be of immense
age. They were supposed to contain a continuous occult the-

1 See below, Heptaplus, Proem, p. 68.

x INTRODUCTION

ology, which Ficino and Pico unveil by symbolic interpretation.
Even such presumably clear-thinking rational philosophers as
Plato and Aristotle were seen as initiates in a secret tradition
of sacred truth.

The Renaissance admiration for the mysterious may seem
slightly puerile and affected, yet Ficino and Pi co took their
work of allegorical exegesis very seriously, for once the inner
meaning of Greek religion, thought, and poetry had been
grasped, they were seen as a natural revelation of the mysteries
of theology. The wisdom of the Egyptians and Greeks was not
merely human; it had a religious origin and history which need
only be discovered by techniques of exegesis.

Such Renaissance thinkers as Nicholas Cusanus, Ficino, and
Pico therefore often exhibited a tolerant eclecticism, an open­
minded, receptive attitude toward foreign and ancient phil­
osophies and religions. As previously suggested, this point of
view had a perfectly definite metaphysical and historical basis:
they believed that the content of these various views was in
basic agreement, and that a continuous religious revelation ran
through the apparent diversity of human cultures.

The texts of the other set of ideas which Pico made use of,
the Judeo-Christian religious tradition, were also interpreted
by methods revealing a secret, deeper meaning underneath the
crude literal and historical surface. Of course both Jews and
Christians had long given the Bible a symbolic interpretation.
But Pi co believed that he could reveal hitherto unnoticed
depths of truth in scripture. For one ,thing, Pico had a phil­
osophic view of the world, including man, according to which
each part of the world is wholly present in every other part. It
follows that a truth about anyone part immediately reverber­
ates through the whole, and discloses truth about every other
part.2 The very text and literary structure of the Bible is
isomorphic with the natural and divine order which it describes.
Scripture contains implicit symbolic truths for every branch of
science, philosophy, and theology.

2 See below Heptaplus, Second Proem, p. 77; Book II, Proem, pp. 94""95.

INTRODUCTION xi

Further, Pico's study of Hebrew gave him some access to the
qabbalah, a Jewish tradition of allegorical commentary on the
Bible. He believed that this tradition reached back to Old
Testament times. It was an esoteric interpretation of the Law,
first revealed by God to Moses alone, then transmitted secretly
down to the present. Pico treats the qabbalah with more respect
than it perhaps deserves. In any case, its influence on his
thought has been much exaggerated. Pico merely utilized the
qabbalah as another tool in his symbolic method of scriptural
exegesis. He derived certain new materials from it, but his
fundamental method of Biblical commentary is in no way orig­
inal. Allegorical interpretation had been practiced throughout
the Middle Ages, and Pico did not need the qabbalah to dis­
cover it.

Pico makes independent use of the Hebrew tradition. He
rightly points out that he is not subservient to it. Whatever in
the Jewish tradition agrees with the Christian Gospel he re­
tains; he refutes whatever in it is foreign to the Gospel. Pico
thus makes use of both Greek and Jewish sources of wisdom
insofar as he considers them to agree with his own Christian
philosophy.

III

Pico's method of interpreting Scripture can be seen in his
Heptaplus or Septiform Narration of the Six Days of Creation.
The principle of his interpretation is the identifying of the
truths of science and philosophy with Biblical doctrines. The
Greek and Latin Church Fathers, in their commentaries on
Genesis, had utilized the cosmology of Plato's Timaeus. Pi co
follows very much in their spirit.

The created world, according to the usual medieval cosmology
that Pico uses, is divided into three chief zones, (1) the intel­
ligences or angels, (2) the heavenly bodies, (3) the corruptible
earthly bodies. Pico's commentary points out how this hierarchy
is present in Genesis, and how Moses already alluded in a hid­
den way to the facts of natural science as Pico understood them.

xii INTRODUCTION

Biblical concepts also include or signify philosophic concepts.
Moses has thus anticipated the findings of Greek philosophers
regarding matter, form, etc. Further, the Platonic notion of
man as intermediate between the physical and spiritual worlds
is held by Pico to be equivalent to the Biblical notion of man as
the image of God. Man reunites the multiple orders of creation
just as God contains the diverse perfections of creatures in a
higher unity.

The natural world, in this sort of interpretation, is a physical
embodiment or model of philosophic and religious truth, not
a mere symbol or metaphor of a supernatural order: nature
actually embodies God's goodness and wisdom. The parallel
between one part of nature and another, between man and
nature, or between man and God, is not a poetic fiction but a
real isomorphism or identity of structure. Man is the image of
God in that he actually reproduces in an imperfect, copied way
the perfections of his exemplary cause.

Pico intended this notion of imitation or representation in a
realistic, not merely in an aesthetic or metaphorical sense. The
permanent interest and value of Pico's view of nature comes
from his seeing the physical order as a translation of philosoph­
ical and religious truth. In this way, physics, philosophy,

1. Marsilio Ficino, the force behind the Platonic revival, was Pico’s most
2. important intellectual mentor. He was also the authority Pico chose to
3. challenge again and again during his career. When considering Pico’s
4. Platonism, Ficino and their relationship is the obvious place to begin.
5. Pico’s challenges and their very public debates highlight their differences
6. in opinion. These differences, as well as their similarities, allow a deeper
7. understanding of Pico’s very particular interests in Platonism.
8.
9. Ficino and Pico began as teacher and student in the early 1480s. But
10. their relationship was complex both in life and after Pico’s death. In the
11. twentieth century it was easy to see Pico as a member of the Platonic
12. Academy.48 Ficino refers to his Academy on multiple occasions. It was
13. understood to be a group of protégé friends, thinkers and patrons who
14. met regularly and whose work formed a relatively coherent opus within
15. the shared context of Ficino’s Platonic revival. This story of the Academy
16. had Ficino at the center, as leader of the Platonic revival, with Pico playing
17. ‘heir-apparent,’ as the young philosopher-prince. Pico is the Princeps
18. Concordiae of this Academy49 described by Ficino as a hero or demi-
19. God.50 Ficino encouraged this story of their intellectual proximity for
20. posterity crafting a narrative after Pico’s death which aligned the young
21. hero’s birth with the beginnings of Ficino’s study of Platonism, and Pico’s
22. arrival in Florence with Ficino’s publication of Plato’s works. According
23. to Ficino, Pico was inspired by Cosimo (Lorenzo’s father) de’ Medici’s
24.
25.
26.
27. 64 S. HOWLETT
28.
29. soul to come to Florence to inspire Ficino, in his turn, to study and trans-
30. late Plotinus.51 This reading of Ficino and Pico portrays Pico as essentially
31. a Platonist52 making Pico’s deviations from Ficino or outright contradic-
32. tions very confusing. Even if we do not accept the stories of heroes and
33. miracles, we would at least imagine Pico was Ficino’s most important
34. and closest disciple within the Academy. But the other approach to their
35. relationship comes from ‘Pico Studies’: those who focus only on Pico.53
36.
37. These works tend to sideline Ficino almost completely, to the point where
38. comparisons and influence disappear. It is almost as if Ficino does not exist
39. in Pico’s story.
40.
41. As so often, the truth lies somewhere in-between. It is hard to pinpoint
42. exactly as both Ficino and Pico are crafting their own self-narratives within
43. which each plays a supporting role, whether as hero or stooge. Two
44. resources give us a closer look: first their correspondence; and second,
45. their debates. If we look at Ficino’s letters, Pico first appears from his late
46. teens as the Aristotelian moving toward Plato. He is involved in more than
47. a fifth of Ficino’s correspondence between 1484 and 1488,54 whether
48. demanding books from Ficino’s library, or annoyed at Ficino’s constant
49. mythologizing of their relationship. The picture from these letters is of
50. Ficino as the benevolent teacher willing to guide and forgive all, and an
51. occasionally tetchy, recalcitrant but brilliant pupil. Pico demands or antag-
52. onizes, Ficino responds with more praise, attempting to gloss over their
53. disagreements.

23. sideline Kabbalism as central to Pico’s point of view (109): ‘Although

28. piece (110), downplaying the Conclusions. Further, Garin’s perceptions
29. of Pico as extolling man as the self-fashioner reflects the rising interest of
30. the times in existentialism (143). Indeed, Copenhaver argues that we are
31. not talking about ‘dignity’ at all in the Oration, remarking that ‘Because
32. Kant invented the modern concept, Pico could say nothing about it.’
33. (155).

1. soul to come to Florence to inspire Ficino, in his turn, to study and trans-
2. late Plotinus.51 This reading of Ficino and Pico portrays Pico as essentially
3. a Platonist52 making Pico’s deviations from Ficino or outright contradic-
4. tions very confusing. Even if we do not accept the stories of heroes and
5. miracles, we would at least imagine Pico was Ficino’s most important
6. and closest disciple within the Academy. But the other approach to their
7. relationship comes from ‘Pico Studies’: those who focus only on Pico.53
8.
9. These works tend to sideline Ficino almost completely, to the point where
10. comparisons and influence disappear. It is almost as if Ficino does not exist
11. in Pico’s story.
12.
13. As so often, the truth lies somewhere in-between. It is hard to pinpoint
14. exactly as both Ficino and Pico are crafting their own self-narratives within
15. which each plays a supporting role, whether as hero or stooge. Two
16. resources give us a closer look: first their correspondence; and second,
17. their debates. If we look at Ficino’s letters, Pico first appears from his late
18. teens as the Aristotelian moving toward Plato. He is involved in more than
19. a fifth of Ficino’s correspondence between 1484 and 1488,54 whether
20. demanding books from Ficino’s library, or annoyed at Ficino’s constant
21. mythologizing of their relationship. The picture from these letters is of
22. Ficino as the benevolent teacher willing to guide and forgive all, and an
23. occasionally tetchy, recalcitrant but brilliant pupil. Pico demands or antag-
24. onizes, Ficino responds with more praise, attempting to gloss over their
25. disagreements. Ficino excuses Pico’s abduction of Margherita calling the
26. couple ‘members of a superhuman race (he a hero and she a nymph)
27. and therefore above morality.’55 There are signs of a similarly sometimes
28. fractious relationship between Ficino and Angelo Poliziano. The debates
29. between Ficino and Pico are the points of rupture—the places where they
30. specifically and publicly engage with each other.
31.
32. Ficino is creating his ideal world peopled by heroes. In a letter to
33. Lorenzo de’ Medici Ficino praises his patron for supporting Poliziano,
34. that young Homeric scholar’56 and asks Lorenzo to continue to attract
35. such artists, for ‘other painters adorn the walls for a time, but these
36. render their inhabitants illustrious for ever.’57 Poliziano asks Ficino to
37. stop calling him ‘Hercules’ (Pico was Ficino’s ‘Apollo’), as if embar-
38. rassed by Ficino. Poliziano ‘bristled at Ficino’s style when Ficino asked
39. for his help in defending De vita (after 1489), and apparently found
40. Ficino’s lectures boring.’58 Certainly Ficino self-fashions as the benev-
41. olent mentor, and it must have been at times tedious. But there is also
42. repeated communication of greetings from Pico, and his friend, Poliziano,

2. this interpretation, Pico champions the human being as a powerful magus
3. who, released upon the world, can act upon it with an array of mysterious
4. magical and occult powers. One commentator has argued that “the com-
5. plete Renaissance Magus, as he burst upon the world for the first time
6. in Pico’s oration in his full power and Dignity, was a practitioner of both
7. natural magic and also of its ‘supreme form,’ practical Cabala,” and the
8. “oration was to echo and re-echo throughout the Renaissance, and it is,
9. indeed, the great charter of Renaissance magic.”126 This occultist account
10. of the Oratio, however, has perhaps been the most controversial approach
11. to Pico’s thought and has been the target of historical criticism.127

14. find antecedents, sources, and influences for Pico’s views on the human
15. condition, are some approaches that find in them seminal anticipations
16. of future historical movements and ideas. For instance, the fact that some
17. of Pico’s interests in the Oratio are theological, along with the fact that Pico
18. initially experienced difficulties at the hands of Roman church authori-
19. ties, has led a few commentators to portray Pico as an harbinger of the
20. Protestant Reformation and even to claim that Pico’s articulation of his
21. theses was nothing less than an unsuccessful version of Martin Luther’s
22. famous episode at Wittenberg.128 Other, arguably less careful, placements
23. of Pico in the history of ideas present him as an early Nietzschean philoso-

27.
28. proliferation of the many differing interpretations of Pico’s thought on
29. the human condition stems to a large degree from a failure to recog-
30. nize the essentially dialectical character of Pico’s procedure in the Oratio
31. and the 900 Theses. In his exegetical approach to authoritative opinions,
32. Pico does not hesitate to treat them in ways that produce, at times, figu-
33. rative and metaphorical confirmations of his views. Simply put, the fact
34. that Pico finds a dialectical confirmation of one of his views in a text from
35. an authority does not, in itself, commit Pico to the general philosophical
36. or theological outlook of that authority; Pico seeks corroboration of his
37. views, and this dialectical process of confirmation need not commit him
38. to an apology for the texts he cites. To give an example, consider the
39. approach that some commentators have taken in evaluating Pico’s rela-
40. tionship to the Hermetic texts attributed to Hermes Trismegistus. While
41. it must be admitted that in one place in the Oratio Pico cites a text from
42. Hermes Trismegistus, this citation does not suffice to establish the Oratio
43. as essentially a Hermetic document.

40. Giovanni Pico della Mirandola (1463–94) was the wunderkind among
41. Italian Renaissance philosophers and a key figure, along with Cusanus,
42. Bessarion, and Ficino, in the revival of Platonic metaphysics, though he
43. was not a devout Neoplatonist like Ficino but rather an Aristotelian by
44. training and in many ways an eclectic by conviction. Nonetheless, he
45. plunged as hardly more than a youth into the works of Plato, Plotinus,
46. Proclus, and other Neoplatonists, notably in the fifteen months or so
47. he spent in Florence from the spring of 1484 to the summer of 1485,
48. where he acquired a rare understanding of the Platonists’ methodology,
49. central postulates, and metaphysical distinctions. This Platonic educa-
50. tion was succeeded by nine months in Paris (July 1485 to March 1486)
51. and was subsequently harnessed to an encyclopedic, ambitious, essen-
52. tially Aristotelian plan. This was to gather together an array of Egyptian,
53. Chaldean, Greek, Hebrew (including Cabalistic), patristic, and scholastic
54. (including Arab) propositions rather than arguments or proofs as such –
55. an array which eventually amounted to 900 conclusions, 900 being the
56. numerological symbol of the soul’s ecstatic return to itself in philosoph-
57. ical study – and to defend them in Rome. The event would take place
58. early in 1487 in what he called a “council” but which would be in effect
59. a grand Parisian disputatio, and it would include, he hoped, the pope,
60. the College of Cardinals, and a number of eminent theologians and
61. philosophers (whose expenses he would cover!). While this breathtak-
62. ing proposal by a brilliant twenty-three-year-old had a positivistic dimen-
63. sion to it inasmuch as a number of the theses either concerned nature

Assistant

Drawing together the leading works you uploaded — Howlett, Dougherty, Zambelli, Farmer, and the Heptaplus text — here’s what new and cutting-edge research in Pico studies reveals beyond the older Yates-style picture of a “Hermetic magus.”

1. Pico as a Dialectical Theologian, Not a “Magus”


Recent scholarship rejects Frances Yates’s vision of Pico as the first “Renaissance magician.” M. V. Dougherty and Stephen A. Farmer both emphasize that the Oration and 900 Theses use magical and Kabbalistic material dialectically, to test Christian and philosophical claims rather than to found an occult science【49:6†(Medieval & Renaissance Texts & Studies 167)…†L29-L43】【49:7†M. V. Dougherty – Pico della Mirandola New Essays†L28-L43】. Pico’s citations of Hermes Trismegistus are rhetorical confirmations, not doctrinal commitments. Farmer shows that Pico wrote his “magical” works before Ficino’s De vita coelitus comparanda, so the idea of a disciple learning magic from Ficino collapses【49:8†(Medieval & Renaissance Texts & Studies 167)…†L37-L56】.

2. Neo-Aristotelianism and Humanist Theology


Sophia Howlett’s Re-evaluating Pico reframes him as a Neo-Aristotelian Christian humanist. She shows that his sustained debates with Ficino — on love (Commento sopra una canzone d’amore), on the relation of the One and Being (De ente et uno), and finally on astrology — mark a deliberate move toward reconciling Aristotle and Plato within a theological horizon【49:2†(Critical Political Theory and Radical Practice)…†L44-L56】. De ente et uno posits that Plato and Aristotle agree that God is both the One and Being, anchoring a synthesis between metaphysics and revealed theology. Howlett’s picture replaces the romantic “Prince of Concord” with a thinker forging a systematic, disputational scholasticism updated by humanist methods.

3. Ficino and Pico: Rival Visions of Platonism


Howlett’s close reading of their correspondence shows a decade-long dialogue of contestation. Ficino mythologized their friendship; Pico repeatedly contradicted him, especially on beauty and astrology. The letters display Pico as an “Aristotelian moving toward Plato,” while Ficino tried to cast him as his Platonic heir【49:0†(Critical Political Theory and Radical Practice)…†L9-L19】【49:1†(Critical Political Theory and Radical Practice)…†L1-L11】. This tension defines the new “Ficino–Pico axis” in Renaissance studies: complementary but irreducible approaches to reconciling philosophy and revelation.

4. From Syncretism to Christian Supernaturalism


Michael Sudduth, in Dougherty’s volume, highlights Pico’s religious frame: his syncretism always resolves into Christian supernaturalism — “all things ought to agree with Christ, who is the Truth itself”【49:14†M. V. Dougherty – Pico della Mirandola New Essays†L21-L24】. The new consensus sees Pico’s project not as secular universalism but as a theological defense of philosophy under papal scrutiny.

5. “Natural Magic” and Intellectual Context


Paola Zambelli’s White Magic, Black Magic restores Pico to the intellectual genealogy of natural magic shared with Ficino. Both grounded magic in Neoplatonism and Avicenna’s theory of imagination, eliminating demonic invocation and making it a branch of natural philosophy. By 1490 “natural magic” had become a respectable philosophical discourse【49:15†Paola Zambelli – White Magic, Black Magic in the European Renaissance†L38-L51】.

6. Pico’s Texts Re-read as Scriptural Science


Paul J. W. Miller’s introduction to the Heptaplus stresses Pico’s biblical exegesis as cosmology: Genesis encodes Platonic and Aristotelian physics, so that theology and natural science mirror one another. Man, the image of God, unites the physical and angelic worlds — a metaphysical anthropology rather than a manifesto of human self-creation【49:9†Heptaplus – On the Dignity of Man – Being and One†L113-L131】.

7. Toward a Post-Yates Historiography


Across these works runs a shared historiographic move:
  • replacing “Hermetic tradition” with Christian Platonism and prisca theologia (following Copenhaver and Walker);

  • re-situating Pico within scholastic logic and Aristotelian dialectic;

  • emphasizing theological orthodoxy, linguistic erudition, and humanist disputation rather than occult rebellion.


Summary: the cutting edge in Pico studies


ThemeNew Position
Magic & KabbalahInstrumental dialectic, not operative occultism
Philosophical AlignmentNeo-Aristotelian harmonization of Plato and Aristotle
Theological AimChristian supernaturalism guiding syncretism
Relation to FicinoContestatory dialogue shaping Renaissance Platonism
HermeticismReplaced by prisca theologia and Christian Platonism
MethodScholastic disputation + humanist philology
LegacyTransition from scholastic theology to humanist theology

In short, the contemporary frontier of Pico research portrays him not as a magician of will, but as a Christian philosopher-theologian using the tools of humanist philology and scholastic disputation to articulate the unity of truth across traditions — a move that now defines the post-Yates era of Renaissance intellectual history【49:6†(Medieval & Renaissance Texts & Studies 167)…†L29-L43】【49:14†M. V. Dougherty – Pico della Mirandola New Essays†L21-L24】【49:2†(Critical Political Theory and Radical Practice)…†L44-L56】【49:15†Paola Zambelli – White Magic, Black Magic in the European Renaissance†L38-L51】.

give me a reading of heptaplus taking all these new scholarly theories and reinterpretations into account

Assistant

Here’s a compact, forward-leaning reading of Heptaplus that fuses the neo-Aristotelian turn, humanist theology, the post-Yates reorientation of magic/Kabbalah, and the current Ficino–Pico reframing.

Heptaplus, re-read

1) What kind of book is Heptaplus—now?


Not a mystical collage but a technical work of biblical science: a seven-fold commentary on Genesis whose structure itself encodes method—elemental, celestial, angelic, human, and integrative “worlds.” That architecture (and Pico’s choice of Genesis 1) signals a program: bring natural philosophy (Aristotle), Platonic metaphysics, and Christian doctrine into one exegetical machine. fileciteturn49file9L120-L131

Methodologically, recent editors stress that Pico cites heterodox materials dialectically (to test positions), not as confessional commitments—so Hermetic/Kabbalistic pieces function as probative authorities within a scholastic disputation, not as an “occult creed.” fileciteturn49file7L28-L43

2) Humanist theology in action


Sudduth’s line—Pico’s syncretism resolves in Christian supernaturalism—fits Heptaplus exactly: “if all things agree with the truth… all things ought to agree with Christ.” The treatise stages agreement by making creation’s text (Genesis) the hub where philosophies converge and are measured against revelation. fileciteturn49file14L18-L24

Practically, this means: philology + patristics + Aristotle’s semantics (names, causes, categories) + Plotinian ascent are deployed to read Moses. It’s humanist in tools, scholastic in rigor, and theological in telos.

3) Neo-Aristotelian backbone


The contemporary view shifts Pico from a Ficinian Platonist to a scholastic metaphysician who seeks a concord of Plato with Aristotle—formulated programmatically in On Being and the One (God as both the One and Being). Read alongside Heptaplus, the six-day structure functions like a metaphysical grid: causes, natures, and powers are arrayed in a hylomorphic key rather than as free-floating emanations. fileciteturn49file2L44-L56

4) Anthropology: from “plastic man” to grace-ordered creature


Against the old “manifesto of self-fashioning” trope (from the Oration), Howlett notes a pivot: Heptaplus places the human within a hierarchy, awaiting grace, not above it by will alone. That is, the exegetical Pico reins in the rhetorical Pico—the anthropology becomes Augustinian-Aristotelian rather than existential. fileciteturn49file3L46-L48 (For the famous “wonder of man” proem in the same volume, see the Oration text printed with these selections. fileciteturn49file11L55-L63)

5) Kabbalah as hermeneutic technology (not an “occult system”)


Read with the post-Yates consensus: Pico mobilizes Hebrew philology, combinations, and names as a theory of scriptural meaning—a semiotics of creation—folded into Genesis commentary. It is instrumental and adjudicated by Christian doctrine, not a rival theology; hence the consistent insistence that the many “agree in Christ.” fileciteturn49file14L18-L24 fileciteturn49file7L28-L43

6) Natural magic, demoted and domesticated


Zambelli shows how, by the 1490s, natural magic (imagination, spiritus, astral correspondences) is debated as a branch of natural philosophy—separable from demonic invocation. In Heptaplus, cosmology is exegetical and doctrinal; any “magical” lexis is pressed into a law-like reading of nature under Genesis, not into techniques of power. fileciteturn49file15L38-L51

7) Anti-determinist horizon


Read retrospectively with the Disputationes in view, Heptaplus already constrains astrology by Genesis-first causality: the heavens are created goods, not fateful governors. The exegetical ordering of causes anticipates Pico’s later doctrinal case against divinatory determinism. (For the volume’s table confirming the tripartite “worlds,” see contents.) fileciteturn49file9L120-L131

8) How to read the seven “expositions” now (a practical map)

  • Elemental World (Exp. 1) — Treats matter/form, qualities, and mixture; map this to Aristotelian physics and hylomorphism under the literal sense of Genesis 1. fileciteturn49file9L126-L131

  • Celestial World (Exp. 2) — Stars and motions are subordinated to creation’s order; configure as non-determinist cosmology preparatory to the anti-astrological project. fileciteturn49file9L126-L131

  • Angelic/Invisible (Exp. 3) — Angelology as metaphysics of intellect; read with Plotinus/Proclus but corrected by Christian doctrine (creation ex nihilo). fileciteturn49file9L128-L131

  • Human World (Exp. 4) — Anthropological hinge: image/likeness, language, task of naming; integrate Aristotelian powers of soul with Augustinian grace (Howlett’s hierarchy point). fileciteturn49file3L46-L48 fileciteturn49file9L131-L134

  • All the Worlds (Exp. 5+) — Concord mechanics: scriptural literal–allegorical–anagogical ladders as a way to reconcile Plato–Aristotle inside Christian exegesis. fileciteturn49file9L131-L134


9) Why this matters for Pico’s “system”


  • It vindicates the post-Yates correction: citations of Hermes/Kabbalah don’t make the work “Hermetic”; they are dialectical instruments evaluated in a Christian frame. fileciteturn49file7L28-L43

  • It centers humanist theology: philology and rhetoric in service of dogma—Genesis as the arena where philosophical universals are tested by revelation. fileciteturn49file14L18-L24

  • It locks the treatise into the neo-Aristotelian arc culminating in On Being and the One: creation’s layered order is rendered in Aristotelian semantics and hylomorphism, not in free-form Neoplatonic emanation. fileciteturn49file2L44-L56


Micro-close-reading prompts (for your draft)


1) Track every place Pico ties naming to essence/function (Aristotelian semantics) within the creation days; note when he shifts from physics to angelology and how he justifies the shift exegetically (literal → spiritual senses). (Use the “Human World” and “All the Worlds” sections as anchors.) fileciteturn49file9L131-L134
2) Annotate where Hebrew letter-combinatorics appear—tag them “instrumental Kabbalah”—and write a marginal note: what doctrinal verdict follows? (Expect “agreement in Christ.”) fileciteturn49file14L18-L24
3) Mark every cosmological claim that weakens astral necessity; connect each to later anti-astrology theses. fileciteturn49file9L126-L131

Bottom line


Heptaplus is Pico’s exegetical engine: Aristotelian in scaffolding, Platonic in aspiration, Kabbalistic in method where useful, and frankly Christian in outcome—designed to harmonize learned traditions under Genesis rather than to enthrone “Magus-will.” This is why the new scholarship treats it as the doctrinal center of Pico’s project, not a side-text to a rhetorical Oration. fileciteturn49file7L28-L43 fileciteturn49file14L18-L24 fileciteturn49file2L44-L56

[L23] In 1486 Pico returned to Florence from his theological studies in Paris.
[L24] Here he had a new and original plan: to organize an international
[L25] council in Rome and to invite to it the best philosophers and theolo-
[L26] gians, to discuss and dispute nine hundred theological and philosophi-
[L27] cal theses which he collected from many sources. These theses included
[L28] much material which was new to Western Europe, taken from Neo-
[L29] platonic sources such as Plotinus and Proclus, and from the Jewish
[L30] Kabbalah. Pico published his theses in Rome in 1486. He was then
[L31] suspected of heresy by some theologians, who persuaded the pope to
[L32] appoint a commission, composed of theologians and experts on Roman
[L33] and Canon Law, to examine these theses. Of the nine hundred theses,
[L34] the commission found thirteen heretical or of dubious orthodoxy. Pico’s
[L35] Apologia, which he published in 1487 was his answer to the condemna-
[L36] tion of these thirteen theses.
[L37]
[L38] In this chapter I intend to deal with Pico’s humanist theology in the
[L39] context of the theological crisis of his time, as expressed mainly in his
[L40] Apologia. I shall focus both on Pico’s critical reaction to his condemned
[L41] theses and on his solution to the crisis. The discussion will be divided
[L42] into three phases. The first will deal with the general background to the
[L43] theological crisis. The second will be an analysis of Pico’s Apologia—his
[L44] response to and attack on the papal commission and on the contem-
[L45] porary scholastic theology, including his solution to the problem of fides
[L46]
[L47] and opinio. The third will explore the philosophical background to some
[L48] of the essential terms in the Apologia. I shall try to demonstrate here that
[L49] Pico uses terms and ideas which are associated with the ancient skep-
[L50] tical tradition and are derived from Cicero’s Academica and Augustine’s
[L51] Contra Academicos.1

[L23]
[L24] a dispute between the Platonists – in the persons of Lorenzo de’ Medici
[L25] and Marsilio Ficino – and the Peripatetics or those who, like Poliziano,
[L26] had always studied the texts of Aristotle. In reality, Pico seemed to dis-
[L27] agree with the very principles of the debate and used the invitation as
[L28] an occasion to articulate his theories on concord in public. To set Plato
[L29] against Aristotle had been one of the most arduous intellectual tasks for
[L30] a long time, so much so that the ideology of humanism had come up with
[L31] two diverse cultural strategies for dealing with, and certainly two different
[L32] models of understanding, the two philosophers. Pico did not succeed in
[L33] bringing the enterprise to a conclusion, but in De ente et uno he left a very
[L34] interesting model of how he would have proceeded.
[L35]
[L36] The question confronted in De ente et uno was not a new one for Pico,
[L37] who had discussed it already with Elia del Medigo, among others. If the
[L38] actual thesis of De ente et uno contained nothing new, certainly new was his
[L39] reevaluation of the Parmenides, Sophist, and Philebus and Simplicius’s com-
[L40] mentaries on Aristotle. His sophisticated project to read Plato not only
[L41] through Plotinus and Proclus but also through Aristotle and medieval
[L42] theologians also remained unpublished.18

[L1] Of the nine hundred theses,
[L2] the commission found thirteen heretical or of dubious orthodoxy. Pico’s
[L3] Apologia, which he published in 1487 was his answer to the condemna-
[L4] tion of these thirteen theses.
[L5]
[L6] In this chapter I intend to deal with Pico’s humanist theology in the
[L7] context of the theological crisis of his time, as expressed mainly in his
[L8] Apologia. I shall focus both on Pico’s critical reaction to his condemned
[L9] theses and on his solution to the crisis. The discussion will be divided
[L10] into three phases. The first will deal with the general background to the
[L11] theological crisis. The second will be an analysis of Pico’s Apologia—his
[L12] response to and attack on the papal commission and on the contem-
[L13] porary scholastic theology, including his solution to the problem of fides
[L14]
[L15] and opinio. The third will explore the philosophical background to some
[L16] of the essential terms in the Apologia. I shall try to demonstrate here that
[L17] Pico uses terms and ideas which are associated with the ancient skep-
[L18] tical tradition and are derived from Cicero’s Academica and Augustine’s
[L19] Contra Academicos.1
[L20]
[L21] 1 Pico’s place in the skeptical tradition (both Academic and Pyrrhonian) of the
[L22] fifteenth century still needs to be explored through a detailed study of all his works
[L23] in regard to ancient skeptical terms, arguments, and modes of thought, as well as
[L24]
[L25]
[L26]
[L27] 280 chapter four
[L28]
[L29] If there is still a necessity in the context of his humanist theology
[L30] to show Pico’s connection to humanism, this chapter will show Pico’s
[L31] Academic and skeptical debt to Cicero and Augustine, and his use
[L32] of this philosophical-rhetorical tradition in his counter-attack on the
[L33] scholastic theologians and on the papal commission.2 Pico’s Apologia
[L34]
[L35] is an embodiment both of his humanist side, i.e., the use of ancient
[L36] sources, and of the theological side, i.e., his deep acquaintance with
[L37] both patristic (Greek and Latin) and scholastic theology.
[L38]
[L39] Pico’s unique place among this remarkable group of individuals
[L40] called ‘humanists’ has been known to modern scholars at least since the
[L41] works of Garin.3 Pico is often represented in the secondary literature
[L42]
[L43] comparisons with his fellow-humanists (especially Ficino and Poliziano), and taking
[L44] into consideration the Florentine intellectual context of the late fifteenth century as
[L45] a whole. This is beyond the scope of this chapter, which offers a limited presentation
[L46] of the way in which Pico used ancient Academic skeptical terms in his argumentation
[L47] against the papal commission and the scholastic theology of his time, thus exploring
[L48] a theological crisis and constituting a humanist theology. For Pico’s use of Sextus
[L49] Empiricus in his composition against astrology see Gian Mario Cao, ‘The Prehistory
[L50] of Modern Scepticism: Sextus Empiricus in Fifteenth-Century Italy’, in Journal of the
[L51] Warburg and Courtauld Institutes LXIV (2001), pp. 229–279; especially 259–260; for a more
[L52] general discussion on Sextus’ transmission see Luciano Floridi, Sextus Empiricus—The
[L53] Transmission and Recovery of Pyrrhonism (Oxford 2002); for Pico’s use of skeptical notions
[L54] in his philosophical ideas and writings, but from a completely different point of view,
[L55] see De Pace, Le scepsi…; especially pp. 111–159. It seems that for De Pace there is Pico
[L56] scepticus, which replaces the Pico platonicus, aristotelicus, or averroeticus, already discussed in
[L57] modern scholarship.

[L1] Further, as the ‘pure thought’ of
[L2] God, by the law of mean terms of an emanatory universe, divine thought
[L3] could be linked with human contemplation in Bahir.33
[L4]
[L5] Judaism was not the only religion to relate a community of believers,
[L6] prayer, and ascent. It is also core to Pseudo-Dionysius’ work and therefore
[L7] familiar as a concept to Pico. Pseudo-Dionysius is also borrowing from
[L8] Platonic gnostic traditions. So, however individualized ascent becomes
[L9] in Pico’s work and others of his period, there is a common foundation
[L10] here: a pathway that begins with prayer that takes the people of God back
[L11] to God. But where then is the Plotinian One? Is it Keter or the Ein-
[L12] Sof ? And what of the First Cause? Pico has told us that God is ‘being
[L13] itself,’ potentially an Aristotelian argument, whereas the Plotinian One is
[L14] considered, by Plotinus and Ficino, to be above being. The question of
[L15]
[L16]
[L17]
[L18] 142 S. HOWLETT
[L19]
[L20] being and God is the topic of Pico’s last finished work, Being and the
[L21] One. There Pico outlines an apparently Aristotelian point of view that
[L22] being and the One are the same, thereby equating the ‘One’ with the
[L23] First Cause. But he argues that this is also Plato’s original perspective, later
[L24] misinterpreted by his followers. As we have seen, he states that the One,
[L25] being, truth, and the good are all in correspondence, and are the same in
[L26] extent. He juxtaposes this with the received Platonic view that the One is
[L27] prior to being meaning that ‘the one is more simple and more universal.
[L28] For this reason they also say that God, whose is the highest simplicity,
[L29] is one, but not that he is being.’34 The problem, simply stated, is how
[L30] can the point of singularity, the unity, the undivided One, be more than
[L31] one thing or is the One here (understood numerically) simply a misnomer
[L32] for the ‘nought.’ More persuasively, this maybe another example of the
[L33] Ein-Sof /Keter separation: there is a Plotinian One that is above being as
[L34] ‘abstract’ unity or singularity, and a One that contains being and all other
[L35] attributes of the divine as the creative, active principle (coordinated unity
[L36] or pleroma) that necessarily must contain everything (as their cause) in
[L37] order to overflow and become multiple.
[L38]
[L39] Plato’s Parmenides and The Sophist both state that being and the
[L40] One are not the same. But Pico argues that in Parmenides, for example
[L41] ‘Nothing in the whole dialogue is positively asserted. If anything is
[L42] asserted, still nothing is clearly found by which we may ascribe this sort of
[L43] teaching to Plato.’ Further, Pico asserts ‘That book is certainly not to be
[L44] included among his doctrinal works, since it is nothing but a dialectical
[L45] exercise. The words themselves of the dialogue are so far from refuting
[L46] our opinion that there are no more arbitrary and forced commentaries
[L47] than those brought in by persons wishing to interpret the Parmenides of
[L48] Plato in another sense.’35 In other words, Pico sees Parmenides as a ‘red
[L49] herring’ followed by later Platonists, but not Plato’s point of view. This is
[L50] a weak parrying of an inconvenient text, but part of a series of arguments
[L51] that examine the relationship between being and the One from a variety
[L52] of different perspectives.

Title: Heptaplus, Pico della Mirandola - On the Dignity of Man - Being and One- (1965).pdf

[L1] Pi co's examination of the problem of being and unity was
[L2] occasioned by a discussion in which Lorenzo dei Medici had
[L3] maintained the Platonic view that the one was higher than
[L4] being. Lorenzo had doubtless been following the traditional
[L5] ancient and medieval interpretation of Plato's Parmenides,
[L6] adopted also by his friend Marsilio Ficino. Pico's On Being and
[L7] the One was written to show Plato is in merely verbal, not in
[L8] real disagreement with Aristotle, who maintained that the one
[L9] is convertible with or equivalent to being.
[L10]
[L11] Modern critics rightly emphasize that the literary form of
[L12] Plato's dialogues often serves as a key to their philosophic
[L13] meaning. Pico was one of the first to remark this. He holds that
[L14] Plato, in the Parmenides, did not intend to assert any positive
[L15] theological or metaphysical doctrines, and that the structure of
[L16] the eight opposed hypotheses of the dialogue shows that Plato
[L17] intended only a dialectical exercise. It is a dialogue of method
[L18] and not of metaphysical content.
[L19]
[L20] Ficino's interpretation had been influenced by the Neopla­
[L21] tonic emphasis on the first hypothesis of the dialogue. This first
[L22] hypothesis describes the ineffable transcendence of the one,
[L23] which is above and apart from all being and determination.
[L24] No being can be affirmed of or connected with the one. This
[L25] interpretation. which reads the opening hypothesis as a negative
[L26] description of the one as a pure identity beyond relatedness,
[L27] had gained added authority and plausibility from the commen­
[L28] tary on the Parmenides written by the Neoplatonist Proclus.
[L29] The commentary breaks off at the end of the first hypothesis,
[L30] with the celebrated texts in which Plato says that the one is
[L31] beyond any positive being or definition. Any reader who in­
[L32] terprets the dialogue more from Proclus' commentary than
[L33] from the dialectic of all eight hypotheses tends to conclude that
[L34] these are Plato's last and most profound words on the one.
[L35] Proclus' commentary had greatly influenced the Christian inter-
[L36]
[L37]
[L38]
[L39] xx INTRODUCTION
[L40]
[L41] pretation of Pseudo-Dionysius, and, in its thirteenth-century
[L42] Latin translation, had been read by the later medieval and
[L43] Renaissance thinkers.
[L44]
[L45] Pico's interpretation, that the first hypothesis of the Parmen­
[L46] ides is no more important than the other seven, and that
[L47] Plato's intent was not to disclose a profound metaphysical
[L48] mystery, is based on a new emphasis on the form and method of
[L49] Plato's dialectic. Pico has attempted to disengage Plato's orig­
[L50] inal meaning from the misleading emphasis of a partial com­
[L51] mentary. (Ficino, in his commentary on the Parmenides, begun
[L52] in the same year as Pico's On Being and the One, 1492, replies
[L53] that Pico's interpretation is "against the opinion of all the
[L54] Platonists."7 For Ficino, following Plotinus and Proclus, Plato's
[L55] dialectical form is only an outer covering for a profound meta­
[L56] physical content.)
[L57]
[L58] Pico's reinterpretation of Plato bears on content as well as
[L59] form. He shows that Plato's metaphysics is equivalent to Ari­
[L60] stotle's by reinterpreting both, using notions derived from
[L61] medieval philosophy.

[L34]
[L35] Christians influenced by Plato identify Plato's one with God.
[L36] The one is a pure identity; it is not another determinate being.
[L37] What Plato says of the one can be applied to God, since God
[L38] too is not another determinate essence or nature having certain
[L39] formal characteristics. God does not have any of the determina­
[L40] tions or properties of creatures. Pico attempts to show that,
[L41] granted the identification of God with the one, it does not fol­
[L42] low that God or the one is above being, in any sense which
[L43] would contradict Aristotle. Aristotle's God, who is the highest
[L44] or most perfectly actual being, is the same as Plato's. This iden­
[L45] tity is brought about by Pico's identifying both with the God of
[L46] Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.
[L47]
[L48] In a standard medieval distinction, employed by Pico, being
[L49] may be either (1) all that which is not nothing, or (2) that
[L50] which does not lack existence (esse). In the first sense of being,
[L51] the things that are, and the things that are one, are exactly the
[L52] same things. Aristotle rightly said that being and one are merely
[L53]
[L54] 7 Marsilio Ficino, In Parmenidem, II, 1164.
[L55]
[L56]
[L57]
[L58] INTRODUCTION xxi
[L59]
[L60] two ways of describing the same things. Everything that is has
[L61] both (a) being and (b) unity. Pico interprets Plato in such a
[L62] way that Plato is simply assimilated to Aristotle on this point.
[L63] Plato said that not-being was a principle of relative being, or
[L64] otherness. Not-being enables beings to be different from other
[L65] beings. So, in Plato, the many, or the not-one, or the different,
[L66] are based on not-being. And if the not-one is not-being, then
[L67] the one must be being. Plato is back in agreement with Ari­
[L68] stotle's view that the one and being are the same.

[L1] Pico aimed at reconciling Plato and Aristotle as two individual
[L2] authors, leaving aside their interpreters. As a result, Pico tried to do with Plato
[L3] what many humanists were trying to do with Aristotle. Pico deconstructed
[L4] the very idea of philosophical tradition, or rather offered an alternative and
[L5] radically new interpretation of this tradition. In the context of the De ente et
[L6] uno, Pico argues that the Neoplatonic notions of One and Being were based
[L7] on a distortion of the Platonic dialogues (particularly the Parmenides and the
[L8] Sophist), and that Plato and Aristotle had unanimously agreed on the fact that
[L9] God could be both One and Being. The implications of this thesis were that, ac­
[L10] cording to Pico, if God could be both One and Being, negative theology ceased
[L11] to be the only valid way of describing God. Thus, contrary to what Ficino had
[L12] stated, the Neoplatonic and Christian mystical tradition was not the only valid
[L13] way to deal with theological matters; Pico admits that the scholastic tradition
[L14] of using affirmations about God was equally acceptable.
[L15]
[L16] Likewise, in the context of astrology, Pico provides a meticulous analysis of
[L17] all astrological sources and argues that all these sources were based on a cor­
[L18] rupt and distorted interpretation of the original auctoritates. On account of the
[L19] discrepancies, which compromised the integrity of the discipline as a whole,
[L20] Pico concludes that astrology could not be regarded as a trustworthy field of
[L21] knowledge. Unlike Ficino’s legacy and Pico’s own earlier works that aimed at
[L22] reconciling frictions amongst contradictory texts in order to present a univer­
[L23] sal, indissoluble and everlasting religious teaching, after 1491, Pico adopted an
[L24] entirely different method of challenging the auctoritates. It does not appear
[L25] to be Pico’s invention; Lorenzo Valla confronted scholasticism in a similar
[L26] fashion.3 What Pico did in his late writings with respect to Platonism, and
[L27] then to astrology, adhered to this approach. The same attitude—a humanist,
[L28] critical examination of the historical interpretations of canonical sources—
[L29] can be traced through both the De ente et uno and the Disputationes.
[L30]

Assistant

Here’s a tight close reading of the Aquinas and Dionysius strands inside Pico’s De ente et uno (“On Being and the One”), framed by Howlett’s neo-Aristotelian reading and Edelheit’s humanist-theology thesis.

1) Pico’s Dionysian opening: “the One above being”


Early in De ente et uno Pico announces a Dionysian apex: God is “above being,” and “the one above being.” He quotes Pseudo-Dionysius, De divinis nominibus—“‘The One is called God because he is all things in one’; and again, ‘He is called One because he is the principle of all things which are, as unity is the principle of all numbers.’” Pico uses these to justify calling God “One” not as a definition of essence but as the modus in which God is all that he is and in which creatures are from him. fileciteturn4file1L16-L24

Takeaway: Pico starts from apophatic altitude (Dionysius’ “beyond being”) but immediately treats “One” as a name of procession (principle/cause), a move that sets up an eventual reconciliation with Aristotelian metaphysics.

Howlett’s gloss fits this: Pico is trying to keep both a “One that is above being” (abstract unity) and a “One that contains being” (creative plenitude). She reads De ente et uno as Pico’s attempt to show that Plato’s and Aristotle’s positions converge when you distinguish these senses of “One/Being” (and to correct Ficino’s absolutizing of the first, ultra-apophatic sense). fileciteturn4file7L20-L37

2) Bringing in Aristotle—and then Aquinas—to ‘place’ God “above being”


Pico pivots: if some think Aristotle “disagrees” with Plato because Aristotle doesn’t put God “under” being, they “haven’t read Aristotle.” Citing Metaphysics VI, he argues that “being per se” is divided into ten categories and God belongs to none; hence God is “above being.” Pico clinches this with Aquinas: “as Thomas teaches in the Sentences I, d.19, q.4, a.1.” fileciteturn4file1L35-L55

Close-reading move: the phrase “as Thomas teaches” matters. For Pico, Aquinas is the authoritative witness that Aristotelian doctrine already contains a way to say God is not a member of the categorical “is”—thereby translating Dionysian ‘beyond being’ into Aristotelian semantics (God = above the categories).

This is precisely the neo-Aristotelian arc Howlett tracks: Pico isn’t subordinating Aristotle to Dionysius; he’s showing Aristotle + Aquinas can say what Dionysius safeguards—without ceding the field to pure negation. fileciteturn4file2L32-L39

3) From names to “four steps…to the darkness which God inhabits”


Immediately after aligning Aristotle and Plato on the names One and Good for God (again echoing Dionysius), Pico introduces “four steps to the darkness which God inhabits.” That “darkness” is straight Dionysian apophatic imagery, now staged as an ascent after a cataphatic clarification (God as One/Good). fileciteturn4file3L13-L35

Reading: Pico orders theology—cataphatic naming (Aristotle/Aquinas) leading into apophatic ascent (Dionysius). He refuses a one-way via negativa; ascent is earned after correct predication.

Akopyan makes the same macro-point about De ente et uno: if God can be both One and Being, negative theology cannot be the only valid way to speak of God; affirmative (scholastic) predication also has standing. Pico is quietly relocating Dionysius within a broader grammar of names. fileciteturn4file14L9-L14

4) The Aquinas function: securing convertibility of “one” and “being”


Pico’s doctrinal maneuver hinges on a scholastic distinction (already classic by Aquinas’ day): in one sense, “being” names all that is not nothing; in this sense, ens and unum are convertible—“two ways of saying the same thing.” That lets Pico re-read Plato through Aristotle and medieval semantics, so that Plato’s “not-being” (otherness/difference) implies that the one = being by opposition. fileciteturn4file10L48-L68

Close-reading point: This is where Aquinas’ semantics (about the transcendental convertibility of ens/unum) does heavy lifting. Pico uses it to neutralize Ficino’s reading of Parmenides as privileging the pure, ineffable One “above” all being in a way that blocks predication. He answers with a Dionysian apex + Thomist semantics combination: God is beyond beings as categories, yet is rightly named One/Good, and ens/unum co-extend as transcendentals.

Howlett explicitly traces Pico’s page-by-page use of these De ente et uno moves (she cites the standard English pagination) to argue that Pico thinks Plato actually agrees with Aristotle when properly read—i.e., “One, Being, Truth, Good” are co-extensive names of God/first cause. fileciteturn4file2L16-L25 fileciteturn4file4L51-L56

5) What this shows about Pico’s “method” (Edelheit)


Edelheit’s contribution is about genre and authority: De ente et uno isn’t a mystical outburst but a piece of technical theology deploying patristic (Dionysius), Aristotelian, and scholastic (Aquinas) materials to settle a live dogmatic-philosophical dispute in Florence: is the One “beyond being” (Ficino/Lorenzo’s line), or are One and Being co-extensive names for God? Edelheit argues Pico’s broader project is humanist theology—philology + patristics + scholastic logic under the primacy of Scripture/Creed and against the elevation of commentators to quasi-canonical authority. De ente et uno is exemplary of that method: harmonize authorities by technical distinctions, not by oracular pronouncements. fileciteturn4file13L25-L37 fileciteturn4file0L1-L10

6) Synthesis: how Aquinas + Dionysius work together in Pico (per Howlett + Edelheit)

  • Dionysius gives Pico the vertical register: God transcends categorical being; the ascent into “darkness” marks the limits of discourse. fileciteturn4file3L30-L35

  • Aquinas gives Pico the semantic register: ens/unum as transcendentally convertible lets us speak truly of God (One/Good) without collapsing God into a genus. fileciteturn4file1L42-L55 fileciteturn4file10L48-L68

  • Howlett: Pico choreographs these so that Platonic apophasis and Aristotelian predication coincide, correcting Ficino by showing Plato never meant to exclude being from the One; rather, different senses of “one/being” must be distinguished. fileciteturn4file7L20-L37

  • Edelheit: the very way Pico argues—quoting Dionysius, Aristotle, Aquinas, then sorting senses—is humanist-theological practice: a technical disputation that subordinates commentator-authority to careful analytic reconciliation in the service of Christian doctrine. fileciteturn4file13L25-L37


One paragraph you can lift into your draft


In De ente et uno, Pico aligns Dionysius’ “One above being” with Aquinas’ semantics of transcendentals to show that God is “beyond” categorical being yet still rightly predicated as One/Good/Being. He cites Dionysius to mark apophatic height—“the One…principle of all things”—then cites Aristotle via Aquinas (In I Sent. d.19 q.4 a.1) to place God outside the ten categories, securing “above being” without silencing names. The result, as Howlett argues, is a neo-Aristotelian reconciliation: Plato and Aristotle converge once “One/Being” are read in their proper senses; and, as Edelheit emphasizes, the procedure itself is humanist theology—a technical, philological, and scholastic harmonization rather than a mystical fiat. fileciteturn4file1L16-L24 fileciteturn4file1L35-L55 fileciteturn4file3L30-L35 fileciteturn4file10L48-L68 fileciteturn4file2L16-L25 fileciteturn4file13L25-L37

If you want, I can map each Dionysian citation and each Aquinas locus in De ente et uno into a two-column table (text → function in Pico’s argument) for quick insertion into your chapter.

[L13] 26.3. The substantial qualities of visible things do not reflect downwards from
[L14]
[L15] a particular separated power, as the Egyptians believe, but from the first recep-
[L16]
[L17] tacle of the font of light, through animate splendor.
[L18]
[L19] 26.4. Partial souls are not illuminated immediately by the splendor of intellect,
[L20]
[L21] as the Egyptians say, but through the mediation of total demonical souls.
[L22]
[L23] 26.5. The intelligible order does not subsist within the intellectual order, as
[L24]
[L25] Ahmose the Egyptian said, but over the whole intellectual hierarchy, unparti-
[L26]
[L27] cipatively hidden in the abyss of the first unity, and under the cloud of the
[L28]
[L29] first darkness.
[L30]
[L31] 26.6. Whatever exists from the moon upwards is pure light, and that is the
[L32]
[L33] substance of the mundane spheres. (345)
[L34]
[L35] 26.2. On hierarchical modes of necessity, cf. 24.2 and note.
[L36]
[L37] 26.3. “first receptacle of the font of light” = the intellectual nature; “animate splendor” = the
[L38]
[L39] world soul. The thesis provides a strong affirmation of emanationism. See 2.17 note.
[L40]

[L42]
[L43] Egyptians. Re illuminationism.

[L54] the ancient and medieval medical, astrological, and philosophical sources cited by
[L55]
[L56] Ficino—it is not clear in what way a magical revival was needed in the Renais-
[L57]
[L58] *? Opera, 121. Like several other personal references, this one is suspiciously dropped
[L59] from the parallel section of the Oration published by Pico’s nephew after his uncle’s death.
[L60]
[L61] Cf. Opera, 328; Garin, Saitti vari, 152.
