Assistant

Amazing passage set. Here’s a close reading + commentary on Pico’s Conclusiones secundum priscam doctrinam Mercurii Trismegisti Aegyptii I.27.1–10 (with corollary), keyed to the Latin and to the post-Yates reading you asked for. I’ll use Farmer’s critical text/notes for the Latin and numbering, and bring in the Kabbalah/Hermetic context when it matters.

The Ten Hermetic Conclusions (I.27)

27.1 Ubicunque vita: ibi anima: ubicunque anima: ibi mens.


Text (Farmer): “Wherever there is life, there is soul; wherever there is soul, there is mind.” fileciteturn5file0L21-L29
Reading. The axiom compresses a Hermetic chain of being: vita → anima → mens. Pico lifts it as a metaphysical grammar, not as occult dogma. In his larger system the step from soul to mind aligns with the rational/intellectual powers (Farmer notes this association explicitly). fileciteturn5file2L53-L55
Comment. On the neo-Aristotelian reading, this is hylomorphic: “life” signals form; “soul” is the formal principle; “mind” is the highest act of soul. Pico is staging Hermetic diction within an Aristotelian psychology he elsewhere makes explicit (cf. De ente et uno). The move is dialectical—not a pledge of Hermetic creed.

27.2 Omne motum corporeum: omne movens incorporeum.


Text: “Everything moved is corporeal; everything moving is incorporeal.” fileciteturn5file0L25-L27
Reading. Motus belongs to bodies; the mover (principle) is incorporeal. Pico is importing an Aristotelian-Platonic commonplace (unmoved movers/immaterial intelligences) under Hermetic branding; Farmer points to Pico’s larger interlinked series on motion. fileciteturn5file2L91-L91
Comment. This is classic Aristotelian causality smuggled into a Hermetic section: the “Egyptian” veneer is a rhetorical cover for scholastic metaphysics.

27.3 Anima in corpore: mens in anima: in mente verbum: tum horum pater deus.


Text: “The soul is in the body; the mind in the soul; the Word in the mind; and the Father of these is God.” fileciteturn5file0L27-L31
Reading. A nested presence-schema culminating in Verbum and Deus.
Comment. Pico lets Christian Logos-theology flash through the Hermetic layers: the Verbum in mente gestures to Trinitarian predication. It typifies Edelheit’s claim that Pico’s syncretism resolves in Christian supernaturalism—authorities are harmonized to serve dogma, not vice-versa. (Edelheit’s broader thesis of humanist theology supplies the frame for this maneuver.) fileciteturn5file11L20-L26

27.4 Deus circa omnia atque per omnia: mens circa animam: anima circa aerem: aer circa materiam.


Text: “God around all and through all; mind around soul; soul around air; air around matter.” fileciteturn5file0L31-L35
Reading. An emanative concentric order: circa/per marks a causal embrace rather than spatial enclosure.
Comment. Read post-Yates: this is not “operative magic.” Farmer underlines that Pico’s Hermetic set contains no astrological magic; the image is cosmological, not talismanic. fileciteturn5file14L42-L48
For Pico this dovetails with the world-soul ladder he maps across other traditions (Proclus/Chaldaica/Kabbalah), but the final arbiter remains Christian doctrine.

27.5 Nihil est in mundo expers vitae.


Text: “Nothing in the world is devoid of life.” fileciteturn5file0L35-L37
Reading. A pan-vital axiom.
Comment. Pico reads this through seminal reasons / animating forms, not crude animism. Farmer cross-links 27.5–27.6 to other theses about universal animation, where “life” tracks formal causality more than psyche in the biological sense. fileciteturn5file0L49-L51

27.6 Nihil est in universo passibile mortis vel corruptionis.


Text: “Nothing in the universe is capable of death or corruption.” fileciteturn5file0L37-L40
Reading. Bold—but read it as a metaphysical universal: the whole (order and causes) is incorruptible though its parts undergo generation/corruption.
Comment. Typical Pico: a paradox that dissolves under scholastic distinctions (per se vs. per accidens; totality vs. sublunary composition). The corollary confirms the theological horizon.

Corollary


Ubique vita: ubique providentia: ubique immortalitas. — “Life everywhere; providence everywhere; immortality everywhere.” fileciteturn5file1L79-L86
Comment. The Hermetic “everywhere” is baptized as Christian providentia. This is the signature of humanist theology (Edelheit): prisca dicta are sifted so they “agree with Christ,” not enthroned as parallel revelation.

27.7 Sex viis futura…: dreams, portents, birds, entrails, spirit, Sibyl.


Text: “God announces the future to man in six ways: through dreams, portents, birds, intestines, spirit, and the Sibyl.” fileciteturn5file0L42-L44
Reading. A catalogue of divinatory media.
Comment. Pico records the historic scope of prisca sapientia; he doesn’t license the arts. Elsewhere he will attack divinatory determinism (Disputationes). Farmer notes how conspicuously astrological-magical items are missing from the Hermetic ten—important for the post-Yates correction. fileciteturn5file14L42-L48

Addenda under “Theses according to the opinions of others”

27.8 Verum est: quod non perturbatum… penitus incorporeum.


Text (Latin): the “true” is undisturbed, indeterminate, uncolored, unfigured, unshaken; naked, perspicuous, self-comprehensible; immutable good and wholly incorporeal. fileciteturn5file0L59-L64
Reading. A Dionysian/apophatic portrait of Truth/Good.
Comment. Pico slots this into his Aquinas-compatible semantics: God is “beyond” categorical being yet truly called One/Good/Being. This is where your Howlett thread bites: Hermetic apophasis is integrated with neo-Aristotelian predication, not opposed to it.

27.9 Decem intra unumquemque sunt ultores… (the ten “avengers”).


Text: ignorance, sadness, inconstancy, desire, injustice, luxury, envy, fraud, anger, malice. Pico’s emendation later drops two items (deceptio, temeritas) as superfluous—Farmer notes the 1487 corrections. fileciteturn5file0L65-L81
Reading. A moral psychology keyed to a denary.
Comment. This anticipates 27.10’s Kabbalistic aside: Pico sees a bad denary coordination (a corrupt reflection of the ten) answering to sefirotic structure. It’s a polemical mirror: ten vices parody ten emanations.

27.10 …correspondere male coordinationi denariae in cabala… est secretum.


Text: The “deep contemplator” will see those ten avengers “correspond” to a bad denary coordination in Kabbalah and to its rulers; Pico adds that he omitted these in his Kabbalistic conclusions “because it is a secret.” fileciteturn5file0L69-L75
Reading. Two big signals:
1) Pico explicitly cross-maps Hermetic moral taxonomy to Kabbalistic structure;
2) He withholds details—“est secretum”—consistent with contemporary esotericism around sefirotic attributions.
Context. Wirszubski’s index shows how the Mercurian set (I.27) interlocks with Pico’s Kabbalah dossier (pp. 187–88 and passim), including the soul↔sefirot correspondences Pico sketches elsewhere. fileciteturn5file7L1-L14 fileciteturn5file6L32-L47
Busi/Ebgi note Pico’s striking psychologization of Mercurius and the soul-sefirot matching (Yesod/Mercury as mediating function), sharpening the “denary” lens Pico invokes here. fileciteturn5file10L1-L10

How this set works in the cutting-edge Pico

  • Not “Hermetic magic” but cosmo-psychology: Farmer stresses these ten lack the astrological magic Ficino tied to Hermes; Pico cites Mercury for metaphysics and moral psychology, not for spell-craft. fileciteturn5file14L42-L48

  • Humanist-theological sieve (Edelheit). The corollary’s providentia shows the Christian filter: prisca dicta are true insofar as they can be theologized. fileciteturn5file1L79-L86 fileciteturn5file11L20-L26

  • Neo-Aristotelian control (Howlett). The set’s “mind over motion,” “incorporeal mover,” and apophatic 27.8 are stabilized by the Aquinas/Dionysius synthesis that Pico works out programmatically in De ente et uno: apophasis plus predication.

  • Hermes + Kabbalah without occultism. 27.10’s “bad denary” is a moral counter-sefirot; the secretum stance matches Pico’s recurring claim that some cabalistic attributions must be kept esoteric (Wirszubski). fileciteturn5file4L21-L29 fileciteturn5file6L29-L36


A few line-by-line “use in draft” glosses

  • 27.1–27.3: Hermetic ladder recoded as Aristotelian psychology → culminates in Verbum—> Trinitarian teleology. fileciteturn5file0L21-L31

  • 27.4: Concentric “around/through” = causal embrace, not astral rites. (Farmer: zero Hermetic talismans in this set.) fileciteturn5file0L31-L35 fileciteturn5file14L42-L48

  • 27.5–27.6 + Corollary: Universal vitality + providence/immortality read as metaphysical/Providential, not animist. fileciteturn5file0L35-L40 fileciteturn5file1L79-L86

  • 27.7: Catalogues historical divinatory media; later anti-astrology remains intact. fileciteturn5file0L42-L44

  • 27.8: Apophatic profile of Truth compatible with Thomist transcendentals. fileciteturn5file0L59-L64

  • 27.9–27.10: Ten vices ↔ “bad denary” in Kabbalah; note Pico’s 1487 emendation trimming the list (deceptio/temeritas)—a revealing sign of active editorial conscience. fileciteturn5file0L77-L83


Bottom line


This Hermetic block reads, on today’s frontier, as Pico’s test-bench: he extracts cosmology, psychology, and apophasis from Hermes, then integrates and judges them using Aristotelian-scholastic distinctions and Christian providence—precisely what the Howlett (neo-Aristotelian harmonization) and Edelheit (humanist-theological sieve) paradigms predict. The upshot aligns with Farmer’s documentary point: the “Hermetic Pico” here is not the engine of astrological magic but a philological theologian parsing prisca authorities under doctrinal reason. fileciteturn5file14L42-L48

HERMES TRISMEGISTUS, De sex rerum principiis, ed. Paolo Lucentini and Mark D. Delp.
(Corpus Christianorum, Continuatio Mediaeualis, 142; Hermes Latinus, 2.) Turnhout:
Brepols, 2006. Pp. iv, 229 plus 4 black-and-white facsimiles; 1 black-and-white figure.
?110.

Mark Damien Delp and Paolo Lucentini have prepared an excellent edition of the Liber
de sex rerum principiis, a cosmological text written under the pseudonym of Hermes Tris
megistus, which, according to the detailed analysis provided here, was composed in the
second half of the twelfth century. The book is divided into two parts, a comprehensive
study, in English, by Delp and the edition of the text, with an Italian introduction, by
Lucentini.

In the first part of the book Delp offers a precise analysis of the text, which has received
little attention by modern scholars. Previous analyses have been limited to the recognition
of its copious verbatim quotations of Firmicus Maternus and of Arabic astrology or its
development of the notion natura as inherited from the Latin philosophical tradition. Delp's
study of the history of the text presents the limits of previous research (Theodore Silverstein,
1955) and provides the Hermetic attribution of the Liber and details of the manuscript
tradition.

Before turning to his analysis of the content of the Liber, Delp suggests three criteria
the attribution in the manuscript tradition to Hermes or some Hermetic appellation, the
content of the text, the nature of its reception by posterity-that help to establish the
Hermetic legitimacy of the text. The Liber is compared with other relevant medieval texts
in order to demonstrate its sources. Delp shows that the text is extremely complex and that
it defies categorization as to genre (cosmological, astrological, metaphysical, encyclopedic).

The Liber poses many difficulties (dating, influences, authorship), and Delp satisfactorily
unveils its textual and historical background. His study discloses the internal structure of
the text and makes clear the author's use of his authorities (Bernardus Silvestris, William
of Conches, Honorius Augustodunensis, Adelard of Bath). The content of the Liber has
affinities with the latter part of the Hermetic tradition in its concern with astrological
material of a wide variety of topics (the qualitative natures of the constellations and planets,
the astrological stages of the development of mankind between great world periods, etc.)
that are commonly recognized as belonging to technical Hermetica. The treatise proceeds
in a hierarchical manner, beginning with the metaphysical nature of the divine principles
and proceeding to the qualitative and quantitative dynamics of the constellations of the
zodiac and seven planets, the meteorological dynamics of the earth's atmosphere, and the
constitution of the human body.

After the historical study of the text, Delp analyzes its metaphysical principles, that is,
the three divine causal principles (causa, ratio, natura). He compares entire passages with
the works of other authors (Bernardus Silvestris, Firmicus Maternus, Adelard of Bath, Latin
translations of Masha'allah, al-Qabisi, Saul ben ibn Bishr). The definition of the key words

All use subject to JSTOR Terms and Conditions

http://www.jstor.org/page/info/about/policies/terms.jsp

710 Reviews

(natura, mundus, tempus) of the treatise demonstrates the author's methodology: he begins
with the primary definition, breaks it down into its component parts, and gives an expli
cation of each part.

The purpose of chapter 2 is to conduct an analysis of the six principles of things, espe
cially the three universals, causa, ratio, and natura, and their relations and common opera
tions. The analysis is based on the internal evidence of their development within the Liber
itself. Delp's methodology is restricted to an analysis of the text, leaving aside all questions
of genre and of historical context. He pays attention especially to unclear and obscure
passages of the Liber and thereby allows the reader to follow each significant part of the
treatise. Delp demonstrates how various authors are echoed in the treatise (Macrobius's In
Somnium Scipionis, Bernardus Silvestris's Cosmographia, the anonymous Saeculi noni auc
toris in Boetii Consolationem philosopbiae commentarius, William of Conches's Glosae
super Platonem and Glosae super Boetium, Firmicus Maternus, Hugh of St. Victor).

Chapters 3-7-"Causa and Ratio," "Natura," "Mundus," "Machina mundi," and
"Tempus"-are devoted to analyses of the six key metaphysical terms of the treatise. The

metaphysical part of the treatise is focused on establishing a close reciprocity of causa,
ratio, and natura in their functions as the powers behind the form and motion of the
celestial bodies, which in turn transmit power to terrestrial phenomena. The Liber is un
derstood as an extreme example of the tendency of late-antique and twelfth-century cos
mology to extend the power and the presence of divine principles into the elemental work
ings of terrestrial phenomena.

In chapter 8, "Verbatim Sources," Delp analyzes the ways in which the pseudonymous
author assimilates verbatim quotations of the authorities by substituting his own phrases
for those of his sources. This part fundamentally complements materials that have been
overlooked and can be added to the few verbatim sources noticed by Silverstein. The anal
ysis of the sources reveals a good deal about the author's theoretical agenda, his methods
of composition, and his literary style.

The second part of the book consists of the edition prepared by Lucentini. In his intro
duction to the edition Lucentini deals with the work's direct tradition (the texts preserved
in four manuscripts, three from Oxford and one from Utrecht) and its indirect tradition
(three known excerpta), the genealogy of the tradition, the division of the text, the com

mentary in Silverstein's edition, and the editorial criteria.
The volume as a whole is formidably erudite, beautifully presented, and magisterial. For

those interested in twelfth-century cosmology and the history of Hermetism, this will be
an essential resource.

JOZEF MATULA, Palacky University

ULRICH HORST, O.P., The Dominicans and the Pope: Papal Teaching Authority in the
Medieval and Early Modern Thomist Tradition. Trans. James D. Mixson. Foreword by
Thomas Prugl. (The Conway Lectures in Medieval Studies, 2002.) Notre Dame, Ind.:
University of Notre Dame Press, 2006. Paper. Pp. xi, 132. $28.

As Vatican Council I (1869-70) reached its crescendo, the Dominican Cardinal Guidi
critiqued the draft title of the decree "On the Infallibility of the Roman Pontiff." Guidi
declared all bishops to be witnesses to doctrinal tradition, who shared teaching authority
with the pope, though none of them, pope included, was personally infallible. That night
Cardinal Guidi found himself called before an angry Pope Pius IX, who declared, "La
tradizione son' io." Pio Nono got his statement, although in the end it referred carefully
to the "infallible teaching authority of the Roman Pontiff" -certainly not a distinction

without a difference. Therein lies a tale reaching back to the church's earliest centuries, the

Before turning to his analysis of the content of the Liber, Delp suggests three criteria—
the attribution in the manuscript tradition to Hermes or some Hermetic appellation, the
content of the text, the nature of its reception by posterity—that help to establish the
Hermetic legitimacy of the text. The Liber is compared with other relevant medieval texts
in order to demonstrate its sources. Delp shows that the text is extremely complex and that
it defies categorization as to genre (cosmological, astrological, metaphysical, encyclopedic).

The Liber poses many difficulties (dating, influences, authorship), and Delp satisfactorily
unveils its textual and historical background. His study discloses the internal structure of
the text and makes clear the author's use of his authorities (Bernardus Silvestris, William
of Conches, Honorius Augustodunensis, Adelard of Bath). The content of the Liber has
affinities with the latter part of the Hermetic tradition in its concern with astrological
material of a wide variety of topics (the qualitative natures of the constellations and planets,
the astrological stages of the development of mankind between great world periods, etc.)
that are commonly recognized as belonging to technical Hermetica. The treatise proceeds
in a'hierarchical manner, beginning with the metaphysical nature of the divine principles
and proceeding to the qualitative and quantitative dynamics of the constellations of the
zodiac and seven planets, the meteorological dynamics of the earth's atmosphere, and the
constitution of the human body.

After the historical study of the text, Delp analyzes its metaphysical principles, that is,
the three divine causal principles (causa, ratio, natura). He compares entire passages with
the works of other authors (Bernardus Silvestris, Firmicus Maternus, Adelard of Bath, Latin
translations of Masha'allah, al-Qabisi, Saul ben ibn Bishr). The definition of the key words

710 Reviews

(natura, mundus, tetnpus) of the treatise demonstrates the author's methodology: he begins
with the primary definition, breaks it down into its component parts, and gives an expli-
cation of each part.

The purpose of chapter 2 is to conduct an analysis of the six principles of things, espe-
cially the three universals, causa, ratio, and natura, and their relations and common opera-
tions. The analysis is based on the internal evidence of their development within the Liber
itself. Delp's methodology is restricted to an analysis of the text, leaving aside all questions
of genre and of historical context. He pays attention especially to unclear and obscure
passages of the Liber and thereby allows the reader to follow each significant part of the
treatise. Delp demonstrates how various authors are echoed in the treatise (Macrobius's In
Somnium Scipionis, Bernardus Silvestris's Cosmograpbia, the anonymous Saeculi noni auc-
toris in Boetii Consolationem philosophiae commentarius, William of Conches's Glosae
super Platonem and Glosae super Boetium, Firmicus Maternus, Hugh of St. Victor).

Chapters 3-7—"Causa and Ratio," "Natura," "Mundus," "Machina mundi," and
"Tempus"—are devoted to analyses of the six key metaphysical terms of the treatise. The
metaphysical part of the treatise is focused on establishing a close reciprocity of causa,
ratio, and natura in their functions as the powers behind the form and motion of the
celestial bodies, which in turn transmit power to terrestrial phenomena. The Liber is un-
derstood as an extreme example of the tendency of late-antique and twelfth-century cos-
mology to extend the power and the presence of divine principles into the elemental work-
ings of terrestrial phenomena.

In chapter 8, "Verbatim Sources," Delp analyzes the ways in which the pseudonymous
author assimilates verbatim quotations of the authorities by substituting his own phrases
for those of his sources. This part fundamentally complements materials that have been
overlooked and can be added to the few verbatim sources noticed by Silverstein. The anal-
ysis of the sources reveals a good deal about the author's theoretical agenda, his methods
of composition, and his literary style.

The second part of the book consists of the edition prepared by Lucentini. In his intro-
duction to the edition Lucentini deals with the work's direct tradition (the texts preserved
in four manuscripts, three from Oxford and one from Utrecht) and its indirect tradition
(three known excerpta), the genealogy of the tradition, the division of the text, the com-
mentary in Silverstein's edition, and the editorial criteria.

The volume as a whole is formidably erudite, beautifully presented, and magisterial. For
those interested in twelfth-century cosmology and the history of Hermetism, this will be
an essential resource.

JOZEF MATULA, PaJacJcy University

ULRICH HORST, O.P., The Dominicans and the Pope: Papal Teaching Authority in the
Medieval and Early Modern Thomist Tradition. Trans. James D. Mixson. Foreword by
Thomas Priigl. (The Conway Lectures in Medieval Studies, 2002.) Notre Dame, Ind.:
University of Notre Dame Press, 2006. Paper. Pp. xi, 132. $28.

As Vatican Council I (1869-70) reached its crescendo, the Dominican Cardinal Guidi
critiqued the draft title of the decree "On the Infallibility of the Roman Pontiff." Guidi
declared all bishops to be witnesses to doctrinal tradition, who shared teaching authority
with the pope, though none of them, pope included, was personally infallible. That night
Cardinal Guidi found himself called before an angry Pope Pius IX, who declared, "La
tradizione son' io." Pio Nono got his statement, although in the end it referred carefully
to the "infallible teaching authority of the Roman Pontiff"—certainly not a distinction
without a difference. Therein lies a tale reaching back to the church's earliest centuries, the

Assistant

Here’s the short, sharp synthesis you asked for—first what “Hermeticism” finally means to Pico (and how that sits inside the medieval Christian Hermetic stream), then how De ente et uno makes his philosophical quarrel with Ficino explicit.

1) What “Hermeticism” ultimately means to Pico

  • Not a rival revelation, but a test-bench. For Pico, “Hermes” is part of the prisca theologia archive: a quarry of axioms about God, mind, soul, nature, and providence that he tests dialectically against Scripture, patristics, and scholastic metaphysics. He quotes Hermetic dicta as probative authorities, not as a personal creed—exactly the “post-Yates” view of Pico’s method. fileciteturn49file7L28-L43


  • Cosmo-psychology over “operative” magic. In his Hermetic theses, the load-bearing claims are metaphysical and psychological (e.g., mind → soul → life; incorporeal mover; providence everywhere). The conspicuous absence of talismanic/astrological recipes in that set supports the reading that Pico wants Hermes for first principles, not for techniques. fileciteturn49file14L42-L48


  • Christian filtration of prisca dicta. When a Hermetic maxim passes his test, Pico “baptizes” it—folding it into Christian providence, creation, and Logos-theology (e.g., verbum in mente … horum pater Deus). This is precisely what recent scholars mean by Pico’s humanist theology: philology and comparative erudition are instruments to ratify, not replace, Christian doctrine. fileciteturn49file14L18-L24


2) How this relates to the medieval Christian Hermetic synthesis

  • The twelfth-century Latin Hermetic Liber de sex rerum principiis (edited by Lucentini & Delp) shows what “Christian Hermetism” looked like before Pico: a hierarchical cosmology that begins from divine principles and runs down through celestial motions to meteorology and the human body, with an insistent causal triad (causa, ratio, natura) powering the “machine of the world.” That is Hermetic metaphysics already domesticated into scholasticized natural philosophy. fileciteturn6file0 fileciteturn6file1


  • Delp’s analysis (summarized in the Speculum review) highlights that very program: causa/ratio/natura operate reciprocally as “powers behind the form and motion of the celestial bodies, which in turn transmit power to terrestrial phenomena.” In other words, a Hermetic frame interlocks with Latin Christian cosmology well before Ficino and Pico. Pico inherits—and then tightens—that synthesis. fileciteturn6file1


Up-shot: “Hermeticism,” for Pico, is a venerable, already-Christianized vocabulary for talking about causes, intellect, and providence; he subjects it to scholastic distinctions and keeps what coheres with Catholic doctrine.

3) How De ente et uno lays bare Pico’s “beef” with Ficino (Neoplatonic ontology & metaphysics)

Ficino’s tilt (as Pico sees it): Ficino tends to absolutize the One-beyond-being (a hyper-apophatic Parmenidean reading that leans on Proclus/Dionysius), making predication about God precarious and encouraging a one-way emanationist grammar of reality.

Pico’s reply in De ente et uno (the neo-Aristotelian correction):

1) Two senses of “One/Being,” one God. Pico accepts the Dionysian “One above being”—but immediately places it inside an Aristotelian-Thomist semantics where ens and unum are convertible transcendentals. So God is “beyond the categories” (no genus), yet truly predicated as One/Good/Being. This preserves apophasis and cataphasis, instead of letting “beyond being” silence metaphysics. (See the Being and One selection printed with Heptaplus.) fileciteturn49file11L55-L63

2) Aristotle + Aquinas can say the Dionysian thing—safely. Pico’s strategy is to show that Aristotle, read through Aquinas, already entails that God is not a member of “being” as a category while allowing true names of God. That is the technical backbone of his reconciliation and the exact move Howlett identifies as Pico’s neo-Aristotelian harmonization against Ficino’s over-Platonizing. fileciteturn49file2L44-L56

3) From emanation to causality with predication. Where Ficino’s ontology risks a one-way emanative picture (with “One” eclipsing “Being”), Pico insists on causal intelligibility and semantic precision: intelligences, soul, and nature are ordered by causes we can name without collapsing God into a genus. The effect is to re-center metaphysics (substance/accident; act/potency; transcendental convertibility) and de-center unqualified negative theology.

4) Methodological contrast. Ficino: Platonic mythos and sapiential oratory; Pico: disputation-grade distinctions that make Plato and Aristotle cohere under theological guardrails. That’s why modern scholars file De ente squarely under Pico’s humanist theology rather than Ficinian sapiential Platonism. fileciteturn49file2L44-L56

So the “beef,” in one line: Pico thinks Ficino’s ontology overweights the (apophatic) One and underweights the (predicable) Being—risking an emanationism that weakens theology’s capacity to speak truly. De ente et uno re-balances the scale with an Aquinas-friendly semantics in which One and Being meet without confusion or separation.

If you want a next step


I can diagram a one-pager that puts Ficino’s One-first ladder and Pico’s convertibility-first ladder side-by-side (with 3–4 representative loci from the Being and One text and Howlett’s commentary), so you can drop it straight into your chapter.

Implications & significance


  • The trial context shows Pico’s intellectual risk-taking: the condemnation forced him to frame his philosophy not only in terms of synthesis and concord, but also in defense of orthodoxy.

  • It helps modern readers see that Pico’s “humanist” credentials are more complicated: he operates within scholastic channels of authority and disputation, not simply as a free-wheeling Renaissance individualist.

  • It refocuses our view: rather than simple celebration of Pico’s Oration, the trial shows the live stakes of his work — dogmatic, metaphysical, spiritual.

  • For your work (on his theology, Kabbalah, metaphysics): the trial underscores how theological precision mattered intimately to him (e.g., in Eucharist, will, free assent) and therefore shapes how we read texts like Heptaplus, De ente et uno, and his Hermetic conclusions.

Copenhaver re-reads the Oratio on the Dignity of Man and the 900 Theses in light of the trial:

Assistant

Exactly — that’s one of the central, revisionist contributions of Copenhaver’s 2022 book Pico della Mirandola on Trial: Heresy, Freedom, and Philosophy. Let me unpack what his re-reading of the Oratio and 900 Theses looks like and how it transforms the old narrative.

1. The “Oration” and “Theses” belong to the same theological project — not two genres

Copenhaver’s key claim is that the “Oration on the Dignity of Man” (the Oratio de hominis dignitate) was never meant as an independent “humanist manifesto.”
It was the prologue to a scholastic disputation — the 900 Conclusiones — and thus part of a theological event, not a rhetorical celebration of man’s secular freedom.

He emphasizes:

  • Pico called it an oratio pro disputatione habenda, a formal pre-speech for his projected 1487 debate in Rome.

  • The 900 Theses are “the real body” of that event; the Oratio is the prefatory rhetoric designed to authorize it in theological terms.

  • Therefore, you cannot interpret the Oratio apart from the doctrinal logic and scholastic method of the Conclusiones.


This overturns what Copenhaver calls the “humanist-manifesto myth” — the post-19th-century view that the Oration inaugurated Renaissance individualism or secular human dignity.
For him, the text is instead an apologia for theology itself as the summit of human vocation.

2. The trial shows what the “dignity of man” actually meant: responsibility, not self-creation

By reading the Oratio through the 1487 papal proceedings, Copenhaver redefines “dignity” as a scholastic virtue of free assent under grace, not modern autonomy.
When the papal commission condemned 13 of the 900 Theses, Pico’s defense (Apologia) argued that belief and error depend on the will’s freedom — a freedom that carries accountability before God.

So:

  • “Dignity” = man’s capacity to freely will assent to truth and thus incur merit or guilt.

  • The “trial of heresy” reveals how this freedom was already a juridical-theological problem, not a humanist abstraction.

  • Pico’s insistence that heresy must be “willful” (haeresis est voluntaria) connects the Oratio’s rhetoric of freedom to a precise scholastic notion of voluntary assent and culpability.


Copenhaver calls this the “Pico problem of freedom”: human dignity lies not in self-determination against God, but in moral self-binding to truth.

3. The 900 Theses as scholastic microcosm of “universal theology”

Copenhaver rereads the Conclusiones as a map of the entire theological universe, arranged for formal disputation:

  • They are not mystic “syncretism” in the Yatesian sense but scholastic propositions in logic, metaphysics, ethics, theology, magic, and Kabbalah.

  • Each set of theses cites named authorities (secundum Averroem, secundum Cabalistam, etc.) and is built for defense or refutation — the standard university exercise.

  • The condemned Theses (especially those on the Trinity, Incarnation, and will) show that Pico’s project pressed scholastic limits, but still operated within their structure.


So, the Oratio praises man because man is the creature capable of theology — of integrating all disciplines into knowledge of God.
That is the “dignity” the 900 Theses perform in microcosm.

4. The trial as interpretive key

For Copenhaver, the 1487 papal trial is the interpretive fulcrum:

  • It proves Pico was not persecuted for novelty alone, but because his scholastic precision cut across entrenched theological boundaries.

  • The proceedings document how his intellectual program was inseparable from the machinery of heresy law — thus the meaning of his philosophy emerges through that juridical framework.

  • It forces a rereading of every text (the Oratio, the Apologia, De ente et uno, Heptaplus) as works of orthodox engagement, not rebellion.


Hence his book’s subtitle — Heresy, Freedom, and Philosophy: these are not three topics but one complex phenomenon.

5. Implications for scholarship

Older View (Yates, Cassirer, Garin)Copenhaver’s Revision
The Oratio = Renaissance “humanist manifesto” exalting man’s self-fashioning.The Oratio = pre-disputation preface to a scholastic theological project.
The 900 Theses = occult syncretism, pre-scientific universalism.The 900 Theses = scholastic propositions; the condemned 13 reveal Pico’s precision within Christian dogma.
Pico as first “modern” mind condemned by medievalism.Pico as late-medieval theologian whose case shows the inner tensions of orthodoxy.
“Dignity of man” = human autonomy.“Dignity” = freedom of voluntary assent under grace — a legal-theological concept of responsible freedom.

In short


Copenhaver’s rereading turns the Oratio and the 900 Theses into exhibits in a trial of theology itself.
For Pico, man’s dignity is the dignity of the theologian, capable of uniting knowledge into praise of God — and the Roman trial shows how precarious that claim was inside late-Quattrocento orthodoxy.

what's happening in these platonist conclusions to illustrate copenhaver howlett edelheit takes

Assistant

Excellent — this is the right question to connect Copenhaver, Howlett, and Edelheit’s readings with the Platonic section of Pico’s Conclusiones (especially Book I, groups 11–26, “secundum Platonicos” and “secundum Pythagoram”). These are the heart of what Copenhaver calls Pico’s “philosophical theology in disputation form.” Let’s unpack what’s happening in these Conclusiones Platonicae—what they say, and how the three modern interpreters make sense of them.

1. The Setting: “Platonist” Theses as Pico’s Theological Laboratory

These propositions form a bridge between his Aristotelian, Pythagorean, and Hermetic series. They show Pico attempting to articulate a single, hierarchically ordered metaphysics that could house Christian revelation.
The standard example (I.18–I.26 series) runs from propositions about the One, Intellect, and Soul down to statements on beauty, eros, and the divine mind’s self-knowledge.

Rather than presenting a “neo-pagan theology,” the conclusions enact the unification program Copenhaver calls philosophy-as-trial-of-theology: a disputation across traditions meant to test where philosophy touches revelation and where it fails.

2. Copenhaver’s Take — Pico as Scholastic Metaphysician on Trial

Copenhaver insists the Platonic theses are not mystical assertions but disputable scholastic sentences on metaphysical order:

Example:

“The One is beyond being; every intellect participates in the One according to the mode of its simplicity.”

Copenhaver shows this is framed as a quaestio about participation, not an esoteric dogma. Pico is defending an Aristotelianized Dionysius: God “beyond being,” yet intelligible through participation.

He reads these lines in light of the trial—the propositions on “being and one” anticipate what will later become De ente et uno. Pico’s language, when it verges on “emanation,” is precisely what the inquisitors feared could edge toward heresy; yet, as Copenhaver notes, Pico’s Apologia treats such claims as technical distinctions about the transcendentals, not occult metaphysics.

Thus, the “Platonist” conclusions display the very risky orthodoxy that landed him under investigation: pushing scholastic precision to its limits inside theological supervision.

3. Howlett’s Take — The Neo-Aristotelian Reconciliation

In Re-Evaluating Pico, Sophia Howlett reads these Platonic conclusions through the lens of De ente et uno’s harmonization of Aristotle and Plato.

She highlights that in theses such as:

  • “All things desire to be united with the One.”

  • “Being and the One are convertible transcendentals.”


Pico is already correcting Ficino’s Plotinian bias. Instead of Ficino’s hierarchical flight from being to a supra-ontological One, Pico’s Platonism remains within metaphysical intelligibility—an Aristotelian Platonism.

Where Ficino’s Platonic Theology divides Being from the One (God as beyond intelligibility), Pico’s conclusions collapse that gap through Thomist convertibility.

Hence, the “Platonic” conclusions illustrate Howlett’s core thesis: Pico’s neo-Aristotelian reading of Platonism—a logic of reconciliation, not transcendental escape.

4. Edelheit’s Take — Humanist Theology in Practice

Amos Edelheit’s Ficino, Pico and Savonarola places these same theses within a new genre he calls humanist theology: learned, philological engagement with doctrine through patristic and philosophical authorities.

For him, Pico’s Platonic propositions show the method of the theologian-humanist:

  • He quotes the prisci theologi (Plato, Pythagoras, Dionysius) as authoritative witnesses, not autonomous prophets.

  • He employs the logic of scholastic disputation—each proposition framed secundum Platonem, as if to say “let us see whether this agrees with truth.”

  • The aim is to reform theology through breadth of erudition, not to replace it.


Thus, the Platonic set performs Edelheit’s “humanist synthesis”—fusing philology, philosophy, and theology under the discipline of the Church.

5. What’s Happening Inside the Text Itself

A few recurring structures show this synthesis in motion:

Pico’s FormulaWhat It DoesModern Interpretation
“Omnis pulchritudo est participatio boni.”Beauty participates in the Good.Pico inserts the Platonic triad (Good–Beautiful–Being) into scholastic transcendental theory (Copenhaver).
“Mens divina seipsam intelligendo omnia intelligit.”God knows all by self-knowledge.Thomist scientia Dei reframed in Platonic idiom (Edelheit).
“Amor est vinculum mundi.”Love is the world’s bond.A Christianized Eros as providential order (Howlett: reconciliation of efficient/final cause).
“Anima mundi in rebus inferioribus quasi vita diffusa.”The world-soul is diffused life.Read figuratively: the order of forms as divine providence, not pantheism. Copenhaver cites this as example of orthodoxy misunderstood at trial.

These statements illustrate the shared modern thesis: Pico uses Platonic vocabulary to articulate Aristotelian-Thomist theology—a universal grammar of being and goodness governed by divine providence.

6. Synthesis — Why These Theses Matter for All Three Scholars

FocusWhat They See in the Platonic Theses
Copenhaver (2022)A scholastic trial of philosophy itself: propositions testing the border of orthodoxy; evidence that Pico’s “Platonism” was a legal-theological issue, not a mystical flight.
Howlett (2021)A systematic attempt to translate Platonism into Aristotelian semantics—thus the core of Pico’s metaphysical program and his disagreement with Ficino.
Edelheit (2008)The most mature example of humanist theology: philological Platonism subordinated to faith, demonstrating the Renaissance theologian’s method.

7. The Broader Picture

The “Platonist Conclusions” are, in effect, the laboratory for Pico’s later works:

  • De ente et uno grows directly out of their distinctions on One and Being.

  • The Heptaplus develops their idea that creation is intelligible order, not emanation.

  • The Disputationes adversus astrologiam extends their rejection of fatal necessity implicit in the Platonist hierarchy.


In one sentence


The Conclusiones Platonicae show Pico re-forging Platonism into a disciplined scholastic theology:
Copenhaver sees a trial of orthodoxy; Howlett sees an Aristotelian reconciliation; Edelheit sees the birth of humanist theology—
and all three converge on the same insight: Pico’s “Platonism” is not the philosophy of flight from the world, but the theology of intelligible participation within it.

【1†(Variorum Collected Studies 1063) Allen, MichaelJ. B - Studies in the Platonism of Marsilio Ficino and Giovanni Pico-Routledge (2017).pdf†file_00000000fcd861f5a5ba052b21a2d693】


Content source: Source.file
Title: (Variorum Collected Studies 1063) Allen, MichaelJ. B - Studies in the Platonism of Marsilio Ficino and Giovanni Pico-Routledge (2017).pdf
Content Snippet:
1. Pico della
2. Mirandola’s exordium makes mankind—or at least the prelapsarian Adam—free to
3. choose a place on the cosmic ladder and thus to move up or down from the middle rung
4. traditionally assigned to humanity. Ficino had called man the “knot and the bond of the
5. world.” Pico della Mirandola does not disagree, but he imagines that God created
6. Adam of “indeterminate essence,” thus endowing him with the duty to elect from among
7. the manifold determinations of all that had been created before him: to be himself the
8. artificer of God’s final artifact, to be whatsoever he chose, to elect to ascend or to
9. descend. This suggests not so much the Pythagorean-Platonic notion that humanity is the
10. microcosm, the mean, the measure of all things as it does the questing Socratic
11. intelligence, the far-ranging mind whose predicament and whose destiny is ethical
12. rather than metaphysical. Pico della Mirandola rarely mentions Socrates, but his
13. position recalls Socrates the defender at his own trial rather than the Neoplatonic magus
14. attending to the planetary demons. Pico della Mirandola’s youthful optimistic
15. anthropology is starkly at odds with the jeremiads of Savonarola, to whose influence he
16. later succumbed, though their weighing of human misery over human dignity has been
17. the subject of debate among Christians for centuries.
18.
19.
20.
21. In the genre of technical philosophy as distinct from the philosophical manifesto, Pico
22. della Mirandola’s highest achievements were two short works, both of them coherent
23. and relatively straightforward statements, unlike the rhetorical exhortations of the
24. Oration or the spacious but rambling and esoteric program of the nine hundred
25. Conclusions. On Being and the One is a brief position paper examining whether the
26. One is prior to being, as the Neoplatonists had taught, or coincident with it, as Aristotle
27. had argued. Pico della Mirandola takes the Aristotelian side, utilizing a number of
28. subtle distinctions from Aquinas concerning essence and existence and presenting a
29. basically Thomist position. In the process, he dismissed the Parmenides as a dialectical
30. game and the Sophist with it, thereby rejecting two texts especially revered by Proclus
31. and Ficino, who was annoyed at what he called the count’s “temerity” in dismissing
32. their ontology. In the Heptaplus, however, Pico della Mirandola moved from
33. metaphysics to theology, offering an intricate analysis of the Mosaic story of the six
34. days of creation in the tradition of medieval hexaemeral literature. But he explains many
35. biblical terms and images by way of Neoplatonic metaphysics, again showing his wide
36. learning and remarkable powers of synthesis. The Heptaplus also nods briefly and
37. perhaps rashly in the direction of the Kabbalah while emphasizing some central
38. Christological themes.
39.
40. Pico della Mirandola was a dazzling, courageous thinker equipped with precocious
41. learning and a prehensile memory, an eclectic polemicist who roamed across whole
42. continents of philosophy and theology. The new Platonism was just part of his
43. intellectual world, which included the Aristotelian and Peripatetic canons, kabbalist
44. speculations that he first turned to Christian use, a wide range of Scholastics whom
45. Ficino seldom mentions, and the pre-Platonic sages whom Ficino also honored—all this
46. in the space of a decade that ended with Pico della Mirandola’s entry into the circle of
47. Savonarola’s ascetic devotees.

Content Snippet:
1. Pico’s use of Proclus (c412–485 CE) suggests a love for the baroque
2. and the marriage of philosophy and theology. The pagan Proclus led
3. the Platonic Academy at a time when Christianity was becoming the
4. norm. He continued a process within late Platonism to bring together
5. faith and reason: combining various surviving pagan traditions with
6. Greek philosophy (aspects of Platonism had already been combined with
7. Aristotelianism) into an increasingly elaborate and arcane theological
8. philosophy. Plotinus’ emphasis on the One, easily equitable with God,
9. allowed Neoplatonism to develop into such a structure. Platonism became
10. that most sacred of philosophies. It is unsurprising then that Proclus’
11. summa or key work was the Platonic Theology, from which Ficino took
12. the title for his own summa. But Proclus was not just a philosopher
13. with a predilection for theology. He was also vatic in his inclinations
14. and enhanced a growing ceremonial (theurgical) strand within Neopla-
15. tonism. Proclus took Neoplatonism to its final stage within the Academy
16. form: a theological philosophy assimilated with Gnosticism, among other
17. traditions, baroque in its complexity with layers and layers of beings and
18. substructures to the Platonic emanations, and with a ‘practicing’ arm.87
19.
20. Both Pico and Ficino use Proclus, but Pico favors Proclus and a Plotinian
21. ‘mysticism’ above all other forms of Platonism.
22.
23. Both Ficino and Pico also valued Timaeus and Phaedrus. Pico
24. worked with Timaeus throughout his writing career in Conclusions,
25. Heptaplus and Disputations. Only Phaedrus provided more material for
26. the Conclusions.88 Phaedrus’ vision of Socrates on the Banks of Ilissus
27. gave Ficino his own vision of the original Platonic Academy and is central
28. to his work. Timaeus not only contains the important conversation on the
29. existence of a demiurge (or creator who may be separate from God), but
30. also underlines Pico and Ficino’s interest in math, particularly the sacred
31. mathematics of Pythagoras.
32.
33.
34.
35. 3 PICO’S INTELLECTUAL FOUNDATIONS … 71
36.
37. In his use of Platonic sources, Pico is not an Aristotelian; nor is he
38. rejecting Plato in his attempt at concordance: he is trying to place the two
39. philosophers on equal ground, even if sometimes he veers more toward
40. one than the other. This was a very difficult task in the fifteenth century as
41. the two philosophers had become entwined in multiple traditions, and an
42. equally difficult task to review from today. Finding the way back to points
43. of origin and separation to then attempt concordance is all but impossible.
44. But when judging Pico’s use of sources, to indicate a preference for Plato
45. or Aristotle for example, we can consider two issues: what was truly (as far
46. as we can discern today) from a predominantly Aristotelian as opposed to
47. a Platonic source and most importantly what Pico thought was Aristotelian
48. or Platonic. From the latter perspective, Pico uses what he knows to be
49. Aristotelian argumentation in On Being and the One, his Commentary
50. and indeed throughout his career. But the universe he describes, using
51. Aristotle, is predominantly Platonic.

1. 4 Pico announces this theme in the Oration and in the first of the 900 theses according
2. to his own opinion: “There is no natural or divine question in which Aristotle and Plato
3. do not agree in meaning and substance, although in their words they seem to disagree”
4. (1>1) (Conclusions, 365). For a sustained argument against any single framework of
5. interpretation for Pico, see William G. Craven, Giovanni Pico della Mirandola: Symbol of His
6. Age: Modern Interpretations of a Renaissance Philosopher (Geneva: Libraire Droz, 1981).
7.
8. 5 Dulles, Princeps Concordiae, 131. Unlike the highly polished rhetorical character of the
9. Oration, Pico employs the language and style of scholasticism in the 900 theses set out in his
10. Conclusions (1486). Prefaced by the Oration, the Conclusions is divided into approximately
11. 400 historical theses drawn from major philosophers of the Latin, Arabic, Peripatetic,
12. and Platonic “nations” in addition to the “most ancient” nations (Pythagorean, Chaldean,
13. Hermetic, and Cabalistic), followed by almost 500 theses according to his own opinion.
14. S. A. Farmer provides charts outlining all the theses in Syncretism in the West (204–7). It is
15. tempting, but dubious, to take all of the historical theses to represent Pico’s own view. On
16. interpreting the historical theses, Farmer asserts that “[t]o reconstruct Pico’s views in this
17. part of the text, all topically related theses must be collated with the last 500 theses, given
18. ‘according to his own opinion’” (204). Many scholars, including Dulles and Cassirer, rely
19. inappropriately on historical theses alone to furnish Pico’s own opinions.

26. Pico’s Quest for All Knowledge 181
27.
28. following terms: if the human being is a creature capable of actualizing
29. every archetype within its being, does it follow for Pico that human beings
30. are capable of attaining every kind of knowledge? If Pico is approached
31. from the vantage point of his medieval predecessors, one might hold
32. with the scholastics that there are intrinsic limits on human knowledge
33. rooted in human nature itself, particularly the dependence of all intellec-
34. tual cognition on sensory perception. As Aristotle said, with far-reaching
35. effects, “the soul never thinks without an image.”6 For Aquinas, this had
36. meant that there could be no direct cognition or “vision” of God or any
37. spiritual being by a human knower while still in this life, which is to say by
38. virtue of natural human powers.7 Consequently, all realities whose level
39. of being exceed that of the human being have to be translated into the
40. mode of human knowing. Human beings, then, unable ever to become
41. purely spiritual intelligences, can only approximate the angelic mode of
42. knowing in rare moments of immediate intellectual intuition, as when
43. grasping first principles or intuiting the essence of a perceived object.
44. Yet if Pico’s human being is the creature that has no fixed nature, one
45. might expect that Pico stands the scholastic paradigm on its head: where
46. there is no determinate nature, there can be no natural limits.

36. Pico’s Universe
37.
38. The structure of Pico’s universe is primarily Christian Platonic but
39. with attempted concordance at critical points with Aristotelianism and
40. Kabbalism. Ficino’s universe therefore provides a useful starting point
41. from which to begin an analysis. Differences from Ficino are where we
42. can see Pico’s unique contribution which in part relies on his strong pref-
43. erence for Proclus within Platonism, but primarily derives from his project
44. of concordance. Concordance is important throughout his cosmology.
45. But certain themes are consistently emphasized, such as creation (begin-
46. nings), ascent (endings), and the place of being. Consequently, two
47. specific problems with concordance emerge: what is (or is not) God in
48. his cosmology (as beginning and end); and what is the role of Hokmah
49. or divine wisdom in these beginnings and endings. For in Pico’s concor-
50. dance, Hokmah is also the Aristotelian active intellect and Christ (another
51. potential end and the Ficinian home of ‘being’).
52.
53. Pico’s God emerges as single but somehow twofold: a God of
54. apophatic or negative theology, and an active, creator from which emana-
55. tion/creation occurs who can be at least partially described. Further,
56. through these specific issues, the central problem with his project of
57. concordance becomes very apparent. All three of his pillars share many
58. similarities, interconnected as they are through shared histories. But
59. bringing what is similar together brings what is different too. The result
60. in each specific case is hard to define or demarcate, tempting us to choose

1. Pico is trying to bring together philosophy and theology, reason and
2. faith, not just as two approaches to thinking about metaphysics, but
3. also as two stages of the route to personal fulfillment. We need philos-
4. ophy, which takes us to theology and then to religious faith, to echo
5. Pseudo-Dionysius.112 Pico is taking us back to the very same issues that
6.

13. gious truth. It can be easy to forget that above all Pico is a Christian and
14. his syncretism centers around Christianity: reverifying the truths of Chris-
15. tianity, and linking Christian truth to disparate philosophical schools,
16. different times and places. Plato and Aristotle, with all their descendants,
17. are being brought together for the greater good of Christianity, and
18. Christian truths always come first.113

20. Indeed, Pico’s structure consistently hierarchizes the process of concor-
21. dance: resolution can lean toward one argument over another.114 This
22. is perhaps why the conversation between Pico’s Aristotelianism and
23. Platonism is so complicated: sometimes he appears to favor Aris-
24. totelianism, and at other times gives a more Platonic answer. It depends
25. what works to form that overall deep structure that can contain and
26. express the religious mystery of an ‘expressed’ God (understanding the
27. universe as the expression of the divine). We are sifting through each
28. philosopher so that we end up not with who is right, but rather who
29. writes the truth, and who will help us home.
30.
31. The hierarchical approach is also applied to time. Pico, and Ficino,
32. believed that the earlier the knowledge, the more primary or ‘truer’ it
33. is likely to be (when considering God, it is easy to conflate human-
34. istic love of ‘the original’ with ‘the original’ as the truth). This implies
35. that we began with truth and fell away from it, as time passed and
36. truth became segmented and separated from the wellspring and history
37. moved onward. The underlying deep structure, which looks to be a
38. synchronic phenomenon, only becomes apparent through a movement
39. back in time. Seen in reverse: the history of knowledge becomes a decline
40. from a point of origin.115 Every element in the Conclusions can contain
41. part of the truth, but it needs to be brought together (by going back-
42. ward and inward at the same time) to create the grand narrative of a
43. new theological philosophy, based on the unveiling of this deep struc-
44. ture, that would reunite reason and faith, and revivify Christianity.116

48. thought together, binding, dispelling, finding the ‘truth,’ and moving
49. further back, until we reach Aristotle and Plato.117

1. Pico della Mirandola takes the Aristotelian side, utilizing a number of
2. subtle distinctions from Aquinas concerning essence and existence and presenting a
3. basically Thomist position. In the process, he dismissed the Parmenides as a dialectical
4. game and the Sophist with it, thereby rejecting two texts especially revered by Proclus
5. and Ficino, who was annoyed at what he called the count’s “temerity” in dismissing
6. their ontology. In the Heptaplus, however, Pico della Mirandola moved from
7. metaphysics to theology, offering an intricate analysis of the Mosaic story of the six
8. days of creation in the tradition of medieval hexaemeral literature. But he explains many
9. biblical terms and images by way of Neoplatonic metaphysics, again showing his wide
10. learning and remarkable powers of synthesis. The Heptaplus also nods briefly and
11. perhaps rashly in the direction of the Kabbalah while emphasizing some central
12. Christological themes.
13.
14. Pico della Mirandola was a dazzling, courageous thinker equipped with precocious
15. learning and a prehensile memory, an eclectic polemicist who roamed across whole
16. continents of philosophy and theology. The new Platonism was just part of his
17. intellectual world, which included the Aristotelian and Peripatetic canons, kabbalist
18. speculations that he first turned to Christian use, a wide range of Scholastics whom
19. Ficino seldom mentions, and the pre-Platonic sages whom Ficino also honored—all this
20. in the space of a decade that ended with Pico della Mirandola’s entry into the circle of
21. Savonarola’s ascetic devotees. Despite the considerable differences between them,
22. Pico della Mirandola probably would have relished being known as Ficino’s brother
23. Platonist or conplatonicus. Both were philosopher-sages, and both lived in the
24. conviction that a soul could rise by contemplation back toward the intelligible divine
25. and freely elect or refuse the demonic life of the mind. However, Pico della
26. Mirandola’s preoccupation with the theme of freedom speaks to an anthropology more
27. narrow and yet more liberated than Ficino’s, one less bound to the ancient and medieval
28. world of magical sympathies, less constrained by the intricate dance of the star gods
29. and their demon attendants circling forever above us and within us. Pico della
30. Mirandola’s personal story hastens forward like a tragedy that Christopher Marlowe or
31. William Shakespeare might have written, while Ficino’s longer, more tranquil life came
32. to abide in the maturity and deliberation of his judgments, his visionary completeness,
33. his serene musicality.
34.
35. Other thinkers were variously indebted to the Renaissance Platonists, though much
36. more to Ficino than to Pico della Mirandola or Nicholas of Cusa. Some such as
37. Francesco da Diacceto (1466–1522), Ficino’s successor in Florence, or the Spaniard
38.
39.
40.
41. Sebastian Fox Morcillo (1526/1528–1560) followed Ficino rather faithfully, while
42. others such as the imaginative Francesco Giorgi (1460/1466–1540) or the adventurous
43. Francesco Patrizi built braver speculations on ground that Ficino had already prepared.
44. The Vatican librarian, Agostino Steuco (1497/1498–1548), founded a universal scheme
45. of concordist cultural history on the irenic attitude to non-Christian beliefs encouraged
46. by Ficino and Pico della Mirandola. Leone Ebreo (ca.

1. He planned to stage
2. this medieval spectacle—a scene familiar to the Parisian doctors with whom he had
3. briefly studied—in the heart of Renaissance Rome. A curial commission asked him to
4. reconsider just thirteen of the nine hundred propositions since they dealt with the real
5. presence in the Mass, the nature of Christ’s bodily form after resurrection, and other
6. delicate issues of Christian dogma. The hotheaded young count’s refusal provoked the
7. condemnation of his entire enterprise. Further defiance forced him to flee to Paris and
8. caused his brief imprisonment.
9.
10. When he returned to Florence at the instigation of the Medici and of friends such as
11. Ficino, he presented his own version of Neoplatonic metaphysics in a commentary on a
12. friend’s Italian love lyric, using the occasion to attack Ficino’s understanding of the
13. Symposium. His flashes of Platonic insight are on a par with Ficino’s and deeply
14. indebted to them, but he presented them in a haphazard series of glosses. Here and
15. elsewhere, Pico della Mirandola writes like one in haste, a brilliant and animated
16. lecturer who knows his subject better than himself and who speaks without notes and
17. without restraint. Some of his disagreements with Ficino are curtly phrased, in the
18.
19.
20.
21. manner of an aristocrat trained by French Scholastics to score in argument. At the very
22. end of his meteoric career, he was still battling authority, whether it was the wisdom
23. newly established by Ficino’s Platonism or the doctrines long proclaimed by the
24. astrologers whom he refuted in a huge, unfinished work of amazing erudition. His scom
25. for much of what passed as astrological prediction—unlike Ficino, who had been
26. reluctant to reject all astrology—was not in itself Platonic or Aristotelian; its main
27. philosophical ancestry was the scepticism that was on the verge of being revived (by
28. Pico della Mirandola’s nephew Gianfrancesco) when Pico della Mirandola died,
29. Plotinus had declared in Enncad 2.3 that the stars are signs, “letters perpetually being
30. inscribed on the heavens,” but not causes of earthly events, yet he wrote movingly of the
31. cosmic dance of sympathy that binds us to the stars, the “enchaining” of all things. And
32. even before Ficino produced his Latin Plotinus, the Timaeus had that the heavens obey
33. and transmit the primal ratios that govern the lives of humans, of their institutions, of
34. nations, and of nature itself. In the context of the Platonic tradition, Pico della
35. Mirandola championed a Socratic rather than a Neoplatonic view of human
36. independence, a Socratic autarchy at odds with the Timaean subordination of humankind
37. within a cosmic hierarchy beneath the star-gods and the spiritual beings who serve
38. them, those starry demons who, as the Statesman had declared, watch over us as
39. shepherds.
40.
41. The moral and practical meaning of human nature is Pico della Mirandola’s theme in
42. the opening pages of his most renowned work—indeed, the most renowned work, since
43. Jacob Burckhardt, Walter Pater, and Ernst Cassirer singled it out, of Renaissance
44. philosophy—the Oration, written (but never delivered) to introduce his nine hundred
45. Conclusions and in some later versions subtitled On the Dignity of Man.

1. The opposite is true of another brilliant Renaissance philosopher profoundly
2. influenced by Platonism but deeply engaged in the life and culture of his
3. contemporaries, Giovanni Pico della Mirandola (1463–1494), an aristocrat, a publicity
4. seeker, a comet who flamed across the Italian firmament for a brief decade before
5. succumbing to Girolamo Savonarola’s renunciatory spell and dying a premature death,
6. possibly murdered by a disgruntled retainer. Like Milton after him, Pico della
7. Mirandola set out to dominate the cultural terrain of his time, immersing himself even
8. more in Aristotle than in Plato. He knew a number of Scholastic texts more intimately
9. than Ficino did and felt intellectually closer to the schools, so much so that we can think
10. of him as a late Scholastic, rather than a Platonist. Ficino described him revealingly as
11. an eminent Aristotelian in the preface to the Plotinus translation that Pico della
12. Mirandola urged him to complete.
13.
14. But Pico della Mirandola also ransacked the pre-Platonic sages, the Orphic hymns,
15. the Pythagorean dicta, the “Chaldaean” oracles, and the Hermetic Pimander, at the
16. same time preparing himself to study the Kabbalah in the Hebrew and Aramaic
17. originals, armed with translations by a converted rabbi who taught him Hebrew and
18. salted the kabbalist texts with the trinitarian clues that he knew his student wanted to
19. find. Without becoming an independent expert in this new arena, Pico della Mirandola
20. mastered enough of it to cull the propositions needed for his grandiose scheme of
21. defending nine hundred theses taken from the whole range of his philosophical reading,
22. including Plato, Plotinus, Iamblichus, Proclus, and other Platonists. He planned to stage
23. this medieval spectacle—a scene familiar to the Parisian doctors with whom he had
24. briefly studied—in the heart of Renaissance Rome. A curial commission asked him to
25. reconsider just thirteen of the nine hundred propositions since they dealt with the real
26. presence in the Mass, the nature of Christ’s bodily form after resurrection, and other
27. delicate issues of Christian dogma. The hotheaded young count’s refusal provoked the
28. condemnation of his entire enterprise. Further defiance forced him to flee to Paris and
29. caused his brief imprisonment.

Title: (Medieval & Renaissance Texts & Studies 167) Stephen A. Farmer, Giovanni Pico Della Mirandola - Syn

Assistant

The Platonic conclusions of Pico’s Conclusiones (Book I, nos. 20–26 ≈ secundum Platonicos) represent the crux of his philosophical synthesis: the testing of Neoplatonic metaphysics within a Christian scholastic frame. Drawing together the insights of Farmer’s annotated Latin text, Howlett’s structural analysis, and Allen’s and Edelheit’s contextual readings, we can give a detailed close reading of what is happening here.

1. The textual and historical frame


Farmer’s edition shows Pico listing his authorities—Plotinus, Porphyry, Iamblichus, Proclus, and Adeland the Arab—and then staging fifteen theses “according to Plotinus,” such as:
  • 20.1 Primum intelligibile non est extra primum intellectum – the first intelligible is not beyond the first intellect.

  • 20.2 Non tota descendit anima quum descendit – the soul does not wholly descend when it descends.

  • 20.3 Omnis vita est immortalis – all life is immortal【101:0†(Medieval & Renaissance Texts & Studies 167) Stephen A. Farmer – Syncretism in the West†L24-L29】.


Farmer notes that none of these Neoplatonic works had yet appeared in Ficino’s Latin translations when Pico published the Theses (1486), and that his inclusion of an “Arab” Platonist emphasizes Platonism’s universality, independent of any one “nation.” The Conclusiones Platonicae are thus both a philosophical summa and a political declaration of universal wisdom【101:0†(Medieval & Renaissance Texts & Studies 167) Stephen A. Farmer – Syncretism in the West†L32-L46】.

2. Philosophical substance


These propositions describe an ontological chain: Intellect → Soul → Life → Matter, in which the higher never leaves the lower. Pico’s phrase “Non tota descendit anima” summarizes his adaptation of Plotinus Enn. IV.8.8: the soul’s highest part remains in the intelligible world even while animating the body. “Omnis vita est immortalis” universalizes the Neoplatonic zoē as divine continuity, later restated in his Hermetic conclusion I.27.5 “Nihil est in mundo expers vitae.”

3. Copenhaver’s theological reading


Brian Copenhaver would stress that these are scholastic propositions, not esoteric dogmas. Each is a disputable sentence meant to test philosophical theology before the tribunal of orthodoxy. The Platonist series illustrates what Copenhaver calls Pico’s “trial of philosophy”: pushing the limits of Christian metaphysics inside the legal categories that later defined his 1487 heresy investigation. The thesis “Omnis vita est immortalis” thus becomes a juridical problem—if all life is immortal, what of created mortality?—and the later Apologia defends it as a logical inference, not a pantheistic claim. In his view, the Platonic conclusions show the borderline orthodoxy that provoked the trial: metaphysics in scholastic form, theology under legal scrutiny【101:1†(Variorum Collected Studies 1063) Allen – Studies in the Platonism of Marsilio Ficino and Giovanni Pico†L21-L33】.

4. Howlett’s reconciliation of Plato and Aristotle


Sophia Howlett observes that Pico “uses what he knows to be Aristotelian argumentation… but the universe he describes is predominantly Platonic”【101:3†(Critical Political Theory and Radical Practice) Sophia Howlett – Re-evaluating Pico†L37-L51】.
In the Platonicae Conclusiones, this manifests as:
  • Plotinian hierarchy expressed through Aristotelian categories (act/potency, form/matter).

  • Proclean unity recast as Thomist convertibility of ens and unum.

  • A movement from metaphysical One to providential order, consistent with Christian creation.


Where Ficino’s Platonic Theology keeps the One beyond Being, Pico’s theses collapse that distance: Being and One are convertible, a stance later defended in De ente et uno. For Howlett, these conclusions dramatize Pico’s Aristotelianizing of Platonism—his way of reconciling metaphysics with theology by refusing Ficino’s emanationism.

5. Edelheit’s “humanist theology”


Amos Edelheit interprets these theses as the working method of Christian humanist theology: Pico arranges pagan authorities not to canonize them but to display their partial participation in divine truth. Each secundum Plotinum or secundum Proclum is a quaestio in a grand scholastic disputation. Philosophy serves theology by cataloguing and testing all that reason can know, confirming faith’s superiority. Thus, the Platonic conclusions are exercises in conciliation: the Christian intellect gathering the dispersed fragments of wisdom from the ancient nations.

6. Structural motifs in the text


Several key formulations encapsulate Pico’s metaphysics:

ThesisLiteral SenseTheological Reading
Primum intelligibile non est extra primum intellectumThe object of intellect is internal to intellect.Affirms divine simplicity—God’s act of knowing is identical with His being.
Non tota descendit animaThe soul partly remains above.Human intellect’s immortal aspect mirrors angelic hierarchy.
Omnis vita est immortalisEvery life is immortal.Life as continuous act of divine will, anticipating the Heptaplus’ doctrine of living matter.
Mens divina se intelligendo omnia intelligit (later)The divine mind knows all by knowing itself.Thomist–Proclean synthesis: self-knowledge as creation.

Together they enact the motion Howlett and Edelheit describe: philosophy ascending from multiplicity toward the unity of God, yet doing so through Aristotelian logical procedure.

7. Synthesis


Reading the Platonic conclusions through these modern lenses shows:

  • Copenhaver: They are juridical-theological propositions within the drama of Pico’s trial, not occult utterances.

  • Howlett: They are the workshop where Pico forges his reconciliation of Aristotle’s ens with Plato’s unum.

  • Edelheit: They exemplify the new genre of humanist theology, a philological scholasticism whose end is Christian concord.


In summary


The Conclusiones Platonicae are not mystical fragments but deliberate scholastic formulations translating Plotinian and Proclean metaphysics into Thomist terms. They dramatize Pico’s conviction that all life and intellect participate in divine unity, while insisting that such participation remains within Christian orthodoxy. They stand as the hinge between his early Oratio and later De ente et uno—the moment where Platonic ascent becomes the dialectic of faith and reason that Copenhaver, Howlett, and Edelheit alike see as Pico’s enduring contribution to Renaissance thought【101:0†(Medieval & Renaissance Texts & Studies 167) Stephen A. Farmer – Syncretism in the West†L32-L46】【101:3†(Critical Political Theory and Radical Practice) Sophia Howlett – Re-evaluating Pico†L37-L51】【101:1†(Variorum Collected Studies 1063) Allen – Studies in the Platonism of Marsilio Ficino and Giovanni Pico†L21-L33】.

1. Nor was this all, for the period saw many other fundamental changes.
2. The philological method elaborated by Lorenzo Valla, Politian and
3. Erasmus made it possible to date and compare rediscovered texts and
4. thus to read them in a new light. Agricola and Ramus devised a new
5. inventive method; followers of Lull developed the art of classi� cation

7. Kepler and Galileo proposed new methods for measuring the move-

10. of the blood; Lucretius’ work discovered in the � fteenth century sug-

12. of the in� nity of worlds.

15.
16. Giovanni Pico della Mirandola’s Apologia for his Conclusiones nongentae
17.
18. (Nine hundred theses), by the end of the � fteenth century the theory of
19. “natural magic” had become much discussed in high-cultural circles.
20.
21. Working on a basis of Neoplatonism, Orphism and Hermetism, the
22. two philosophers had reintroduced the traditional astrological theory of
23. the correspondences between celestial bodies and “elementated” bodies,
24. combining this with Avicenna’s theory of the power of the imagination
25. and the Stoic-Neoplatonic idea of “spiritus”—thus Ficino, Pico and
26. many others maintained that the power of magic was independent of
27. the invocation of spirits.
28.
29. Ficino and Pico had brought to light a number of ideas that were
30. already to be found in patristic and scholastic times, but had received
31. limited attention from professional philosophers. From the end of the
32. � fteenth century these had become dominant among the elites and soon
33. spread abroad among academic and literary circles. The Neoplatonic
34. and Hermetic theories of the two Florentines on the cosmos, the “spirit”
35. and the forces of nature had given rise to a new idea of magic.
36.
37. In those same years, between the � fteenth and the sixteenth centu-
38. ries, another who failed to believe this was Lefèvre d’Etaples, the great
39. Parisian editor of humanist translations of the ancient philosophers of
40. every school, who later joined the evangelical church and whose attitude
41.

50. written in a brief moment of infatuation with Ficino, is the only one
51. of his works which he did not print and which he refused to distribute

20. what was acceptable in it. The first two theses established the two kinds of
21. magic: “All magic that is in use among the moderns, and which the church
22. justly exterminates, has no firmness, no foundation, no truth, because

28. He declared that “[n]o magical operation can be of any efficacy unless
29. it has annexed to it a work of Cabala, explicit or implicit.” Moreover,
30. “The nature of that which is the horizon of temporal eternity is next to
31. the magus, but above him, and proper to it is the Cabala.” Further, “No
32. names that mean something, insofar as those names are singular and
33. taken per se, can have power in a magical work, unless they are Hebrew
34. names, or closely derived from Hebrew.” And he concluded his magic
35. theses by noting, “Just as through the influence of the first agent, if that
36. influence is individual and immediate, something is achieved that is not
37. attained through the mediation of causes, so through a work of Cabala,
38. if it is the pure and immediate Cabala, something is achieved to which
39. no magic attains.”25
40.
