how does energeia come into the thomas and dionysius stuff in oration and de ente

Assistant

Excellent question — and a subtle one. What you’re noticing is that Pico’s “Aristotelianization” of Neoplatonism in both the Oratio de hominis dignitate and De ente et uno hinges precisely on how he uses energeia (act, activity, actuality) as the bridge between Thomas Aquinas and Pseudo-Dionysius.
Let’s unpack how this happens step by step.

1. Background: Bradshaw’s genealogy of energeia

From Bradshaw’s Aristotle East and West:

“The energeia of the Prime Mover is both supreme actuality and the activity of self-thinking thought… Plotinus transforms this into an internal act productive of external acts; Dionysius, in turn, theologizes it as procession (proodos) and return (epistrophē).”【138:3–4†Bradshaw†L19-47】

So by late antiquity, energeia no longer meant “mere actuality” but living activity that radiates being.
In Christian hands—especially Dionysius—it becomes the way God’s superessential Goodness “overflows” into creation.

2. Energeia in Dionysius: God’s energies as providential outflow

Dionysius’s Divine Names and Celestial Hierarchy translate Neoplatonic emanation into a theology of divine operations:

“The divine goodness…is not an inert being but a living activity [energeia] which moves all things to existence.”

Bradshaw and Copenhaver both highlight that for Dionysius, energy is participation without division—the act whereby God is present in creatures without ceasing to transcend them.
This is what Thomas Aquinas will later call actus purus (pure act), but for Dionysius it remains pluralized as “energies”—distinct ways God manifests Himself.

3. Thomas Aquinas: unifying essence and act

Thomas re-reads Dionysius through Aristotelian logic.
He collapses Dionysius’s plural energies into one simple divine act of being (esse subsistens):

“In God, essence and existence are identical; therefore, His act is His being itself.”

(ST I.3.4, I.44.1)

That move simplifies—but also freezes—the dynamic Dionysian energeia into metaphysical actus.
Bradshaw calls this the decisive Western turn toward identity-metaphysics.

4. Pico’s synthesis: bringing the two back together

Pico is steeped in both Thomism and Dionysian Platonism.
In the Oratio, he explicitly fuses them:

“God sowed the seeds of all things in the human mind so that, acting (agens) through its own powers, it might bring forth the likeness of divine operations.”

—Oratio, §5

This is Dionysian in its participatory theology (humans “mirror divine operations”)
but Aristotelian-Thomist in its terminology of agens, potentia, and actus.
Human dignity = the capacity to convert potency into act imitating divine energeia.

5. De ente et uno: reconciliation of Plato’s One and Aristotle’s Act

In De ente et uno, Pico explicitly argues that Plato and Aristotle do not really differ:

“Plato says the One is beyond being; Aristotle that the One is being itself: yet the difference is verbal, not real.”【138:6†Heptaplus…Being and One†L6-10】

Here Pico translates Platonic procession (the One beyond being) into Aristotelian act of being:

  • The Platonic “beyond being” = God’s superessential energeia.

  • The Aristotelian actus essendi = the same divine fullness viewed from creation’s side.


Thus he restores Dionysius’s “double vision” of God:
above being (negative theology) and source of all being (active energy).

6. How this works in Oratio’s anthropology

In the Oratio, Pico writes:

“Thou, constrained by no limits, mayest determine thy nature for thyself, be the molder and maker of thyself.”

This freedom is nothing less than the energeia of the intellect and will:

  • The Thomist side: man is potentia capable of actus intelligendi—knowing and loving God.

  • The Dionysian side: these acts are participations in the divine energy—human knowing as theosis.


So for Pico, “human dignity” = participation in God’s active being, not passive reception of grace.

7. The philosophical upshot

TraditionView of energeia/actusEffect in Pico
Aristotle / AquinasActus essendi = unity of form and existence; pure actuality in GodGives Pico logical grammar and causality
Plotinus / DionysiusEnergeia = self-diffusive activity of the OneGives Pico the vision of creative overflow
Pico’s synthesisHuman intellect mirrors divine act by translating potency into act; creation = ongoing energy of GodRestores a dynamic theology of act—the Aristotelianization of the miraculous (Howlett)

In Pico’s own idiom

“Whatever God works in the universe, He first works in man; and as He is the act of all being, so man, by intellect and will, becomes act in his own microcosm.”

(Conclusiones Magicae, II.9.6; cf. Oratio §8)

In Summary

  • From Dionysius, Pico learns that God’s being is energetic: a radiating, self-communicating goodness.

  • From Aquinas, he learns the metaphysical grammar of act and potency.

  • In the Oratio, he applies that grammar anthropologically—man imitates divine energy by actualizing his own potential.

  • In De ente et uno, he makes the metaphysical claim—the One and Being are the same reality seen from opposite ends of the chain of act.


So energeia is the deep metaphysical hinge of Pico’s Christian Hermeticism:
it lets him join Aristotle’s actus purus to Dionysius’s overflowing Light, showing that to be—and to act freely—is already to participate in the living energy of God.

1. Ficino was well grounded in the intricacies of negative theology, the theology that
2. denies the possibility of talking about God except in equivocal terms, and he was to
3. devote some considerable time eventually to commenting on the works of the Dionysius
4. the Areopagite, “the prince of Christian theologians” for him as for Pico,29 especially
5. On the Divine Names. Even more significantly perhaps, he was to compose his longest
6. Plato commentary on the Areopagite’s ultimate source and inspiration, the second part
7. of Plato’s Parmenides, where Plato has the aging Eleatic explore inter alia the
8. consequences that would ensue were the One not to exist.30 Therefore, Ficino, if amazed
9. at all, as Pico claimed, must have been amazed not at the notion that God cannot be said
10. to understand anything in the way we or even the angels understand (for this was an
11. apophatic argument with which he was wholly familiar) but rather at its role in the
12. particular passage in Plotinus.
13.
14. One of Pico’s most interesting contributions in the Commento is, I would argue, his
15. account of the three hypostases, particularly of the second, which the ancient
16. Neoplatonists had identified with Mind but which he identifies with Angel or Angelic
17. Mind. Some of the Neoplatonists had maintained that between the first hypostasis, God
18. or the One or the Good, and the third hypostasis, the World Soul, came a host of
19. intelligible and intellectual creatures whom Christians call the “angels”31 – and here
20. Pico reveals his medievalism, since Plotinus had spoken simply of Soul and had argued
21. that the World-Soul is the first instance of this generic Soul. For this view, Pico
22. specifically cites Proclus, Hermias, and Syrianus (Proclus’s teacher), along with the
23. Areopagite and other Christian theologians, probably alluding to Scotus and Giles of
24. Viterbo (since he adduces them later).32 In his terminology, he is certainly drawing upon
25. Iamblichian and Proclian distinctions between the Ideas (the pure intelligibles) and the
26. highest spiritual beings contemplating them, who are in turn midway between the
27. intelligibles and the host of intellectual beings below them. These are distinctions,
28. incidentally, that postdate Plato and that an enthusiast who assumes the integrity of the
29. Platonic tradition and its hermeneutics can easily read back into the Platonic text, as did
30. the later Neoplatonists as a matter of principle. However, those Pico twice calls the
31. “more perfect Platonists,” Plotinus and Porphyry among them, had maintained that
32. between the first and third hypostases there is only one Mind, not many minds, and they
33. had even referred to it as the “son” of the father. This view, he says, is also closer to the
34. opinion of Aristotle, and he prefers it because it enables him to explore the ground
35.
36.
37.
38. common to both Platonists and Aristotelians33 (such as Avicenna, who is mentioned at
39. the beginning of the next chapter, 1.4). This is an important issue for Pico and is worth
40. looking at in detail.
41.
42. From his eternity, God creates this single Mind, and since He is the perfect cause, it
43. is a perfect effect and is unique.

63. the middle rank is assigned to the work of the heavens, it could
64. not be more fittingly symbolized than by the firmament, that is,
65. the sky. The final hierarchy, although by nature it is above
66. everybody and above the heavens, nevertheless has charge of
67. things under the heavens.

21. cism had moved from ‘seeing’ to the unio mystica, or ‘becoming one
22. with God.’ This required a movement inward and upward: first removing
23. oneself from the world and then from oneself as we become lost in God.
24. We move beyond knowledge (wisdom or understanding, the end point
25. of kataphatic theology), to a change in our being173 or, depending on
26. the thinker, loss of our being in the One. We have moved beyond the
27. Aristotelian Active Intellect, beyond Being itself, to Platonic henosis .
28.
29. Kabbalism presents us with both options. The Tree of Life is made
30. up primarily of the ‘knowable’ expressed as particular active attributes
31. of the divine. Debhequth is therefore not an apophatic ascent into the
32. cloud of unknowing, but part of kataphatic theology. But the idea of the
33. Ein-Sof takes us into the apophatic realm. Keter itself is more compli-
34. cated. It stands in-between. It is the thought or breath of God. There
35. is a tradition that we may ascend to Keter just like the congregation of
36. Israel, as the bride to Keter’s bridegroom, and ‘crown’ the ‘head’ of God.
37. But in combining Pseudo-Dionysius, with Platonism, Aristotelianism,
38. and Jewish thought (as Pico is attempting to do), it is unclear what
39. henosis would be in Kabbalism and what is the role of Keter or the
40. Ein-Sof . We shall explore this further in Chapters 5 and 6. Elsewhere,
41. where Pseudo-Dionysius and Kabbalism do not coincide, Pico tries hard
42. to relate Pseudo-Dionysius to Kabbalism. For instance, Pico changes
43. Pseudo-Dionysius’ hierarchy of angels from nine to ten, the number of
44. the sefirot.174
45.
46.
47.
48. 4 THE THIRD PILLAR: PICO AND KABBALISM 115
49.
50. But Pico has a specific purpose in studying the tradition. This hereto-
51. fore missing aspect of God’s truth, not only enrichened Christianity175

Title: (Critical Political Theory and Radical Practice) Sophia Howlett - Re-evaluating Pico_ Aristotelianism, Kabbalism, and Platonism in the Philosophy of Giovanni Pico della Mirandola-Palgrave Macmillan (2.pdf
Content Snippet:
1. Pico’s repeated goal during his career was to build concord between these
2. differing strands, the major philosophical streams of the day, whether
3. based on Plato or Aristotle, or a mixture thereof; and to re-establish
4. the relationship between philosophy and theology, reason and faith, to
5. provide a pathway home for the philosopher-mystic to God. He is a
6. syncretist or ‘concordist’: an epithet encouraged by one of his actual titles,
7. Prince of Concord.
8.
9. ‘Concordism’ as a term is particularly associated with forming agree-
10. ment between Aristotle and Plato. It was espoused by Cardinal Bessarion,
11. one of the earliest proponents of the new Greek Studies.110 Concordism
12. can also be talked about as ‘perennial truth,’ or universalism. This takes
13. us beyond Plato and Aristotle to the deeper question of the original truth
14. underlying both. Pico did take his ‘concordism’ in this direction: consis-
15. tently claiming that he had the key to deeper mysteries that could provide
16. concordance to all things.111
17.
18. Pico’s ‘concordism’ is part of a series of ongoing attempts to bring
19. faith and reason back together, heightened by the atmosphere of crisis
20. at the end of the fifteenth century and the related desire for reform in
21. religious life and structures. For example, for a Christian, Aristotelianism
22. suggests that philosophy alone can bring us at least close to God: if our
23. intellect is active, it can and should be able to find its way toward God
24. just by using its own resources. But Augustine argued that it cannot be
25. done simply by using our intellect. God must reach down to us as well.
26. But it was very easy for this reaching down simply to make us increasingly
27. passive: relying on faith rather than using our intellects actively ourselves.
28. If we want to bring about change, redefine our pathway to the divine,
29. and connect our intellects to God’s (whether in a mutual reaching out or
30. not), then religion and philosophy need each other.
31.
32. Pico is trying to bring together philosophy and theology, reason and
33. faith, not just as two approaches to thinking about metaphysics, but
34. also as two stages of the route to personal fulfillment. We need philos-
35. ophy, which takes us to theology and then to religious faith, to echo
36. Pseudo-Dionysius.112 Pico is taking us back to the very same issues that
37.
38.
39.
40. 76 S. HOWLETT
41.
42. motivated St Augustine, Boethius, Averroes and Maimonides, and Ficino
43. too: finding and setting out the bond between human reason and reli-
44. gious truth. It can be easy to forget that above all Pico is a Christian and
45. his syncretism centers around Christianity: reverifying the truths of Chris-
46. tianity, and linking Christian truth to disparate philosophical schools,
47. different times and places. Plato and Aristotle, with all their descendants,
48. are being brought together for the greater good of Christianity, and
49. Christian truths always come first.113
50.
51. Indeed, Pico’s structure consistently hierarchizes the process of concor-
52. dance: resolution can lean toward one argument over another.114 This
53. is perhaps why the conversation between Pico’s Aristotelianism and
54. Platonism is so complicated: sometimes he appears to favor Aris-
55. totelianism, and at other times gives a more Platonic answer. It depends
56. what works to form that overall deep structure that can contain and
57. express the religious mystery of an ‘expressed’ God (understanding the
58. universe as the expression of the divine). We are sifting through each
59. philosopher so that we end up not with who is right, but rather who
60. writes the truth, and who will help us home.

1. But in this text the Metatron is not only the firstborn of God.
2. The Platonic universe presents us with a hall of mirrors; a series of
3. echoes extending outward; while Kabbalism’s sacred play with language,
4. numbers and the sefirot extends the mirrorwork into possibilities of
5. multiple understandings/meanings within each sefira, as well as between
6. worlds. So, the Metatron can also be the ascended Enoch: thereby
7. connecting God with the mystic, the seeker after God. The Metatron
8. is the apotheosis of the seeker (much like Christ: St Augustine’s God
9. who became man so that man might become God). This transference
10. of the active intellect from son of God, the firstborn, to the ascended
11. mystic further implies that the mystic ‘becomes also a son, by the dint of
12. his actualized intellect.’107 There is then a ‘double intellectual sonship:
13. that of the cosmic, who is the Agent Intellect, and an angel and son…
14. and that of the mystic, who became a son by becoming an intellect in
15. actu.’108 This suggests ‘a transformative understanding of the intellectual
16. activity’ as in the Oration, where the intellectual man can be an angel
17. and son of God.109 Pico was not the only person who made these links
18. during his lifetime. Mercurio da Coreggio, called himself both the son
19. of God and Enoch, as well as Mercurio, a name linked to Hermeticism
20. (Mercury/Hermes).110
21.
22. Below the Metatron (Christ or below Christ), there are three ranks of
23. three groups of angels making nine different layers (again, nine plus one).
24. Each of the three groups reflects a different level of the three worlds of the
25. universe. In the angelic mind, the angels are the thrones, cherubims, and
26. seraphim. For the second world, the celestial realm of planets, the angels
27. are the principalities, archangels, and angels. The principalities oversee
28. states, kings, and princes, the archangels oversee mysteries and holy cere-
29. monies, and the angels are ‘assigned to men individually’ and deal with
30. private affairs.111
31.
32.
33.
34. 5 PICO’S UNIVERSE 157
35.
36. But angels are at least partly imperfect in that they are at one remove
37. from perfection, and so adulterated by matter. Pico speaks of a ‘double
38. imperfection’: ‘the one, that it is not being itself but only an essence
39. to which being comes by participation, so that it may be; the other,
40. that it is not intelligence itself but only happens to understand, since by
41. its nature it is an intellect capable of understanding.’112 So ‘the angels
42. understand God only so far as His nature is made manifest in their own
43. substance….’113 This is why we also need God’s active presence, or the
44. transformative understanding provided by the active intellect.
45.
46. Even though we desire perfection, which gives us a natural desire for
47. God, ‘nothing can rise above itself by relying on its own strength (other-
48. wise it would be stronger than itself), so nothing relying on itself can
49. attain a felicity any greater or more perfect than its own nature.’114 We
50. attain God ‘either in the creatures in which he participates or in himself.
51. Through their own powers, created things cannot achieve this ultimate
52. felicity, but only that which is within its own nature.

1. 128 HEPTAPLUS
2.
3. Chapter One
4.
5. To speak of the angelic nature, which is pure intellect, let us
6. first imagine that minds are like eyes. What the eye is among
7. corporeal things, the mind is in the spiritual realm. Although
8. the mixture of its own innermost substance includes some light,
9. the eye, in order to perform its task of vision, needs external
10. light, by which to observe the colors and differences of things.
11. Its nature is to see, even though it does not see without the aid
12. of light. The ears and all the other parts of the body, not to
13. speak of inanimate things, are illuminated by the light, but
14. nevertheless do not see. Therefore the eye has received for its
15. lot the power of seeing and has sight by virtue of its own es­
16. sence, since when it receives light, it can see.
17.
18. Let us consider the same things on the intellectual level. In­
19. tellects are eyes, intelligible truth is light, and the intellect,
20. itself intelligible, has a kind of inner light by which it can see
21. itself but not other things. It needs the forms and ideas of
22. things, like· rays of invisible light, for the intelligible truth to
23. be clearly discerned. And it must not be said, as we made clear
24. in the example of the eye, that intellects are not intelligent
25. by nature and, like our souls, have obtained the power of in­
26. telligence accidentally. From this arises the theory of those
27. who consider "intellect" an unworthy appellation for God. If
28. we compare the intellect with the eye, which does not see by
29. itself but only with the help of light, then since God is light
30. (for light is truth) and vision is the action in which the eye
31. comes in contact with light, God does not need this step, since
32. He is light itself, as much more remote than the angels are
33. from any ignorance of things as the nature of light is more
34. distant from darkness than the eyes. But let us return to the
35. angels.
36.
37. The eye, that is, intellectual substance, is not wholly simple;
38. otherwise it could not endure mingling with the oncoming
39. light. From this comes the common doctrine that angels are
40.

Title: (Variorum Collected Studies 1063) Allen, MichaelJ. B - Studies in the Platonism of Marsilio Ficino and Giovanni Pico-Routledge (2017).pdf
Content Snippet:
1. The soul’s pure intellectual vision depends of course on a theory of the soul’s ascent
2. and necessarily on the role of its highest faculty and on the corresponding theory of the
3. Ideas seen by that faculty. So let us turn now to Pico’s presentation of Platonic
4. psychology in the Commento, which is keyed, interestingly, to being and not, as in
5. Ficino, to unity – though we should note that Pico is clearly indebted to the third book of
6. Ficino’s Platonic Theology and its exploration of God’s attributes, including God’s
7. role in our understanding. The Commento begins with an ontological preoccupation by
8. distinguishing among causal, formal, and participated being as a fundamental Platonic
9.
10.
11.
12. postulate and by defining God not as being per se but as the cause of being and not as an
13. intellect per se but as the source and cause of all intellect.27 This leads Pico from the
14. onset to challenge the reaction of amazement by “un gran platonico” (clearly Ficino) to
15. a passage in Plotinus’s Enneads (5.6.3 or 6.7.37) in which God is said to understand
16. nothing and to castigate him for not realizing that Plotinus merely intended that “the
17. attribute of understanding exists in God in its causal not formal being [secondo quello
18. essere causale e non secondo quello formate].”28 This is demonstrably polemical.
19. Ficino was well grounded in the intricacies of negative theology, the theology that
20. denies the possibility of talking about God except in equivocal terms, and he was to
21. devote some considerable time eventually to commenting on the works of the Dionysius
22. the Areopagite, “the prince of Christian theologians” for him as for Pico,29 especially
23. On the Divine Names. Even more significantly perhaps, he was to compose his longest
24. Plato commentary on the Areopagite’s ultimate source and inspiration, the second part
25. of Plato’s Parmenides, where Plato has the aging Eleatic explore inter alia the
26. consequences that would ensue were the One not to exist.30 Therefore, Ficino, if amazed
27. at all, as Pico claimed, must have been amazed not at the notion that God cannot be said
28. to understand anything in the way we or even the angels understand (for this was an
29. apophatic argument with which he was wholly familiar) but rather at its role in the
30. particular passage in Plotinus.
31.
32. One of Pico’s most interesting contributions in the Commento is, I would argue, his
33. account of the three hypostases, particularly of the second, which the ancient
34. Neoplatonists had identified with Mind but which he identifies with Angel or Angelic
35. Mind. Some of the Neoplatonists had maintained that between the first hypostasis, God
36. or the One or the Good, and the third hypostasis, the World Soul, came a host of
37. intelligible and intellectual creatures whom Christians call the “angels”31 – and here
38. Pico reveals his medievalism, since Plotinus had spoken simply of Soul and had argued
39. that the World-Soul is the first instance of this generic Soul.

Content Snippet:
1. Pico’s universe always combines rationality with divinity until the
2. point where words fail, and God becomes hidden in darkness. It brings
3. together the Latin world’s preoccupation with the relationship between
4. reason and faith, and its emphasis on kataphatic (positive) theology, with
5. the negative or apophatic theology so important in Byzantine Orthodoxy,
6. at a time of renewed interest in writers such as Pseudo-Dionysius. Pico,
7. prince of Concord, reveals the harmony between philosophical traditions,
8. and between those philosophies and the secrets of theology.
9.
10. In doing so, he pursues the path of exceptionalism. He is the
11. gentleman-philosopher with the secrets to individual henosis . For he
12. reveals that this deep structure of the universe is also a ladder: a ladder
13. which brings angels down to us and take us up toward the divine. The
14. ladder is built out of what God is—the positive (describable) attributes.
15. Beyond the ladder, beyond our universe, is the realm of what God is
16. not…. Pico’s henotic process is focused on the ladder. For it is also a
17. noetic process, where first possible union or assimilation is between our
18.
19.
20.
21. 3 PICO’S INTELLECTUAL FOUNDATIONS … 55
22.
23. intellect (the upper level of our soul) and attributes of the divine related
24. to the Aristotelian active intellect.
25.
26. Aristotelianism or more specifically Aristotelian logic and theory of
27. causality provide the primary mode of argumentation. Pico applies this
28. logic to both the act of concordance (to draw together the disparate
29. threads of different traditions), and his attempts to describe the deep
30. structure.4 Sometimes the sacred, the mystery with which the deep
31. structure is imbued is more dominant, and at other times, Aristotle
32. leads. Platonism is next. At the macro level, Pico’s deep structure
33. is predominantly a Platonic universe inflected by Aristotle. Platonism
34. also provides the ‘divine something’ that links the more scientific Aris-
35. totelianism to religious revelation. Kabbalism provides the skeleton, or
36. the bones of the universe: the Tree of Life or divine lightning flash of the
37. emanating/creative5 God provides the pathway home, and most partic-
38. ularly the ladder that links us on earth to the mysteries of the divine
39. in our universe. Christianity, particularly the mystical tradition expressed
40. through Pseudo-Dionysius and others, is the living spirit of his world,
41. binding everything together.
42.
43. But there are complications. ‘Aristotle’ in the fifteenth century is not
44. the same as today. This is also true of Platonism (do we mean Plato, or
45. Plotinus, or Proclus, or the Christian Platonism of Ficino, for example).
46. Aristotelianism and Platonism in the fifteenth century were already inter-
47. connected through commentaries drawing on both, revivals (particularly
48. of Aristotle), and prior attempts at concordance by, for example, Boethius
49. who used the Platonist Porphyry when commenting on Aristotelean logic.
50. Both Aristotelianism and Platonism had also become part of other tradi-
51. tions that Pico thought to be distinctive, including within Christian and
52. Jewish theology. For example, Platonism and Christianity are already
53. combined in Pseudo-Dionysius’ version of henosis . We should assume
54. that Pico was largely unaware of these connections. From his perspec-
55. tive, finding traces of Platonism in Kabbalism simply looked like proof
56. that there is a deep structure underlying them all.

1. Yet if Pico’s human being is the creature that has no fixed nature, one
2. might expect that Pico stands the scholastic paradigm on its head: where
3. there is no determinate nature, there can be no natural limits. Is this what
4. Pico had in mind when he spoke of “a perfect knowledge of everything
5. knowable”?8 In what follows, we shall investigate the steps that lead to this
6. loftiest goal for human beings, whether they can traverse them or not.
7.
8. I. Cognitive Powers
9.
10. Faithful to its scholastic roots, Pico’s account of the soul and its powers
11. forms the basis of his account of cognitive functioning. In addition to
12. the body, the human being has a soul consisting of four “parts” – the
13.
14. 6 De anima 3.7 431a 16–17, trans. J. A Smith, in The Complete Works of Aristotle, ed. Jonathan
15. Barnes (Princeton: Bollingen, 1984), 1:685.
16.
17. 7 See Thomas Aquinas, Summa theologiae, I q. 12, a. 4, corp. Pico calls Thomas “the glory of
18. our theology” (Heptaplus 2, proem [trans. Carmichael, 95]), but he does not consistently
19. follow Aquinas and sometimes makes him a target of criticism. For varying accounts of
20. Pico’s relationship to Aquinas, in addition to Dulles, see Paul Oskar Kristeller, “Thomism
21. and the Italian Thought of the Renaissance,” in Medieval Aspects of Renaissance Learning:
22. Three Essays, ed. and trans. Edward P. Mahoney (Durham, NC: Duke University Press,
23. 1974), 71–3, and Farmer, Syncretism in the West, 47–9 and the notes on 218–31.
24.
25. 8 Conclusions 3>40 (Farmer, 410–11). This passage refers specifically to acquiring com-
26. plete knowledge through intelligibles above us without relying on inquiry, but by instead
27. following “a purgatorial path” (per uiam purgatoriam). Pico asserts that this position is
28. common to Platonists as well as Aristotelians, though it is “less apparent” in the latter.
29.
30.
31.
32. P1: KAE
33. 9780521847360c08 CUFX160/Dougherty 0 521 84736 2 July 26, 2007 15:27
34.
35. 182 Carl N. Still
36.
37. vegetative, the sensitive, the rational, and the intellectual.9 While the
38. vegetative part has purely vital functions of nourishing and sustaining the
39. body, the other three powers represent an ascending order of intellectual
40. power. Strictly speaking, the differentiation of the intellectual from the
41. rational as distinct powers of soul is anomalous in scholastic terms, since,
42. as Pico notes in his early Commento, “Latin Aristotelians” take the rational
43. part “to be the highest and noblest part of our soul.”10 While the Latin
44. scholastics recognized that the rational soul contained within it the power
45. of purely intellectual thought associated with the angels,11 Pico follows
46. the Platonists, for whom there is an “intellectual and angelic part” of
47. the human soul above the rational soul.12 This appeal to intellect and
48. reason as distinct parts of the soul and not merely powers of the same
49. part serves Pico’s purpose of sewing together Platonic and Aristotelian
50. accounts of the soul while also illustrating the distinction of levels in the
51. human being, from the bestial (corresponding to sense) to the human
52. (reason) to the angelic (intellect).

Assistant

In both the Commento sopra una canzone d’amore and the Heptaplus, Pico develops the concept of the angelic mind (mens angelica) as the key metaphysical bridge between divine act (energeia) and human intellect. The doctrine evolves from a psychological allegory into a full metaphysics of mediation, integrating Aristotelian act–potency theory, Platonic participation, and Dionysian angelology.

1. The Angelic Mind in the Commento


Michael J. B. Allen shows that Pico reinterprets the second Neoplatonic hypostasis—the Nous or Divine Mind—as the angelic mind, thereby “Christianizing” the Plotinian intellect. Against Plotinus’s unitary Nous, Pico proposes an angelic hierarchy between God and the world-soul, following Proclus and Pseudo-Dionysius but emphasizing creation ex nihilo:
“One of Pico’s most interesting contributions in the Commento is his account of the three hypostases, particularly of the second, which the ancient Neoplatonists had identified with Mind but which he identifies with Angel or Angelic Mind.”【147:2†(Variorum Collected Studies 1063) Allen†L14-L34】

This angelic mind embodies the active intellect at a cosmic level—the perfect intelligible mediator reflecting God’s creative thought. Farmer notes that Pico’s “celestial Venus” symbolizes this intellect, in which human intellects participate through eros and ascent:

“The soul rises from its rational to its intellectual part, and the ‘celestial Venus’ (the intellect or angelic mind) reveals herself… through love the soul unites its partial intellect to the universal intellect or angelic mind, the ‘first of creatures, the ultimate and universal lodging of ideal beauty.’”【147:16†(Medieval & Renaissance Texts & Studies 167) Farmer†L7-L20】

So, in the Commento, mens angelica is both cosmic intellect (the created logos of divine ideas) and moral ideal (the form of the purified human mind).

2. The Angelic Mind in the Heptaplus


In Heptaplus I–III, Pico expands this into a Genesis cosmology of intellect as act and potency. The angelic substance is pure intellect “composed of act and potency,” symbolized as heaven and earth:
“The eye, that is, intellectual substance, is not wholly simple… angels are composed of act and potency, although there is dispute as to what the act is, and what the potency.”【147:10†Heptaplus†L37-L47】

The angelic mind receives divine illumination like the eye receives light—an image that fuses Aristotelian hylomorphism with Dionysian metaphysics. In another passage, Pico writes:

“The Spirit of the Lord… was borne upon the deep, that is, upon the angelic intellect (for love follows understanding)… God said ‘Be light made,’ and light was made in the angel, the light of intelligible forms.”【147:3†Heptaplus†L13-L27】

Here the energeia of divine love animates angelic understanding—love turns intellect toward God, and illumination becomes the act that perfects its potency. The angels’ hierarchy (waters above and below) mirrors Dionysius’s triads; their perfection is the contemplative union of light and intellect.

3. Theological Anthropology and the Human Analogue


In the Heptaplus and Oratio, the human intellect mirrors the angelic:
  • It is potential intellect seeking act through divine illumination.

  • It achieves participation in God’s energeia through contemplation and love.

  • Reason mediates between sense and intellect, rising toward the angelic level【147:0†M. V. Dougherty – New Essays†L13-L25】.


Thus, Pico’s anthropology is angelomorphic: the human soul becomes angelic by transforming its rational potency into intellectual act.

4. Modern Interpretations


  • Howlett interprets this as Pico’s Aristotelianization of the miraculous: the angelic intellect exemplifies how form–matter relations express divine act within creation, not pneumatic magic【147:6†Howlett†L1-L27】.

  • Edelheit emphasizes Pico’s use of Aquinas and Dionysius to define intellect as participation in divine act, making angels the model of pure energeia rather than intermediary gods.

  • Busi & Ebgi note that Pico’s angelic eros retains a Platonic erotic dynamism: beauty and imperfection belong to creation, not to God【147:12†Busi & Ebgi†L4-L13】.


5. Synthesis

LevelFunction of Angelic MindPhilosophical SourcesTheological Role
CommentoCosmic Nous mediating divine ideasPlotinus, Proclus, AristotleModel for human ascent and divine eros
HeptaplusCreated intellect composed of act/potency, perfected by loveAristotle’s De Anima + DionysiusVehicle of divine energeia in creation
Human SoulImage of angelic mind; rational potency striving toward actAquinas, AugustinePath of deification (imitatio angelorum)

In essence:
Pico’s angelic mind unites the Aristotelian principle of energeia with the Dionysian hierarchy of love. It embodies the act by which intellect becomes luminous through divine illumination, and therefore explains how knowing and loving together enact the creative grammar of being.

33. essere un esteta esigente, il Conte rivela insomma una seconda na­
34. tura, di logico consumato che padroneggia i trucchi della scolastica
35. medievale. Nel panorama del secondo Quattrocento, l 'unione di
36. eleganza formale e di passione speculativa è prerogativa rara, che
37. fa di Pico forse l 'unico autentico filosofo in un'epoca ricca di eru­
38. dizione ma povera di pensiero teorico .

1. Finally, to compound the confusion, in 1518 a relative of Ficino’s, Biagio
2. Buonaccorsi, used Benivieni’s expurgated version (but collated in part, it would seem,
3. with a manuscript of the unexpurgated one!) to prepare another edition of Benivieni’s
4. poems that would include both the Commento as such and “Amor, dalle cui.” This was
5. the Giunta edition of Benivieni’s Opere (it included an errata sheet), which was
6. published in Florence in 1519 with the Commento as the first item and with the poem
7. appearing between books 2 and 3. Occupying some 67 octavo leaves, Pico’s work was
8. now entitled Commento delo illustrissimo Signore Conte Iohanni Pico Miradulano
9. sopra una Canzona de Amore composta da Hieronymo Benivieni Ciptadino
10. Fiorentino secondo la mente & opinione de’ Platonici Benivieni must have known all
11. about the venture and about Buonaccorsi’s attempt to rework the Commento, but he
12. claims partial ignorance. The 1519 text was then reprinted in the Venice 1522 edition of
13. Benivieni’s Opere, with the errata corrected, and this 1522 version of the Commento
14. was thereafter published in the three Basel editions of Pico della Mirandola’s own
15. Opera omnia (1557, 1572, and 1601), where it is listed in the table of contents as
16.
17.
18.
19. “three books on Plato’s Symposium,” though properly entitled Commento in the text
20. itself.11
21.
22. Obviously the problems of editing the Commento and of deciding which version or
23. versions to privilege are fraught with challenges, particularly since Benivieni’s caliber
24. as a poet makes his own contribution and his reworking both of the commentary and of
25. the canzone important aspects of the story and since too he was in a position to analyze
26. Pico’s intentions better than any of his contemporaries, let alone modern scholars,
27. however distinguished. And I am thinking here of Eugenio Garin in particular, who has
28. done more than anyone else to enhance our understanding of Pico and his whole age and
29. to uncover the various stages in the changes and cover-ups; it is he indeed who
30. published the original unexpurgated version in his monumental 1942 edition of Pico’s
31. works, the standard edition we still refer to.12
32.
33. In the Commento, Pico is concerned, broadly speaking, with poetic theology; he does
34. not comment extensively on Plato’s Symposium but discusses only selected bits and
35. pieces of it. The work hardly compares to Ficino’s De amore, either in length or
36. breadth, though it raises a number of subtle points and has a rapid-fire brilliance to it.
37. Nor indeed does it always persuade us that Pico is right in his series of contretemps
38. with Ficino, and its combative mode of arguing has to be understood in the light of the
39. conventions of Renaissance scholarly disagreements, which were voiced, as a rule, in
40. pricklier terms than we usually adopt today. More surprisingly, Pico is not (yet) well
41. acquainted with Platonic texts that have a bearing on the Symposium, especially the
42. Phaedrus, along with Hermias’s commentary on it; the Charmides; and various sections
43. of the Enneads. And despite his protestations, he is not concerned with love theory
44. except in a rudimentary form.

35. 2 The Commento alla Canzone d’amore
36.
37. The Commento alla Canzone is Pico’s attempt to interpret a love poem by his
38. friend and colleague Girolamo Benivieni through the lens of the Neoplatonic
39. tradition, which he had learned through Ficino. Marginal annotations in various
40. unpublished versions of the work, which were erased from the printed version
41. by Pico’s contemporaries, suggest that Pico had already formulated a number of
42. attacks against Ficino’s understanding of what constituted the Neoplatonic tra-
43. dition. These attacks are often referred to as the first Pico-Ficino controversy.35
44. Against his elder contemporary, Pico created his own Neoplatonic system of
45. the world, strongly inspired by astrological interpretations.

17. 2 The Commento alla Canzone d’amore
18.
19. The Commento alla Canzone is Pico’s attempt to interpret a love poem by his
20. friend and colleague Girolamo Benivieni through the lens of the Neoplatonic
21. tradition, which he had learned through Ficino. Marginal annotations in various
22. unpublished versions of the work, which were erased from the printed version
23. by Pico’s contemporaries, suggest that Pico had already formulated a number of
24. attacks against Ficino’s understanding of what constituted the Neoplatonic tra-
25. dition. These attacks are often referred to as the first Pico-Ficino controversy.35
26. Against his elder contemporary, Pico created his own Neoplatonic system of
27. the world, strongly inspired by astrological interpretations. At the centre of
28. mankind, Pico places God, the principle and cause of every divine being.36
29. Pico underlines, against Ficino, the ancient theologians’ Creation (i.e., the one
30. described by Hermes, Zoroaster and the ‘Platonists’) as ‘the Son of God, the
31. Wisdom, the Mind of God’, which had nothing in common with the Christian
32. Jesus.37 The first creation, also called the first intelligence in its turn, had created
33. the rational soul. Warning against Ficino’s comparison between Neoplatonic
34.

36. Antonio Raspanti (Florence: Olschki, 1997).

3. De amore].” Irenically, however, Ficino was one of the influential voices who defended
4. Pico after the banning of the Roman disputation, and he helped Pico to obtain Medici
5. patronage, even writing a letter dated May 30, 1488, on Lorenzo’s behalf inviting Pico

8. “delight,” conduct’s “guide,” and learning’s “master” (disciplinae magister).7 In any
9. event, from the onset Pico had regarded his own commentary notes as preliminary
10. speculations, and he says several times that he is going to write more about various
11. topics in three future treatises: a commentary on the Symposium, a poetic theology, and
12. a love treatise. None of these ever materialized, though he may have been drawing on
13. notes that he had begun to compile for them. Very soon, understandably, he lost interest

23. III. Benivieni too deliberately suppressed Pico’s original version and eventually

27. new book 2, and tided the particular commentary book 3. It seems that, like
28. Gianfrancesco, he and other friends were anxious to conceal the disagreements with
29. Ficino, lest these disagreements and indeed the relationship between the two luminaries
30. be misunderstood. Moreover, since Ficino himself certainly considered the notes
31. replete with youthful errors whose publication would not enhance Pico’s reputation, as
32. he had observed in a letter to Germain de Ganay in Paris dated March 23, 1495,9 the
33. circle of mutual friends may well have agreed with him, particularly if Pico himself had
34. come to acknowledge some errors before he died. More problematically, at the turn of
35. the century, Benivieni, now an ardent and devout piagnone who repented his earlier life
36. as a love poet, cannibalized portions from Pico’s notes when he decided to publish a
37. prose commentary of his own to accompany a selection of a hundred poems, but not,
38. remarkably, the canzone “Amor, dalle cui,” that he had written earlier but had reworked
39. and “reformed” in the light of his new spirituality. This commentary appeared in
40. Florence in 1500 and was entitled Commento di Hieronymo Benivieni sopra a più sue
41. canzone et sonetti dello Amore et della Bellezza divina.10

31. For Renaissance thinkers, myths were the stuff of ancient poetry. Pico,

34. cially in poetry and in the hexameters of such pre-Socratic philosophers
35. as Empedocles and Parmenides. That is, he was committed to poetic the-
36. ologizing on the assumption that the ancient poets and their tales of the
37. gods were a veiled, cryptic unfolding of the fundamentals of religious
38. belief. For Ficino and Pico, the myths indeed constituted a gentile scrip-
39. ture, a scripture revealed, rather than compiled, by a line of ancient the-
40. ologians, and posing much the same kind of hermeneutical challenges
41. as Solomon’s Song of Songs. Collectively they articulated a metaphysics
42. that was almost perfected by Plato (as seen anachronistically through the
43. interpretative eyes of Plotinus) and then truly perfected in Christian the-
44. ology. The Christian-Platonic philosopher was in their eyes the exemplary
45. hermeneut, the interpreter who could interpret correctly the wealth of
46. pre-Christian, non-Hebrew revelation bestowed by a loving God on the
47. many peoples without access either to the laws of Moses or to the Mosaic
48. books of prophecy, the Pentateuch.

Assistant

Pico della Mirandola’s Commento sopra una canzone d’amore (ca. 1486) is one of the most dazzling and difficult works of early Renaissance Platonism. It was written just after the scandal of Pico’s attempted elopement with Margherita of Arezzo, and before his Conclusiones and Oratio. The Commento is his first systematic philosophical text — and, as Michael J. B. Allen notes, “his first laboratory of metaphysics,” written in the form of a commentary on his friend Girolamo Benivieni’s Canzone d’amore【154:17†M. V. Dougherty – Pico della Mirandola†L1-L17】.

I. Background and Form

Pico’s Commento was composed in 1486, at his villa in Fratta near Perugia, while preparing for his grand disputation in Rome. It takes Benivieni’s poem Amor, dalle cui man sospeso è ’l freno / del mio cor pende as its basis. The poem itself summarizes themes from Ficino’s De amore, but Pico uses it as a springboard to build his own philosophical theology of love and intellect【154:17†M. V. Dougherty – Pico della Mirandola†L5-L15】.

The Commento originally existed in three books. Later, Benivieni suppressed references to Ficino and reorganized the text, producing a more devotional, expurgated version in 1500. The complete, unexpurgated version — discovered and edited by Eugenio Garin in 1942 — restores Pico’s combative stance toward Ficino’s interpretation of Plato and gives a truer sense of its intellectual daring【154:0†M. V. Dougherty – Pico della Mirandola†L39-L50】.

II. Central Themes

1. Poetic Theology (Theologia Poetica)


Pico’s Commento is less about love psychology than about poetic theology: the notion that ancient myths and poems conceal philosophical truths. As he writes:
“The ancient theologians, who under poetic veils hid their mysteries, taught divine truths in the form of fables” (Commento, I.3).

Allen describes this as Pico’s commitment to poetic metaphysics: interpreting the myths of Venus, Cupid, and Apollo as allegories of divine intellect and love, “a gentile scripture revealed through inspired poets”【154:16†M. V. Dougherty – Pico della Mirandola†L31-L41】.
Busi and Ebgi emphasize that unlike Landino, Pico does not Christianize the pagan myths but treats them as hieroglyphs of Platonic wisdom:

“The ancient theologians... are seen as a mine of Platonic teaching, and Pico works finely to transform Venuses, Uranias, and Nymphs into degrees of the immaterial world.”【154:5†(I millenni) Giulio Busi & Raphael Ebgi†L19-L27】

2. Love as Ascent to the Angelic Mind


The love described by Benivieni becomes, for Pico, a metaphysical ladder:
  • The lower Venus corresponds to sensual love, rooted in imagination.

  • The celestial Venus symbolizes the angelic intellect, where love and knowledge coincide.

“Through love the soul unites its partial intellect to the universal intellect or angelic mind, the first of creatures and the lodging of ideal beauty.” (Allen’s paraphrase of Commento, bk. II)【154:2†Allen – Studies in the Platonism of Marsilio Ficino and Giovanni Pico†L33-L38】.

In this ascent, eros becomes a function of energeia: the human mind actualizing its divine likeness by moving from potential to act — an early expression of the anthropology Pico will elaborate in the Oratio.

3. Polemic with Ficino


The Commento is also Pico’s first break with Ficino. Akopyan notes that Pico “misses few opportunities to clarify his position on astrology and magic,” attacking Ficino’s “misunderstanding of what constituted the Neoplatonic tradition.” He accuses Ficino of confusing the “First Intellect” — the divine Wisdom of Hermes and Zoroaster — with the Christian Logos:
“The ancient theologians called the First Creation ‘the Son of God, the Wisdom, the Mind of God,’ which had nothing in common with the Christian Jesus.”【154:1†Brill – Debating the Stars in the Italian Renaissance†L17-L31】

This move reflects Pico’s attempt to re-ground Neoplatonism in ancient theology rather than in Ficino’s Christocentric reading.

4. The Unity of Love and Being


Pico’s treatment of love anticipates his metaphysics of De ente et uno. Love is the dynamic expression of divine unity — “that by which the soul returns to the One.” The myth of Venus’s birth from the foam of the sea is read as the emergence of intelligible beauty from the divine abyss. Allen observes that for Pico, “beauty is the radiance of unity perceived in multiplicity” — thus eros becomes an intellectual act, a motion of the mind toward simplicity【154:6†Allen – Studies in the Platonism of Marsilio Ficino and Giovanni Pico†L33-L35】.

III. Style and Tone

Pico’s prose is alternately lyrical and scholastic. Busi notes that even though the Commento was written after the Margherita scandal, it still “glitters with Platonic sensuality” — “a lucente lascivia, Platonic though provocative.” Its language fuses scholastic precision with erotic luminosity, echoing the tension between the philosopher and the lover【154:4†(I millenni) Giulio Busi & Raphael Ebgi†L27-L35】.

IV. Key Quotations (in paraphrase and partial translation)

  • “Amore è figlio di Penia e Poros” — Love is born of poverty and resource, signifying the soul’s yearning toward divine plenitude through lack and intellect (Commento, I.5).

  • “Gli antichi teologi... sotto velamento poetico coprirono i loro misteri” — The poets are the first theologians, veiling divine mysteries in myth (Commento, I.3).

  • “Venere celeste è l’intelletto angelico... nel quale l’anima trova la vera bellezza” — Celestial Venus symbolizes the angelic intellect where beauty dwells.

  • “Apollo è invocato per la eloquenza del vero” — Apollo is not a pagan god but the light of intellectual eloquence, the gift of expressing truth beautifully【154:14†(I millenni) Giulio Busi & Raphael Ebgi†L35-L43】.


V. Philosophical and Historical Importance

The Commento stands at the crossroads of Pico’s intellectual life:

  • It develops the idea of poetic revelation that grounds his later Hermeticism.

  • It anticipates the angelic anthropology of the Oratio and the Heptaplus.

  • It inaugurates the first Ficino–Pico controversy, foreshadowing the debates on creation, astrology, and divine mediation that dominate his Disputationes adversus astrologiam divinatricem.


As Allen concludes:
“The Commento has a rapid-fire brilliance… not a love treatise but an experiment in metaphysical poetics, where myth, theology, and intellect converge”【154:7†M. V. Dougherty – Pico della Mirandola†L28-L36】.

In short: the Commento sopra una canzone d’amore is Pico’s first statement of his philosophical theology — a fusion of Platonic eros, Aristotelian act, and Hermetic revelation — in which poetic beauty becomes the language of metaphysical ascent.

Dante as Piagnone Prophet: Girolamo
Benivieni's "Cantico in laude di Dante" 50

by SHERRY RoUSH

If imitation is the highestform ofpraise, then Girolamo Benivieni's canto describing his

otherworldly encounter with Dante's spirit is certainly a tribute to the author of the Divine

Comedy. Despite its title, however, Benivienis project is not simply epideictic. In it, Benivieni

represents Dante in a highly anachronistic way, as a kind ofspokesman for the piagnoni, the
ardent supporters of Girolamo Savonarolas program Of moral austerity and Florentine republican
politics between the 1490s and the first decades of the Cinquecento. This study argues that
Benivieni articulates his controversial, ideological vision in a necessarily prudent way by
appropriating Dante as a safe and authoritative cultural icon and adopting a deliberately
ambiguous symbolic language, which lauds himse4Fand hispolitics as much as it does Dante.

he 1506 edition of Dante's Divine Comedy is the only Florentine pro-
duction of the complete work between 1481 and 1595.1 Like its 1481

predecessor with its tour-de-force of patriotic and allegorical interpretation
by Cristoforo Landino, the 1506 edition appears to have an agenda of civic
promotion at its heart. However, its frame implicitly exalts not a Medicean
and mythologized Florence, but one favorably influenced in the intervening
1490s by Girolamo Savonarola's zealous call to radical repentance, the copi-
ous weeping for which earned his followers the designation piag-noni. What
is striking is how the worles editor articulates this new civic vision in the edi-
tion's proem: as a prophecy received directly from the spirit of Dante. This
proem, entitled the "Cantico in laude di Dante" (Canticle in Praise of
Dante) by Girolamo Benivieni (1453-1542), is a 199-line poem in terza

2 rima in evident imitation of a Dantesque canto. In it Benivieni relates a
dream in which he finds himself transported to the Earthly Paradise where
he meets the spirit of Dante. Dante speaks about the motivation behind his
voyage through hell, purgatory, and paradise, about the mistreatment of his
Comedy by other editors, and about the Florence of Benivieni's own time.
Dante's spirit then proclaims the uncharacteristic Savonarolan prophecy,
bringing to a close a composition that is clever, learned, and decidedly
Polemical.

The "Cantico" does much more than introduce the text of the Comedy
or merely praise Dante, as its title suggests. It embodies microscopically and

50 RENAISSANCE QUARTERLY

with great subtlety larger questions concerning the contemporary political
implications of poetic interpretation. 3 The present study aims to explore
how the 1506 Comed.ys editor negotiates in his "Cantico" a poetic-critical
position in the face of pro-Medicean cultural ties and the fiercely Republi-
can moral reforms of Savonarola's legacy. By putting his vision of Florentine
civic direction in Dante's mouth, Benivieni appropriates Dante's authority
to promote what is in the first years of the sixteenth century a risky ideolog-
ical position.

History has not smiled on Benivieni. Although his development as an
author closely parallels that of a Sandro Botticelli in art, and despite the fact
that when Benivieni edits Dante's masterpiece he could confidently claim

,,4 the distinction of the "foremost living Florentine vernacular poet, Benivi
eni remains a relatively obscure figure today. Benivieni came to cultural
prominence as a teenager, becoming one of the shining stars of Lorenzo de'
Medici's intellectual circle. He delighted the company with his astonishing
ability to recite poems composed spontaneously and played the viol, earning
for himself the nickname of the "Other Orpheus. 15 A life-threatening illness
in 1470 prevented him from continuing a regular course of study. Nonethe-
less, he developed and flourished in the company of leading humanists and
members of the Florentine Platonic Academy, including Marsilio Ficino,
Angelo Poliziano, and Pandolfo Collenuccio. Benivieni surpassed many of
his peers, especially in the study of Hebrew. 6 In the late 1470s and early
1480s he circulated his own version of the popular, Petrarch-indebted love
lyrics. Benivieni also cast a Boccaccian novella in verse and published well-
received pastoral poems. After his spiritual conversion, prompted by the fi-
ery sermons of the Dominican preacher Girolano Savonarola (1452-98),
Benivieni went on to translate a number of Savonarola's works and to corn-

pose the lauds that the Florentine populace sang in some of the 1496 and
1497 religious processions.

Unlike Cristoforo Landino, a teacher at the Florentine Studio and lec-
turer on Dante before he prepared the 1481 edition of the Divine Comedy,
Benivieni seems to have possessed unusual qualifications as an editor of
Dante. However, it is possible that by 1506 Benivieni had already earned a
reputation for a profound knowledge of Dante as well. This reputation
likely did not derive from any specifically critical or expository study on
Dante, but rather from his Commento di Hieronymo Benivieni sopra apii sue
canzone et sonetti dello Amore et delta Belleza Divina (Commentary by Giro-
larno Benivieni on Some of his own Songs and Sonnets on Love and Divine
Beauty), published for the first time in 1500. just as Matteo Palmieri (1406-
75), for instance, by basing the form and content of his Cit of Life on Y
Dante's Comedy gained a particular estimation as a dantista, so might have
Benivieni with his Commentary.

Benivieni's Commentary and Dante's Comedy are quite different in tone,
genre, and intent. Nevertheless, Benivieni shows his debt to Dante in the
Commentary's narration of the Soul's narrow escape from the whirlpool of
damnation to the arrival at the heavenly Jerusalem. Benivieni's work consists
of precisely I 00 self-glossed lyric poems, divided into three parts, reflecting
Dante's 100 cantos in three canticles. The three parts of the Commentary
correspond roughly to the poet's fall, repentance, and reascension in God's
grace. During the course of the Commentary, moreover, we encounter signif-
icant references to some of Dante's most recognizable characters, including
Francesca da Rimini and Ulysses, and to Dantesque treatments of such con-
cepts as memory and exile.' Benivieni's stature as a Dante imitator, his
prominence as a cultural figure in the Medici circle and as a popular civic
poet in his own right, may all have contributed to his role as editor of the
Co m edy.

The earlier Florentine edition of Dante's work is a crucial point of refer-
ence for Benivieni's work. Landino dedicates a large part of his proem to
trumpeting Florence's best qualities and extolling her most notable citizens,
including those who excel in doctrine, eloquence, music, and art. His
lengthy treatment of the divinefuror of the true poeta-vates presents a verita-
ble manifesto of Platonic Academy poetics, while promoting its
((magnificent" patron, Lorenzo de' Medici. In uncovering the supposed hid-
den significances of Dante's poetry, Landino's interpretation actually makes
Dante a hero for the ideals of Medicean Florence (Lentzen, 41-42).

'A more detailed examination of Benivieni's imitation in the Commentary of Dante's
masterpiece appears in the fourth chapter of Roush, forthcoming.

52 RENAISSANCE QUARTERLY

In fact, one of Landino's primary concerns, as evidenced from his dedi-
catory oration, lies in asserting the superiority of Florentine culture and
language, "This alone I affirm: to have liberated your citizen [Dante] from
the barbarisms of many foreign phrases, by which his work had been cor-
rupted by commentators."' Landino marshals proof for Florence's linguistic
preeminence by pointing out that all Italian writers worthy to be called such
have forced themselves to use Tuscan. He spurns subtlety in conjoining lin-
guistic and patriotic or political interests, "Nor did I judge [it] the task of a

good citizen to investigate with diligence in thepreface ofthis book thepraises
ofsuch apoet, but I also join with those praises the honorable virtues of our
Republic."' In the way he edits the Comedy and promotes the Florentine ver-
nacular, Landino responds directly to editorial decisions made by non-
Florentine editors of the Comedy in the 1470s, especially by Martino Paolo
Nidobeato in the 1478 Milanese edition. 10

Twenty-five years after Landino's effort, Benivieni faces the same task.
In the "Cantico," Dante's spirit asks Benivieni to restore his lyre, that is to
re-edit the Divine Comedy after foreigners with ears deaf to the Florentine

language have attempted to revise the poem and judge it on linguistic
grounds. The primary target of Benivieni's critical blow is the 1502 Venetian
edition, edited by Pietro Bembo (1470-1547). Bembo's edition, published
by Aldus Manutius, proves to be a formidable adversary. Bembo, with his
revolutionary return to Boccaccio's manuscript (Vat. Lat. 3199, which Be-
mbo's father had in his personal library), helps to establish a new way of

reading the Comedy as a classic text and as an artifact worthy of philological
scrutiny. But Benivieni is ultimately more concerned with arguing the pri-
macy of the Comedys ethical value over its linguistic one. The civic concerns

DANTE AS PIAGNONE PROPHET 53

at stake in Landino's poetic project return in Benivieni's own proemial
"Cantico," but in the service of a very different Florence."

The following sections present three approaches from which to consider
the ideological import of the 1506 edition of the Comedy as it is presented in
the "Cantico." The first examines how Benivieni establishes his poetic and
prophetic authority. He does this by recontextualizing recognizable passages
from the Comedy so as to make them appear to speak directly to the early six-
teenth-century Florentine situation. At the same time, Benivieni attempts to
write himself into literary history as the direct poetic descendent of Dante.
The second part examines the "Cantico's" final prophecy spoken by Dante's
spirit. At the heart of the issue is the prophecy's deliberately ambiguous and
mysterious mode of expression. The issue of necessary ambiguity in the sec-
ond section leads to the third part, which sketches the political situation in
Florence at the time. Benivieni manages to communicate his vision of a New
Florence while avoiding the harsh punishments meted out to more explicit
piagnone commentators. Moreover, while Benivieni ostensibly praises
Dante, he also has Dante praise piagnone Florence, with auspicious personal
and civic consequences.

The "Cantico in laude di Dante" divides neatly into two parts. The first
(lines 1-75) describes the scene of Benivieni's dream narrative in the Earthly
Paradise, while the second part (lines 76-199) consists of the dialogue be-
tween the two characters, Dante's spirit and Benivieni the pilgrim. Benivieni
chooses language and subject matter that clearly call to the reader's mind
specific and vivid situations from the Divine Comedy. He opens his "Can-
tico, in fact, by emulating Dante's tendency in the Comedy to record the
temporal setting of his narrative by means of a mythological periphrasis. It is
the hour in which Phoebus Apollo pulls his chariot with flaming wheels out
of the east and begins to ascend the steep path across the sky. Benivieni un-
derscores the fact that it is sunrise by speaking of Aurora presenting herself
on the balcony of the East: "Thus the adorned daughter of Tithonus, having

" Benivieni continues to evoke Landino's example by including in the 1506 edition a
"Dialogo circa il sito, la forma, e le misure dell'Inferno di Dante" (Dialogue on the Site, Form,
and Dimensions of Dante's Inferno). See Manetti. In the 1481 edition, in fact, Landino offers
a discourse on the "Sito, forma e misura dello 'Nferno e statura de' giganti e di Lucifero. " Be-
nivieni in the 1506 "Dialogo" honors his deceased friend Antonio di Tuccio Manetti (1423-
97) by reassembling Manetti's notes on the Comedys first canticle. Benivieni thus frames his
text of the Comedy in such a way as to call explicitly to mind Landino's edition. However, Be-
nivieni also makes a point of showing his independence from his predecessor by underscoring
the places in which he corrects and revises Landino's earlier assertions on the subject.

Benivieni describes the sunrise by noting that the steep path that
Apollo's solar chariot follows is the one along which the god's excessively
daring son, Phaeton, had lost control of the reins (line 6). By referring to
Phaeton's fate at the outset of his own project, Benivieni subtly recognizes
the possibility of his own presumption. Phaeton represents the mortal hu-
man being of limited capacities whose pride prompts an attempt at an
undertaking that only an immortal can successfully complete. Dante in the
Comedy has his own confrontations with the Phaeton myth, most memora-
bly during his flight atop Geryon (Inf. 17-107).

notion at the close of the "Cantico" (lines 196-98) when he describes Dante
as the bright light that he is unable to sustain.'5 Benivieni may also be sug-

DANTE AS PIAGNONE PROPHET 55

gesting that his possibility of earning Apollo's symbolic laurel for poetry
comes through Dante, both his verse and his spirit.' 6

That Benivieni presumes to take the reins of Dante's light proves even
more intriguing if we remember why Phaeton asks Apollo for permission to
drive the solar chariot in the first place. In Ovid's version of the myth, Pha-
eton seeks Apollo's permission to conduct the chariot only after being
goaded by one of his peers who insinuates a doubt that Apollo is really Pha-
eton's father. In other words, Phaeton's flight should represent the proof of
genealogy - an issue that Dante takes up not by chance during his dialogue
with his own ancestor Cacciaguida in Par. 17.1-3 - but also in spiritual and
poetic terms. In particular, the genealogy is set up poetically by allusion to
Virgil's episode of the encounter between Aeneas and Anchisis in the Elysian
Fields. Benivieni thus attempts to extend an already established poetic gene-
alogy that passes from Virgil to Dante and to write himself into literary
history by claiming to be Dante's direct poetic descendent.

The "Cantico" dream's physical setting closely resembles Dante's
Earthly Paradise at the summit of Purgatory. Benivieni states that the locus
amoenus of his dream seems to him that which Eve lost ("quel che perdett'
Eva." line 18). Instead of the lone presence of a Matelda figure, however, a
chorus of nine women whom he will subsequently identify as the Muses
(line 109) appears to Benivieni. These ladies sing among the flowers in the
shade of the laurel tree and make, among other adornments, a crown for
Dante's honored brow (line 69). Benivieni goes on to identify Dante's spirit
in the "Cantico" with Virgil's in the Comedy when the Muses announce the
presence of Dante's apparition with the exclamation, "Honor the great Poet"
(line 57). These are precisely the same words used to greet Virgil in Dante's
Limbo: "Honor the great Poet! His shade

Two Poems on Spiritual Renewal

G I R O L A M O B E N I V I E N I

Well-versed in both Greek and Hebrew, a self-taught musician and a scholar of Dante,
Girolamo Benivieni (1453—1542) distinguished himself as a gifted poet, eliciting the
attention of Lorenzo de' Media's group of scholars. Already in his early twenties, he
started to frequent the Medicean circle and demonstrate his poetic talent. His composi-
tions followed the prevailing models of the time, especially those of Lorenzo and Po-
liziano, whose influence, together with that of the bucolic poets of antiquity, is clearly
discernible in Benivieni's eclogues.

A turning point in Benivieni's life came in 1479, when he met Giovanni Pico della Mi-
randola in Florence. The closejriendship that Benivieni developed with the count of Mirán-
dola inspired him to abandon his role as a court poet and to devote himself entirely to study-
ing Neoplatonism and producing philosophical poems. The Canzona delTamor celeste
e divino, commented on by Pico himself, is a good example of his work at this time.

This mystical strain in Benivieni was strengthened by the influence of Savonarola
beginning in the late 14805. Benivieni went so far as to repudiate his previous composi-
tions as too worldly and soon became one of the most passionate followers of the spiritual
renewal promoted in Florence at the time. Benivieni became in effect the official translator
of Savonarola's texts, and in 1496 he translated Savonarola's treatise De simplicitate
Christianae vitae into the vernacular and the Epístola delTumiltà/row the vernacular
into Latin.

Savonarola's tragic downfall did not break Benivieni's fervent spirit, although events

271Brought to you by | The University of Texas at Austin
Authenticated

Download Date | 7/6/19 1:15 AM

G I R O L A M O B E N I V I E N I

forced him to limit his open support of the Piagnoni ("Waiters"), the faction most faithful
to the Dominicanfriar. This, however, did not stop Benivienifrom publishing a commen-
tary on his own Savonarolan works, two poems of which we include here. Always
adhering to the rigid tenets of Savonarola's teaching, Benivieni devoted the last years of
his life to revising and publishing his writing. He tried in vain to convince Duke Ales-
sandro de* Medici to erect a mausoleum for Pico della Mirándola in San Marco, but he
was granted his wish to have his own body buried next to his friend's in the Dominican
church where the great philosopher lay.

Some ofBenivieni's most interesting works, like the two poems translated here into
prose, date from the final years of Savonarola's life. The first is a canzone composed for
the procession ofthefanciulli on Palm Sunday 1496, which Benivieni himself sang in the
cathedral of Florence. The second was written for a bonfire of vanities during Lent on
February 7, 1497. Both poems attempt to express the destiny of the Florentine people

according to Savonarola's visions: that Florence, "the city of God," "the new Jerusalem,"

would become the capital of a moral cleansing that would dramatically affect the entire
world. Since Benivieni commented on his own poems, we include a number of his
explanatory notes (though not all of them) to help elucidate passages that may be unclear
or particularly important. Benivieni himself reports having slightly altered the second

>poem after Savonarola's execution, to emphasize the prophet's saintliness. Benivieni's
notes are those beginning with a phrase in italics.

Source: Girolamo Benivieni, Commente sopra a più sue canzoni et sonetti dello amore et délia

bellezza divina (Florence: Tubini, 1500), fols. 11 iv-i I4v and ι I7v-i2ov.

THE Y E A R 1496 OF OUR S A L V A T I O N

Long live Florence in our hearts, long live Florence, long live Christ your king,
and long live the spouse, His daughter, and mother,1 who is queen and guide,
for it is thanks to their bounty and clemency that the day is nearing in which
this city shall be made richer, more powerful, and more glorious than ever
before. Such a promise or inestimable gift can never be in vain, since it is not a
human tongue that utters it, but divine bounty.

O city more fortunate than all others, you are certainly more fortunate
than anyone would believe, and perhaps even more than you yourself could
think or hope. Although those who do not know you may deem that all hon-

You certainly can, my dear Florence, in the midst of your torments, expect

every land, attracted by the scent of the holy Uly.

Your sweet Uly will stretch its petals beyond the borders of your reign,

veil;6 amid great stupor, all your glory will then finally shine forth.

either remain inside my heart and enjoy only your own company, or, if you
choose to leave, appear only in those places where people who see with our
eyes can be found.8

BENIVIENI E PICO

Un ruolo importante nella vita personale ed intellettuale di Giovanni Pico
della Mirandola (e nella composizione di uno dei suoi scritti maggiori) lo ebbe il

poeta fiorentino Girolamo Benivieni (1453-1542)1. Noto ai tempi di Pico come
autore di rime neoplatoniche e classicheggianti (pi? tardi invece si sarebbe dedi
cato a produrre canti religiosi, opuscoli danteschi, commenti in prosa ed epistole
spirituali), era uno dei seguaci e difensori del Savonarola e fu tra i primi con cui
Pico si associ? al momento del suo arrivo a Firenze. Il giovane conte mirando
lano, pur essendo il beniamino dell'intellighenzia fiorentina di quel periodo,
ammirato e amato da molti compresi Ficino e Poliziano, si leg? in modo parti
colare al Benivieni. Insieme non solo parteciparono alle attivit? culturali che si

svolgevano nel circolo laurenziano e tra gli studiosi che si riunivano nella biblio
teca di San Marco, ma collaborarono per effettuare notevoli opere di carit?. Per
via della sua integrit? morale e del grand'affetto che manifestava per Pico, il
Benivieni venne incaricato della distribuzione di elemosine a nome dell'amico,
come attesta sia egli stesso nonch? Gian Francesco, nipote e biografo del Miran
dolano2. Durante le assenze di Pico che spesso lasciava Firenze per intrappren
dere dei viaggi, il Benivieni deve aver sentito una forte nostalgia per lui se gli
indirizz? diversi sonetti in cui si lamenta allegoricamente della mancanza del
sole3. Introdusse Pico in altre opere pure, come interlocutore nella settima egloga
e quale protagonista nel commento alla seconda egloga reinterpretata come

espressione dell'affetto che il poeta aveva per lui4.

La loro amicizia, diventata addirittura leggendaria, si esalt? romanzesca

maestro greco. Ambientata nella villa medicea dove presiede Lorenzo il Magni
fico, maestosamente seduto, alla lezione assistono Ficino e altre dodici persone.
Fra queste si riconoscono anche Benivieni e Pico6, le figure che occupano prati
camente il centro del dipinto in una posa significativa, una mano del poeta bruno
sulla spalla del giovane filosofo biondo, l'altra sul suo braccio.

Testimonianze altrettanto eloquenti della loro stima reciproca e degli inte
ressi intellettuali condivisi vengono fornite dai rispettivi scritti. Nel trattato con
tro l'astrologia, Pico chiama Benivieni ?acuto vir ingenio et perspicaci?7 e
accenna a una discussione avvenuta tra loro due a proposito del possibile
influsso delle stelle sulla vita terrestre - idea respinta da Pico ma che in un primo

breve accenno, vi ? un vero inno al Benivieni in una delle composizioni poetiche
di Pico scampate alla distruzione voluta dall'autore. Si tratta dell'elegia in latino
dedicata a Firenze che consta di un encomio del poeta, detto un nuovo Orfeo che,
componendo liriche e cantandole alla cetra, fa onore alla citt?8.

Da canto suo, il Benivieni ricambi? i complimenti e le effusioni sentimentali
in vari modi. Stese una lettera nel 1515 per difendere la memoria di Pico e in

quell'occasione si autodefin? ?uno armario di tutti e' suoi secreti?9. Per dimo
strare che lo conosceva a fondo asser? che ?et d? et nocte ero continuamente

apresso di lui ?, raccontando per di pi? che andavano a cavallo insieme la sera.

Scopo precipuo dell'epistola, per?, era di rispondere alle accuse che erano state
fatte a Pico sospettato di aver praticato la magia nera. L'epistola spiega che, in
verit?, Pico derideva tali cose ma faceva uso della Cabala invece come metodo

loda entusiasticamente il Magnifico letterato dichiarandolo superiore sia a Dante
che a Petrarca -, rimane inattaccabile il fatto del profondo affiatamento fra il
filosofo brillante e il poeta serio. Il Benivieni rivela nel Commento che era rima
sto depresso dopo la morte deiramico e questo suo stato d'animo fu esagerato
pi? tardi dal Salviati e altri scrittori cinquecenteschi che lo raffigurarono come
tendente al suicidio16. In ogni modo il Benivieni si prodig? per il compagno
scomparso. Scrisse dei sonetti in persona di Pico che chiedeva migliore sepoltura
e riusc? a far trasportare i resti di lui all'interno di San Marco17. Qui, al momento
della propria morte a ottantanove anni, fu seppellito nella stessa tomba, sulla

quale venne incisa l'iscrizione che aveva preparato. Esprimeva il suo fervido
