Content Snippet:
1. The soul’s pure intellectual vision depends of course on a theory of the soul’s ascent
2. and necessarily on the role of its highest faculty and on the corresponding theory of the
3. Ideas seen by that faculty. So let us turn now to Pico’s presentation of Platonic
4. psychology in the Commento, which is keyed, interestingly, to being and not, as in
5. Ficino, to unity – though we should note that Pico is clearly indebted to the third book of
6. Ficino’s Platonic Theology and its exploration of God’s attributes, including God’s
7. role in our understanding. The Commento begins with an ontological preoccupation by
8. distinguishing among causal, formal, and participated being as a fundamental Platonic
9.
10.
11.
12. postulate and by defining God not as being per se but as the cause of being and not as an
13. intellect per se but as the source and cause of all intellect.27 This leads Pico from the
14. onset to challenge the reaction of amazement by “un gran platonico” (clearly Ficino) to
15. a passage in Plotinus’s Enneads (5.6.3 or 6.7.37) in which God is said to understand
16. nothing and to castigate him for not realizing that Plotinus merely intended that “the
17. attribute of understanding exists in God in its causal not formal being [secondo quello
18. essere causale e non secondo quello formate].”28 This is demonstrably polemical.
19. Ficino was well grounded in the intricacies of negative theology, the theology that
20. denies the possibility of talking about God except in equivocal terms, and he was to
21. devote some considerable time eventually to commenting on the works of the Dionysius
22. the Areopagite, “the prince of Christian theologians” for him as for Pico,29 especially
23. On the Divine Names. Even more significantly perhaps, he was to compose his longest
24. Plato commentary on the Areopagite’s ultimate source and inspiration, the second part
25. of Plato’s Parmenides, where Plato has the aging Eleatic explore inter alia the
26. consequences that would ensue were the One not to exist.30 Therefore, Ficino, if amazed
27. at all, as Pico claimed, must have been amazed not at the notion that God cannot be said
28. to understand anything in the way we or even the angels understand (for this was an
29. apophatic argument with which he was wholly familiar) but rather at its role in the
30. particular passage in Plotinus.
31.
32. One of Pico’s most interesting contributions in the Commento is, I would argue, his
33. account of the three hypostases, particularly of the second, which the ancient
34. Neoplatonists had identified with Mind but which he identifies with Angel or Angelic
35. Mind. Some of the Neoplatonists had maintained that between the first hypostasis, God
36. or the One or the Good, and the third hypostasis, the World Soul, came a host of
37. intelligible and intellectual creatures whom Christians call the “angels”31 – and here
38. Pico reveals his medievalism, since Plotinus had spoken simply of Soul and had argued
39. that the World-Soul is the first instance of this generic Soul.

1. 4 Pico announces this theme in the Oration and in the first of the 900 theses according
2. to his own opinion: “There is no natural or divine question in which Aristotle and Plato
3. do not agree in meaning and substance, although in their words they seem to disagree”
4. (1>1) (Conclusions, 365). For a sustained argument against any single framework of

8. 5 Dulles, Princeps Concordiae, 131. Unlike the highly polished rhetorical character of the
9. Oration, Pico employs the language and style of scholasticism in the 900 theses set out in his
10. Conclusions (1486). Prefaced by the Oration, the Conclusions is divided into approximately
11. 400 historical theses drawn from major philosophers of the Latin, Arabic, Peripatetic,
12. and Platonic “nations” in addition to the “most ancient” nations (Pythagorean, Chaldean,
13. Hermetic, and Cabalistic), followed by almost 500 theses according to his own opinion.
14. S. A. Farmer provides charts outlining all the theses in Syncretism in the West (204–7). It is
15. tempting, but dubious, to take all of the historical theses to represent Pico’s own view. On
16. interpreting the historical theses, Farmer asserts that “[t]o reconstruct Pico’s views in this
17. part of the text, all topically related theses must be collated with the last 500 theses, given
18. ‘according to his own opinion’” (204). Many scholars, including Dulles and Cassirer, rely
19. inappropriately on historical theses alone to furnish Pico’s own opinions.

24. 9780521847360c08 CUFX160/Dougherty 0 521 84736 2 July 26, 2007 15:27
25.
26. Pico’s Quest for All Knowledge 181
27.
28. following terms: if the human being is a creature capable of actualizing
29. every archetype within its being, does it follow for Pico that human beings
30. are capable of attaining every kind of knowledge? If Pico is approached
31. from the vantage point of his medieval predecessors, one might hold
32. with the scholastics that there are intrinsic limits on human knowledge
33. rooted in human nature itself, particularly the dependence of all intellec-
34. tual cognition on sensory perception. As Aristotle said, with far-reaching
35. effects, “the soul never thinks without an image.”6 For Aquinas, this had
36. meant that there could be no direct cognition or “vision” of God or any
37. spiritual being by a human knower while still in this life, which is to say by
38. virtue of natural human powers.7 Consequently, all realities whose level
39. of being exceed that of the human being have to be translated into the
40. mode of human knowing. Human beings, then, unable ever to become
41. purely spiritual intelligences, can only approximate the angelic mode of
42. knowing in rare moments of immediate intellectual intuition, as when
43. grasping first principles or intuiting the essence of a perceived object.
44. Yet if Pico’s human being is the creature that has no fixed nature, one
45. might expect that Pico stands the scholastic paradigm on its head: where
46. there is no determinate nature, there can be no natural limits.

【6†(Variorum Collected Studies 1063) Allen, MichaelJ. B - Studies in the Platonism of Marsilio Ficino and Giovanni Pico-Routledge (2017).pdf†file_00000000fcd861f5a5ba052b21a2d693】

Content Snippet:
1. Plotinus was responding to the ««mystery» in the Odyssey 11.601–604 and ff., where
2. Homer sings of Odysseus’s encounter in Hades with the shade (eidôlon) of Herakles:
3. whereas the lionskinned hero had gone to feast with his father and the other gods, this
4. terrifying idolous phantom had been left to be in a way the Herakles below,
5. «surrounded by the dead crying like affrighted birds».
6.
7. Now as a general principle, Plotinus refused to believe that the soul had ever
8. descended in its entirety into matter.62 Rather, here in this material world we live a
9. double life among the shadows, as Plato had so memorably set forth in the Republic’s
10. parable of the Cave. In glossing this passage, Plotinus therefore argues that there are
11. two Herakles’s possessed respectively of two kinds of soul. In 4.3.27 and 32 he says
12. that the authentic feasting Herakles on Olympus possessed the ‘higher’ soul which soon
13. began to forget the deeds it had performed on earth and its life here; but that the
14. terrifying shade in Hades possessed ‘a lower’ soul which clung to its memories much
15. longer.63 This subtle Plotinian exeg esis, complementary as it is to the references to the
16. two Hades’s in the Phaedo and Cratylus, therefore served as an exemplary guide for
17. Ficino, and presumably for a Neoplatonizing Pico also. It taught both of them to
18. interpret certain key mythological or legendary figures that appear in the Platonic
19. dialogues in a double, essentially antithetical way that calls radically into question who
20. the figures really are and what they signify both to the ordinary multitude and to the
21. initiated few.
22.
23. Be that as it may, whereas Orpheus had believed, so the revisionist Phaedran-
24. Medicean argument went, that in order to gaze upon Eurydice again he had to descend
25. into darkness, Plato and his disciples knew to the contrary that any true philosopher had
26. to ascend into the light of heaven in order to see her as the very breadth of judgment, as
27.
28.
29.
30. the luminous principles by which we judge. And there indeed he could claim her, not as
31. an infernal, but as a supernal bride.
32.
33. The interpretation of Pico is equally unexpected. In his gloss on Benivieni’s fourth
34. stanza in the third book of his Commento,64 he went so far as to argue that Orpheus had
35. been unwilling to die in order to pursue his beloved «because he had been made soft
36. and weak by his own music», the music, he adds enigmatically, that had been taught him
37. by the very same serpent that had stung Eurydice. That is, the serpent had prevented
38. Orpheus from dying for love by making him into a musician (though the chronology of
39. this escapes me)! By way of partial clarification, Pico asserts that the poet had
40. succumbed to his imagination; and this had led him down to Hades to beg for a fantastic
41. or imaginary Eurydice, the insubstantial wraith, the eidolon of his beloved. Instead, he
42. should have cut himself off, Pico argues, from the functioning of his lower faculties, and
43. summoned his intellect to wing its way upwards to heaven in order to gaze upon the
44. authentic Eurydice in the midst of the intelligible Ideas.65

18.
19. The Active Intellect
20.
21. In Ficino’s Christian Platonic universe, the angelic mind is the home of
22. being, whereas Pico distinguishes between formal being in the angelic
23. mind, and the locations of causal and participatory being. For both Ficino
24. and Pico, the angelic mind is also Plato’s world of forms or ideas, and the
25. intellectual and intelligible world—the place of divine mind and under-
26. standing (at least Hokmah and Binah, and potentially Keter too, in the
27. Kabbalistic scheme).
28.
29. But Pico reorganizes Ficino’s hierarchy of forms or understands them
30. in a different way, for instance beauty becomes a subspecies of the good.
31. Further, the concept of a world of forms is problematic from an Aris-
32. totelian perspective. The Platonic world of forms contains the universals
33. from which every particularity derives (e.g. the idea of beauty rather than
34. the particular beautiful object). Plato argues that we recognize beauty in
35. its particular form (a beautiful person or thing) because there is a universal
36. or form, Beauty, much as we all recognize a particular circle because we
37. are connecting that particular, probably mathematically inaccurate circle
38. with the universal form of a Circle that actually exists. The world of
39. forms is real in a way that our world is not…. We are in a cave watching
40. shadows of the real on the rockface. Our senses, as the part of ourselves
41. most closely connected to the world of matter, lie to us all the time, so
42. we cannot use the evidence of our senses to deduce the existence of a
43. universal from a particular example (the idea of beauty from a particular
44. beautiful object). But we understand that a particular object is beautiful,
45. because we already carry within us an understanding of what beauty is….
46. These universals are in the world closest to the One, as universals must
47. be the first things emanated: the most perfect (unified) of things, the
48. abstract concepts, before the emanative process multiplies into particular-
49. ities. Just as Plato requires a world of forms where the forms (or ideas)
50. exist, Christianity requires an angelic world created by God. Christian
51. Platonists, such as St Augustine and Ficino put the two together.
52.
53. Aristotle starts from the particular. We see particular things in the mate-
54. rial world and then we abstract from the particular. We do so by using the
55.
56.
57.
58. 154 S. HOWLETT
59.
60. ‘active intellect’ (intellectus agens).

43. passage in Plotinus.

1. It may be added
2. that just as every virtue of the heavens (as Avicenna writes) is conveyed
3. to earth by the vehicle of light, so every virtue of the soul, which we
4. have called heaven, every power – life, motion, and sense – joins and is
5. transferred into this earthly body, which we have called earth, through
6. the medium of the luminous spirit.’78
7.
8. Immortality of the Soul
9.
10. Pico’s soul/body corresponds with the different worlds of the emanated
11. universe, from the intelligence and the supracelestial world to the senses
12. and the world of nature. We can symbolically or even literally become part
13. of each world depending on whether we live in our sense, our reason, or
14. look upward toward God. Of course, the question of literal ‘becoming’
15. is also reliant on the larger issue of the immortality of the soul which was
16. an open question in Pico’s time. Ficino insists on the immortality of the
17. soul in Theologia platonica de immortalitate animorum, following Plato,
18. who uses the argument of affinity in the Phaedo: as the soul can know
19. the ideas, it must be like them, that is eternal and incorporeal.79 Aristotle
20. was ambiguous, seeing the intellect as incorruptible but confusingly not
21. clearly part of the individual soul. Alexander of Aphrodisias refers to the
22. third book of Aristotle’s De anima80 arguing that the active intellect is
23. outside the individual soul, leaving the soul as mortal. Averroes removes
24. all that could be considered immortal or incorruptible within our souls.
25.
26.
27.
28. 182 S. HOWLETT
29.
30. We are simply connecting with the immortal intellect when we perform
31. an abstraction.81
32.
33. Immortality was not official church doctrine,82 and was not adopted
34. as such until the Council of Trent in 1545, though the Lateran Council
35. of 1512 began the process by denouncing the Averroist perspective.
36. The idea of an immortal soul came from the Church Fathers, not the
37. gospels, headed by Augustine who used Plato’s argument of affinity.83
38.
39. Ficino’s defense of the immortality of the soul, following the Byzan-
40. tine philosopher, George Gemistus Pletho, is ‘a conscious reaction against
41. later medieval thought, a reaction that would quite properly claim to be a
42. fight in the name of Plato (and of Augustine) against Aristotle or, at least,
43. against his commentators.’84 In his consistent attempt to try and bridge
44. the Aristotelian and Platonic traditions, Pico is left potentially needing to
45. bridge Averroism with the immortality of the soul, but this argument was
46. left unmade.85
47.
48. Pico discusses the question early in his Commentary as a debate among
49. Platonists, but only as to which parts of the soul are mortal and which
50. immortal: ‘Proclus and Porphyry will have it that only the rational part
51. is immortal and all the others are corruptible. Xenocrates and Speusippus
52. make the sensitive part immortal also. Numenius and Plotinus, adding
53. even the vegetative part, conclude every soul to be immortal.’86 Pico
54. essentially follows Ficino’s deeply held belief in our immortality. For
55. instance, he places us as subject to providence rather than to fate (fate
56. only rules that which exists in space and time whereas our souls are incor-
57. poreal).

1. Phantasy in Ficino can lead you astray
2. just like the senses.72 Pico’s phantasy might be the common sense (‘the
3. inner sense which philosophers call the phantasy.’73) The potential lack
4. of a deceptive imagination in Pico is however suggestive. Ficino considers
5. the physical world, as brought to us by our senses, to be deceptive (Plato’s
6. cave). The ‘real’ world is beyond, in the world of forms. For Aristotle, the
7. senses provide the particulars from which we derive universals. They give
8. us parts of the truth. We use our common sense to classify what we sense,
9. and then take it on to the imagination,74 examine with our reason, and so
10. on upward through the soul. The intelligible is abstracted by our active
11. (activated) intellects from the sensible world (phantasmata).
12.
13. If the intellect is the Aristotelian active intellect, then Pico’s intel-
14. lect, once activated, has a far stronger role than Ficino’s which tends
15. to reflect somewhat passively the divine. Ficino’s distinction between the
16. imagination and deceptive phantasy would also disappear. Epistemolog-
17. ical concerns—what we can know, and how we can know it—become
18. far more central in Pico’s philosophy in his effort to amalgamate Aris-
19. totelianism with other traditions. We make the effort of will to become
20. what we wish to be, using the degree of freedom granted to us by God’s
21. grace, but it is an effort of will based on knowledge. We are also poten-
22. tially caught in a trap: we must understand in order to act, but potentially
23. we cannot understand (take from the particular to the universal) until we
24. are illuminated.
25.
26. The senses are the lowest part of the soul. Connecting body and soul
27. is spirit. The soul itself is a circle and a ‘heaven’ ‘for Aristotle calls the
28. heaven a self-moving living being, and our soul (as the Platonists prove)
29. is a self-moving substance.’ When the reason looks upward and joins with
30.
31.
32.
33. 6 THE WAY HOME 181
34.
35. the intellect, then the heavenly vehicle’s motion is ‘perfectly circular.’75
36.
37. Further ‘Heaven is a circle, and the soul is also a circle, or rather, as
38. Plotinus writes, heaven is a circle because its soul is a circle. Heaven moves
39. in an orbit; a rational soul, going from causes to effects and returning
40. again from effects to causes, revolves through an orbit of reasoning.’76 If
41. the soul is heaven, then the body is earth ‘because it is an earthy and heavy
42. substance. Made from dirt (humus) as Moses writes, it gave its name to
43. man (homo).’77 There is then a link between the earth of the body and the
44. heaven of the soul as something needs to join these very different natures
45. ‘to this task was assigned that delicate and airy body which physicians and
46. philosophers call the spirit and which Aristotle says is of diviner nature
47. than the elements and corresponds by analogy to heaven. This is called
48. “light,” a term which could not better suit the opinion of physicians and
49. philosopher s, who all agree that it is of a very bright substance and that
50. nothing pleases, fosters, and refreshes it more than light.

Assistant

Pico’s Plotinian conclusions (Conclusiones secundum Plotinum, I.20.1–15) embody a selective and critical engagement with Plotinus that exposes both his continuity with Ficino’s Neoplatonism and his decisive shift toward an Aristotelianized Christian metaphysics. Several key scholarly perspectives—Farmer, Allen, Howlett, and Dougherty—help unpack how Pico transforms Plotinus’s Enneads into a theology of intellectual freedom, hierarchy, and deification.

1. Plotinus’s Doctrines in Pico’s Hands

Stephen Farmer notes that Pico composed these fifteen Plotinian theses before Ficino’s translation of the Enneads was completed, relying instead on Greek and Arabic intermediaries (Porphyry, Iamblichus, “Adeland the Arab”)【205:3†(Medieval & Renaissance Texts & Studies 167)†L13-L19】. The early theses—“Primum intelligibile non est extra primum intellectum” and “Non tota descendit anima quum descendit”—mark his alignment with Plotinus’s ontology of emanation while already signaling his preference for a participatory metaphysics: intellect and intelligible coincide within divine act, not as separate hypostases.

Farmer observes that Pico’s Plotinian section is “much more perfunctory” than his elaborate Proclean theses, revealing that Plotinus was for Pico a theological resource rather than a systematic model【205:3†(Medieval & Renaissance Texts & Studies 167)†L48-L54】. The Plotinus theses affirm the immortality of all life (20.3), the hierarchy of soul (20.4–5), and the coincidence of being, life, and intellect (20.6) as a triune structure of existence—concepts Pico integrates into his Christianized doctrine of felicity (20.7).

2. The Ascent of the Intellect and Felicity

Thesis 20.7—“Foelicitas hominis ultima est cum particularis intellectus noster totali primoque intellectui plene coniungitur”—epitomizes Pico’s transformation of Plotinian henosis into scholastic idiom. As Farmer and Howlett note, this union of the individual with the “total intellect” reframes mystical absorption into God as participation in energeia, not dissolution into unity【205:15†(Medieval & Renaissance Texts & Studies 167)†L31-L33】【205:10†(Critical Political Theory and Radical Practice)†L10-L19】. Howlett connects this to Pico’s Aristotelian notion of the intellectus agens: felicity is the actualization of intellect’s potential through divine illumination—the human reflection of angelic act.

Thus, the Plotinian felicity thesis anticipates Pico’s later anthropology in the Oratio and Heptaplus: man’s freedom lies in his capacity to rise by intellect toward the angelic and divine, actualizing within himself all the forms of being.

3. Virtue and Deification

Theses 20.8–9—rejecting civic virtue as “virtues simpliciter” and claiming that assimilation to God through virtue is only preparatory—distill Plotinus’s mystical quietism into Christian moral theology. Farmer observes that Pico interprets Plotinian virtue hierarchically: lower virtues are merely ethical dispositions, while higher contemplation realizes participation in God’s act itself【205:15†(Medieval & Renaissance Texts & Studies 167)†L52-L56】. This complements his later magia naturalis doctrines, where knowledge of causal order mirrors divine providence.

4. Allen and Dougherty: Plotinus in the Ficino Debate

Michael J. B. Allen shows that Pico weaponized Plotinus against Ficino in the Commento and De ente et uno, particularly around the statement that “God understands nothing.” Pico corrects Ficino’s reading by insisting that Plotinus meant God possesses intellect causally, not formally—that divine thought is the cause of all understanding, not an act within it【205:4†(Variorum Collected Studies 1063)†L12-L18】. This recasting of Plotinian apophaticism as causal metaphysics turns the mystical ascent into an Aristotelianized doctrine of efficient causation, grounding divine simplicity in act (energeia) rather than negation.

Dougherty similarly notes that both Ficino and Pico “celebrated philosophically the birthday of Venus” but diverged on the metaphysics of ascent: Ficino’s unity of love versus Pico’s intellectual causality of being【205:1†M. V. Dougherty – Pico della Mirandola: New Essays†L5-L19】.

5. Howlett: Plotinus and the Active Intellect

Sophia Howlett situates Pico’s Plotinian theses within his Aristotelian anthropology: the intellect’s ascent from potency to act is both ethical and metaphysical. “For Pico,” she writes, “true freedom is based on the reasoned employment of the intellect to overcome the tyranny of the will”【205:9†(Critical Political Theory and Radical Practice)†L42-L46】. Thus the Plotinian identification of being, life, and intellect (20.6) becomes, in Pico, an anthropology of energeia: the human soul mirrors the eternal procession of divine act through understanding.

6. Synthesis: Pico’s Christianized Plotinus

In sum:

  • Plotinus’s ontological triad (Being–Life–Intellect) becomes for Pico the template of Trinitarian participation.

  • Felicity (20.7) redefines mystical union as intellectual participation in God’s causal act.

  • Virtue and purification (20.8–9, 20.11) translate Neoplatonic ethics into Thomist perfectionism.

  • Non-descent of the soul (20.2) and double life (20.4–5) become the basis for Pico’s angelic anthropology in the Oratio and Heptaplus.

  • Critique of Ficino: Pico rejects Plotinus’s ineffable One as pure negation, insisting instead on energetic causality—a God who acts rather than merely transcends.


Thus, Pico’s Plotinian theses are less a repetition of the Enneads than a reconstruction of Plotinus through Aquinas and Aristotle, transforming mystical Neoplatonism into a theology of intellectual freedom—the soul’s power to rise through understanding into the causal act of divine being itself【205:15†(Medieval & Renaissance Texts & Studies 167)†L21-L33】【205:4†(Variorum Collected Studies 1063)†L12-L18】【205:9†(Critical Political Theory and Radical Practice)†L42-L46】.

Series Foreword

The history of European witchcraft and magic continues to fascinate and chal-
lenge students and scholars. There is certainly no shortage of books on the
subject. Several general surveys of the witch trials and numerous regional and
micro studies have been published for an English-speaking readership. While the
quality of publications on witchcraft has been high, some regions and topics
have received less attention over the years. The aim of this series is to help illu-
minate these lesser known or little studied aspects of the history of witchcraft
and magic. It will also encourage the development of a broader corpus of work in
other related areas of magic and the supernatural, such as angels, devils, spirits,
ghosts, folk healing and divination. To help further our understanding and inter-
est in this wider history of beliefs and practices, the series will include research
that looks beyond the usual focus on Western Europe and that also explores their
relevance and influence from the medieval to the modern period.
