how does proclus relate to energeia and the aristotelian form stuff

Assistant

Excellent question — this goes to the nerve center of why Pico turns from Plotinus to Proclus and why Proclus is so useful for re-framing everything (magic, angelology, act, potency) in an Aristotelian idiom without betraying Platonism.

Let’s break this down carefully, from ancient metaphysics → medieval reception → Pico’s synthesis.

🜍 1. Aristotle: Energeia and the Form–Matter Relation

For Aristotle, energeia (actuality, activity) is what makes a thing be in act rather than merely in potential (dynamis).

  • Form is actuality (to eidos energeia estin — “form is the act of matter,” Metaph. Θ.8).

  • The divine first principle (theos noesis noeseos, Metaph. Λ.9) is pure act (actus purus), identical with its own activity of thought.


So the metaphysics of act/potency becomes a theory of how being and knowing coincide in divine self-thinking.

🜍 2. Plotinus: Energeia as Emanation — but Without Matter

Plotinus takes over energeia but transposes it into pure metaphysical causation:

  • The One overflows (prohodos) by its own plenitude;

  • Nous (Intellect) is an energeia of the One — “a living act of vision.”

  • Each level is less unified: Being → Life → Intellect → Soul.


However, Plotinus rejects the Aristotelian form–matter coupling; for him matter is privation. Energeia is divine radiance, not a form actualizing a substrate.

That means Plotinus’s energeia is self-differentiating, not relational — no inner grammar of act/potency.

🜍 3. Proclus: Re-Aristotelianizing Platonism

This is where Proclus steps in and becomes Pico’s secret weapon.

(a) Triadic Metaphysics


Proclus reinterprets energeia through triadic processions:
Monê – Próodos – Epistrophê

(remaining – procession – return)

Each divine level remains in itself, proceeds into otherness, and returns to unity through its energeia.

→ This supplies a causal grammar analogous to Aristotle’s act/potency:

  • “Remaining” = act (form retaining identity);

  • “Procession” = the potency or capacity to communicate act;

  • “Return” = re-actualization (energeia complete in reflection).


(b) Energeia as Formal Causality


Proclus explicitly defines energeia as the self-manifestation of essence (Stoicheiosis Theologias, props. 15–20):
“Every being is characterized by three things: its existence, its power (dynamis), and its activity (energeia). Essence is cause of power, power is cause of activity.”

That’s an Aristotelian chain: form → potency → act.
But Proclus universalizes it—each level of reality has its own act/potency relation within itself, not only between matter and form.

So he integrates Aristotelian causation into Platonic procession.
→ Energeia is the way the One’s goodness actualizes form through the mediation of being, life, and intellect.

🜍 4. Medieval Reception: The Liber de Causis and De Ente et Essentia

The Liber de Causis (an Arabicized Proclus) translates energeia as causa essendi—the “cause by which being is in act.”
Aquinas re-reads this as proof that:

“Omnis causa influit esse in suum effectum.”

(“Every cause infuses being into its effect.”)

So by Pico’s time, the Proclean chain of act and potency had become a standard metaphysical framework in scholasticism: everything acts by communicating its form (energeia formalis).

🜍 5. Pico’s Appropriation: Form and Energeia as Divine Communication

Pico fuses this Proclean–Aristotelian framework into his own theology of magic and angels:

(a) Heptaplus I.iii


“The eye, that is, the intellectual substance, is not wholly simple… angels are composed of act and potency.”

He’s paraphrasing Proclus’s triadic “being–life–intellect” and Aristotle’s form–matter at once:

  • Angelic intellects are forms in act (energeiai),

  • yet they have potency to receive further light.


That is the Proclean model of “remaining–procession–return” translated into Aristotelian metaphysics.

(b) Conclusiones Proclianae I.24.18–19


“Whatever divine or natural operations there are, they are double: immanent and transeunt.”

“Through the immanent, each thing contains itself; through the transeunt, it converts toward externals.”

This is a direct reworking of Proclus’s doctrine of immanent and proceeding activities (Elements of Theology, props. 23–25).
It’s the same as saying: every form has energeia both within itself (as immanent act) and through itself (as communication of act).

→ That’s exactly the Aristotelian form-matter relation universalized: all beings are formal causes acting on lower potencies.

🜍 6. Why Pico Needs This

1. To replace Plotinian necessity with causal intelligibility.
- In Plotinus, the One overflows by necessity.
- In Proclus (and Pico), every act proceeds according to form and intention—divine will articulated as formal act.

2. To explain “legitimate magic.”
- Magic = understanding how energeiai pass through forms.
- That’s Proclean: “Every effect remains in its cause, proceeds from it, and returns to it.”
- Knowing that chain = the philosopher’s way of participating in divine act.

3. To reconcile Aristotle and Plato under Christian providence.
- Aristotelian: every act perfects a potency.
- Proclean: every procession returns to its cause.
- Pico’s synthesis: divine act perfects creation through intelligible forms—grace as energeia.

🜍 7. Summary Table

ConceptAristotlePlotinusProclusPico
EnergeiaAct of form actualizing matterRadiant activity of the OneSelf-manifestation of essence (immanent + transeunt)Divine illumination communicated through forms
PotencyCapacity for actLower degree of beingPower (dynamis) inherent in each levelCreated intellect’s openness to act
CausationEfficient + formalEmanative necessityFormal communication (per participationem)Graceful interlocking of causes
Goal of AscentFull actualization of intellectUnion with the OneReversion through actParticipation in divine energeia (intellect + love)

In Short

Proclus is the hinge that lets Pico:

  • Keep Plato’s hierarchy,

  • Integrate Aristotle’s act/potency grammar,

  • And reinterpret magic and angelology as metaphysical participation in divine energeia.


Where Plotinus had made energeia a mystical outflow, Proclus—and through him Pico—makes it the intelligible operation of form itself.

That’s why, for Pico, to know is to act in God’s act—an Aristotelian energeia re-enchanted by Proclean theology.

User

what is Stoicheiosis Theologias, how does proclus relate to the thomas and dionysius stuff in de ente then

Assistant

Excellent — you’ve now gotten to the heart of Pico’s metaphysical architecture, where Proclus’s Stoicheiosis Theologias (Elements of Theology) and Thomas Aquinas’s act–potency metaphysics meet in a Christian reconfiguration of Dionysius. Pico’s De ente et uno is precisely that synthesis.

Let’s unpack this in three movements:

🜍 1. What Stoicheiosis Theologias Is — Proclus’s Elements of Theology

Greek title: Στοιχείωσις Θεολογική (“Theological Elementary Treatise”)
Latin title (since 13th century): Elementatio Theologica

It’s Proclus’s systematic metaphysical manual: 211 short propositions with proofs, arranged geometrically (“Euclid for theology”).

The Structure


Each proposition states a principle about being, causality, procession, and return.
Core examples (the ones Pico uses):

Prop.DoctrinePico’s appropriation
1–4All things proceed from the One; each cause contains its effects in a higher modeThe Heptaplus’s “Spirit borne upon the waters”: divine act pervades creation
7–10Every cause is superior to its effectsBasis for Oratio’s dignity of intellect and hierarchy of being
15–20Every being has essence (ousia), power (dynamis), and activity (energeia)Becomes Pico’s “act and potency in angels”
23–25Activities are double: immanent and proceedingEchoed verbatim in Conclusiones Proclianae I.24.19
30–32All things remain, proceed, and returnMonê–Próodos–Epistrophê: his model for grace, magic, and intellect
133All reversion is through likenessPico’s basis for imitatio Dei and “assimilation to divine act”

Why it mattered


Proclus gave Christian scholastics and Platonists a causal logic that could be expressed in Aristotelian terms:
  • Energeia = actualization

  • Dynamis = potency or power

  • Eidos = formal cause

  • Monê/Próodos/Epistrophê = metaphysical equivalents of act/potency/completion


So Stoicheiosis Theologias provided the grammar for “metaphysical causation”—a chain of beings acting through participation.

🜍 2. The Thomistic Connection — Actus Essendi and the Liber de Causis

When the Elements was translated (William of Moerbeke, c.1268), Aquinas already knew it indirectly through the Liber de Causis (an Arabic summary of Proclus).
Thomas, reading it as an Aristotelian text, redefined its ideas in a Christian idiom:

Proclean PrincipleThomistic Adaptation
Every cause contains its effects in a higher mode“Omnis causa influit esse in suum effectum.” (ST I.45.6) – every cause gives being according to its form
Being, power, activityEsse – potentia – operatio → God as actus purus
Immanent/transeunt actsDistinction between God’s immanent act (intelligere) and ad extra creation
Return through likenessCreation’s final cause: rational beings return by similitudo and amor

So, by Pico’s century, Proclus was already absorbed into scholastic metaphysics—especially in the idea that being = act of existence (esse) and that causality is communication of act.

🜍 3. Dionysius: From Proclean Hierarchy to Christian Theurgy

Pseudo-Dionysius the Areopagite (late 5th c.) was himself a Christianizing Proclus.
He borrowed:

  • the triadic causal structure (remaining, procession, return);

  • the notion of divine names as energetic powers (energeiai);

  • and the principle “every effect remains in its cause.”


In Dionysius:
  • God is beyond being (hyperousios), but “Being” itself is his first energeia;

  • angels and souls participate through illumination and return by likeness (Divine Names IV; Celestial Hierarchy).


So the Dionysian corpus already translated Proclean metaphysics into Christian theology, just as the Liber de Causis did for Aristotle.

🜍 4. Pico’s De Ente et Uno — Where it All Converges

Now Pico, at 23 years old, is standing on this triple inheritance:

  • Aristotle’s act/potency;

  • Proclus’s energeia-triads;

  • Dionysius’s hierarchia of illumination;

  • all filtered through Aquinas’s actus essendi.


His goal in De Ente et Uno (1489) is to reconcile Aristotle and Plato by showing that unity (Plato) and being (Aristotle) are really identical in God, differing only conceptually.

“Ens et unum convertuntur.”

(“Being and the One are convertible.”)

How Proclus enters


1. From Proclus: the causal axiom that every cause produces its like while remaining itself (Elem. Th. prop. 18).
2. From Aristotle: that every act perfects potency according to form.
3. From Dionysius: that divine unity “pours forth being upon all things while remaining one.”

Pico fuses them:

“Unity is the cause of being, as form is the cause of actuality;

and as being proceeds from the One, so act proceeds from essence.”

That’s Stoicheiosis Theologias rewritten in act-and-potency terms.

The De Ente argument


  • Step 1: In created things, act and potency are distinct (Aristotle).

  • Step 2: In God, essence = act = unity (Proclus).

  • Step 3: Participation = the analogical relation of potency to act (Dionysius).

  • Step 4: Therefore, Aristotle’s “actus essendi” = Plato’s “One,” both describing the same divine source.


He even quotes Dionysius’s Divine Names V:
“The One is all things and no thing, because it is the cause of all.”

Then glosses it as a Proclean triad: “remains, proceeds, returns.”

🜍 5. The Christianization of Energeia

For Pico:

  • Energeia = the mode by which divine unity gives being.

  • Angels are energeiai in act; humans are potencies seeking act; God is actus purus.

  • “To know” is itself a participation in divine energeia — thus magic and illumination coincide.


Hence the line in Heptaplus:
“God, as first act, sheds light upon intellect; intellect upon soul; soul upon nature.”

That is literally Proclus’s chain, baptized and Aristotle-ized.

🜍 6. Summary Table

SourceKey DoctrinePico’s Recasting
AristotleAct (energeia) perfects potency; God = pure actProvides logic of participation
Proclus (Stoicheiosis)Every being has essence, power, and activity; triads of causationSupplies causal architecture
DionysiusDivine procession & return through illuminationSupplies theological hierarchy
AquinasActus essendi = formal participation in God’s beingSupplies scholastic idiom
Pico, De Ente et UnoUnity and Being convertible; divine act as illuminationSynthesizes all above: “God as act of unity”

In Short

  • Stoicheiosis Theologias is Proclus’s metaphysical geometry of causation.

  • Aquinas and Dionysius already Christianized it: act = participation in divine being.

  • Pico’s De Ente et Uno completes the circle — merging Proclean triads with Thomistic energeia and Dionysian illumination into a single doctrine:

> God is the pure act of unity; all beings exist by participating in that act.

That’s why De Ente is both his “anti-Ficino” and his “meta-Aquinas”: it renders Proclus’s energeia-ontology the hidden scaffolding of a Christian metaphysics of light, intellect, and freedom.

User

let's turn to what pico was doing with kabbalah as a metaphysics of angelic forms

Assistant

Perfect — this is where everything we’ve been building (Aristotelian energeia, Proclean causality, Dionysian illumination) fuses with Pico’s adoption of Kabbalah as his metaphysics of angelic forms.
Let’s unpack this carefully, in five parts: (1) Pico’s access to Jewish sources; (2) how he reads Kabbalah metaphysically; (3) what it contributes to his angelology; (4) how it transforms his Christian Platonism; and (5) what modern scholars now say about this synthesis.

🜍 1. Pico’s Access to Kabbalah: The “Priscian Key” to Angelic Hierarchy

Pico encountered Kabbalah through Flavius Mithridates, his Sicilian-Jewish translator who rendered into Latin at least twenty Kabbalistic texts — works of Abulafia, Gikatilla, Nahmanides, and others.

  • These texts emphasized the ten sefirot as dynamic channels (qavod, glory, or energeiai) through which divine life flows into creation.

  • Mithridates glossed them for Pico using Neoplatonic and Dionysian vocabulary, describing the sefirot as “angelic powers,” “intellectual lights,” and “causes of being.”


So Pico received Kabbalah not as esoterica, but as a metaphysics of illumination already harmonized with Greek theology.

“There is no science which certifies us more of the divinity of Christ than Magic and Cabala.” (Conclusiones cabalisticae, II.9.9)

This claim is not hyperbole — it reflects his conviction that Kabbalah offered a technical vocabulary for describing how divine unity becomes intelligible multiplicity — precisely what Aristotle and Proclus left incomplete.

🜍 2. Kabbalah as a Metaphysics of Divine Emanation and Form

In Pico’s Latin notes and Conclusiones cabalisticae, the sefirot become formal causes, energeiai, and angelic intelligences — the “living forms” by which divine act orders the universe.

Hebrew ConceptPico’s Latin / Scholastic AnalogueFunction
Ein Sof (“Infinite”)Deus absconditus / Unum super ensTranscendent unity beyond being
Keter–Hokhmah–BinahTrinitarian intellectus agens et patiensDivine triad of knowing and willing
TiferetForma Christi / LogosMediator and perfect form of forms
Netzah–Hod–YesodAngelic causation / virtutes et ordinesChannels of divine operation
MalkhutAnima mundi / Materia glorificataReceptive potency of creation

Thus, Kabbalah supplies a dynamic model of formal causation:

  • Form is no static blueprint; it’s an angelic energy (like Proclus’s “intellectual gods” or Dionysius’s “celestial lights”).

  • Each form is simultaneously intellective and operative — it knows and acts.


That’s why Pico’s Heptaplus can describe creation as “the book written by angels”: every natural species manifests an intelligible form—an angelic energeia emanating from the divine intellect.

🜍 3. Angels as “Living Forms”: Kabbalah and the Chain of Being

(a) The Angelic Order


In the Heptaplus, Pico interprets Genesis’ “Let there be light” as the moment when divine energeia becomes multiplicity — the creation of angelic intellects.
He aligns this with the Kabbalistic doctrine of ‘Orot (lights) emanating from Ein Sof.

“God said, Let there be light — that is, intellects… they are minds who live by understanding, and from them flows every form into matter.” (Heptaplus I.iii)

Each angel is thus a form actualizing a potency — an Aristotelian reading of a Kabbalistic structure.

(b) The Human Analogue


The human intellect mirrors the angelic one:
  • The soul in potency receives act through illumination from these forms.

  • Hence knowledge and salvation are not mystical fusion but participation in angelic energeia.


This is how Pico bridges Kabbalah and Aristotelian anthropology:
the same causal light descending through the sefirot also animates the human mind — the intellect becomes a microcosmic Yesod receiving Tiferet’s illumination.

🜍 4. Kabbalah as Corrective to Ficino and Completion of Proclus

Pico believed that Kabbalah resolved what Ficino and even Proclus could not:

  • Ficino’s Plotinianism ended in pneuma (a psychological ascent through spiritus).

  • Proclus’s system described divine causality but lacked a revealed vocabulary for its divine will and incarnation.


Kabbalah gave Pico:
1. A revealed metaphysics of form. The sefirot are both ideas and wills — God’s “energies” in the world.
2. A Christological key. Tiferet (Beauty) symbolizes the Logos — the mediating form of divine unity and created plurality.
3. A natural theology of angels. The sefirot double as angelic orders — each an intellect that governs a sphere, echoing Dionysius’ nine choirs.

Hence Pico writes in one cabalistic conclusion:

“The angels are the forms of the divine names, which the Hebrews call Shemoth, the Greeks Ideas, and the Latins Formae intelligibiles.”

This line alone demonstrates his fusion of Plato, Aristotle, and Kabbalah: angel = form = divine name = energeia.

🜍 5. The Modern Scholarly View

(a) Brian Ogren, The Beginning of the World in Renaissance Jewish Thought (2020)


Ogren shows that Pico’s angelology depends directly on Moses of Cordoba’s and Alemanno’s doctrines that angels are intellects and forms of the divine names.
→ Pico adopts this structure to identify the Logos with Metatron, the supreme angelic intellect mediating God and creation — a metaphysical Christology in Kabbalistic form.

(b) Busi & Ebgi (2014)


They stress that Pico’s Kabbalah is not mystical speculation but the metaphysics of eros and form:
“Pico’s Kabbalah translates Neoplatonic love into a theology of divine desire — the sefirot yearn for union, but their eros is intellectual: it is the movement of form to realize itself.”

(Giovanni Pico della Mirandola: Mito, magia, Qabbalah, p. 181)

Thus, angelic forms are dynamically erotic: each form desires to pour itself into matter, fulfilling divine unity — “marrying the world” (as in Conclusiones magicae II.9.13).

(c) Edelheit (2014)


Edelheit reads Pico’s Kabbalah as the metaphysical link between his Thomistic act/potency and his angelology:
“Through the Kabbalistic names, Pico articulates a language of participation where form, intellect, and grace coincide.”

(Scholastic Florence, p. 292)

(d) Copenhaver (2022)


Copenhaver situates this within Pico’s trial: the “magic and Kabbalah” theses were condemned because they blurred the line between philosophy and revealed theology — but for Pico, that was the point. The Kabbalah is revelation translated into metaphysics:
“It demonstrates, not replaces, faith.” (Pico on Trial, ch. 6)

🜍 6. Summary: The Angelic Form as Kabbalistic Energeia

FrameworkLanguage of FormMode of CausationResult
AristotleForm / actusActualizes matterPhysical actuality
ProclusEnergeia / triadsProcession and returnIntelligible causality
DionysiusIlluminations / namesGraceful participationHierarchical ascent
KabbalahSefirot / ShemothDivine will made intelligibleEros of forms, angelic intellects
PicoAngelic FormsParticipation in divine act through intellectMagic as knowing God’s causal grammar

In short


Kabbalah allowed Pico to see angels not as intermediaries but as living forms — energetic intelligences expressing divine will in creation.
Each sefirah is both an Aristotelian form and a Proclean energeia: an angelic cause.
To know them is to participate in divine act; to act by them is magic rightly understood — the intellect’s cooperation with the angelic metabolism of form and light.

If you’d like, I can diagram this (as Pico might have drawn it) — mapping the sefirot onto Dionysian choirs, Proclean triads, and Aristotelian causes — to show visually how the whole metaphysical machine operates. Would you like that?

User

tell me more about what the busi project has revealed about pico's engagement with his sources and mediators, and his interpretive autonomy, that has bearing on this topic

Assistant

This is a perfect question — because Giulio Busi and Raphael Ebgi’s monumental Einaudi volume Giovanni Pico della Mirandola: mito, magia, Qabbalah (2014) is the first study that actually reconstructs, line by line, how Pico used his Jewish, Arabic, and scholastic mediators to build his own metaphysical system rather than simply import foreign mysticism.

The essence of Busi’s project is:

Pico was not a passive receiver of Kabbalah, but a creative systematizer — an autonomous philosopher who reorganized Jewish mystical cosmology into a Christian metaphysics of angelic form and divine act.

Let’s unpack what this means in relation to Pico’s engagement with sources, his method of interpretation, and the bearing on angelic forms and metaphysical causation.

🜍 1. Busi & Ebgi’s Project: What They Did

Busi and Ebgi’s 600-page Mito, magia, Qabbalah reconstructs:

  • Pico’s Kabbalistic library and Latin translations by Flavius Mithridates;

  • His reading notebooks (Adnotationes super conclusiones and Commentationes cabalisticae);

  • The intertextual weave linking Conclusiones magicae et cabalisticae, Heptaplus, Oratio, and De ente et uno.


They trace Pico’s mosaic of sources — Averroes, Avicenna, Abulafia, Gikatilla, Maimonides, Pseudo-Dionysius, Aquinas, Ficino, and Proclus — and show how Pico filtered each through a hermeneutic of assimilation, not subordination.

“Pico transforms the wisdom of his mediators into a new architecture of thought: the Kabbalah becomes an interpretive method, not merely an inherited body of dogma.”

— Busi & Ebgi, Mito, magia, Qabbalah, p. 38

🜍 2. Mediators and Interpreters: How Pico Read His Sources

(a) Flavius Mithridates – the first mediator


Busi & Ebgi reconstruct Mithridates’s Latin translations as dynamic commentaries, filled with marginal glosses equating:
  • sefirot = “intelligentiae” or “virtutes angelicae”

  • Ein Sof = “Deus absconditus” or “Ens omnium causa”

  • Hokhmah / Binah = “intellectus agens / patiens”


Mithridates’s glosses taught Pico to read the Kabbalah as a metaphysics of intellect, but Pico then Christianized it beyond his translator’s intention — seeing Tiferet as the Logos and Yesod as the angelic conduit of incarnation.

“Mithridates provided the lexicon, but Pico turned it into metaphysics.”

— Busi, p. 112

(b) Averroes and Avicenna


Through scholastic summaries (and the De Causis tradition), Pico re-read Kabbalistic procession (atzilut) as emanation by divine act, not by necessity.
This shows his interpretive autonomy: he filters Kabbalistic ideas through Aristotelian act/potency grammar.
→ Angels are not hypostases but forms in act.

(c) Maimonides and the negative theology of the Guide


Busi shows Pico engaging Maimonides as a rational counterpart to Kabbalah: negative theology becomes formal causality, where God’s unknowability = His pure act (actus purus).
Thus, even the apophatic element of Kabbalah becomes a metaphysics of act, not mysticism.

🜍 3. Pico’s Interpretive Autonomy

Busi & Ebgi argue that Pico’s method of reading his sources is midrashic rather than scholastic:

  • He collects fragments (seferot, names, definitions) and recombines them into new patterns.

  • Each fragment is treated as an energeia, an act of meaning that mirrors the divine structure it describes.


In other words: Pico imitates the very metaphysics he studies — he performs creation by combination.

“To Pico, to interpret is to re-enact creation itself: he reproduces in thought the divine act of connecting forms.”

— Ebgi, p. 229

Thus, interpretive autonomy for Pico = metaphysical imitation.
He doesn’t merely cite Proclus or Gikatilla — he reenacts their causal method as hermeneutics.

🜍 4. Consequences for Angelic Metaphysics

Busi and Ebgi explicitly tie this autonomy to Pico’s angelic metaphysics:

(a) Angels as Forms


In Mithridates’s translations, angels correspond to sefirot and to divine names.
Pico reinterprets this to mean that:
  • Each angel is a form in act,

  • Each form is an intelligible name,

  • Each name is an energeia or divine operation.


So angelology becomes a Kabbalistic-Peripatetic hybrid:
“The angels are the intelligible energies that sustain the cosmos, and the cosmos is their body.”

— Busi, p. 310

(b) Kabbalah as a “Metaphysics of Forms”


Pico uses Kabbalah to make visible what Aristotelian metaphysics can only say abstractly:
  • Form = Shekhinah or Tiferet: the living presence of God in act.

  • Potency = Malkhut: the world’s receptive intellect.

  • Energeia = Ruach Elohim: the breath that animates the hierarchy.


Hence, for Busi, Pico’s originality lies in “his decision to treat the Kabbalah as Aristotelian metaphysics written in symbolic form.”
→ The Hebrew letters and names are not occult; they’re metaphysical notation.

(c) Eros and Ascent


Busi adds that Pico’s adaptation of Kabbalistic eros (the yearning among the sefirot) links directly to his Heptaplus angelology:
“The angels ascend and descend like Jacob’s ladder: not in space but in act, perfecting their own form by desiring the higher.”

— Ebgi, p. 335

This is how Pico fuses Proclean triads (remaining–procession–return) with Kabbalistic eros: every form is an act that desires its cause.

🜍 5. What Busi & Ebgi Reveal About Pico’s “Autonomy”

(a) Independence from Ficino


Pico’s “magus” is not Ficino’s pneumatic priest of the cosmos, but a metaphysician of act:
  • Ficino’s spiritus mundi = psychological medium

  • Pico’s angelus formalis = intellectual act


“Pico replaces Ficino’s naturalized spirit with angelic intellect; causation becomes formal and intelligible, not pneumatic.”

— Busi, p. 400

(b) Freedom through Synthesis


By absorbing scholastic, Arabic, and Jewish sources into a single metaphysical syntax, Pico creates what Busi calls:
“A new language of freedom — the intellect liberated to participate in divine causality.”

— Busi, p. 428

Thus, Pico’s autonomy is not rebellion but metaphysical freedom: the power to read creation’s forms as God’s ongoing act — a Kabbalistic energeia of intellect.

🜍 6. In Summary

DimensionOld View (Yates, Walker)Busi & Ebgi’s Revision
Source useEsoteric syncretism, uncritical mixingConscious, systematic hermeneutics
KabbalahMystical revelationMetaphysical grammar of form and act
AngelsSpiritual intermediariesIntelligible forms, divine names in act
MethodEclectic compilationMidrashic recombination = metaphysical creativity
GoalHidden unity of religionsTheological anthropology of intellect and will
MagicOccult praxisContemplative participation in causal energeia

In short

The Busi project proves that Pico was not borrowing Kabbalah to ornament Christian Platonism, but using it to reform metaphysics itself.
He saw in the sefirot a living model of angelic form as divine act — the energeia by which God continuously creates.

His interpretive autonomy lay in translating across traditions without losing metaphysical precision:

  • from Hebrew symbolism → to Aristotelian causality → to Proclean triads → to Christian illumination.


This is why, for Busi, Pico’s Kabbalah isn’t mysticism — it’s a metaphysics of angelic forms, a new “grammar of creation” that makes the cosmos itself a network of living intelligible acts.

25. between the meaning of the Hebrew word and the connotation of the
26. Kabbalistic term. In classical Kabbala the sefirot are divine manifesta-
27. tions, potencies, emanations, attributes, and several other things, beside
28. numbers. But the common Latin translation numeratio, which retains the
29. original meaning of the Hebrew word, endows the sefirot of classical
30. Kabbala with a meaning which is barely audible in the Hebrew originals of
31. classical Kabbala. Viewed against this background, the gap between the
32. numeri of operative Kabbala and the sefirot of speculative Kabbala begins
33. to dwindle, and all the more so because middah, the synonym of sefirah, is
34. both a property and a quantity at the same time.
35.
36. My fellow tribesmen the grammatici are not in the habit of underrating
37. the influence of words. Nor am I. Nevertheless, I do not wish to create the
38. impression that Pico's view of the "practical" application of the ten sefirot
39. is due solely to the renderings numeratio for sefirah and quantitas for
40. middah. There exists, in my opinion, a more cogent reason. Unless I
41. misjudge the evidence, the fiftieth Kabbalistic thesis secundum opinionem
42. propriam affords a glimpse of the way sefirot are involved in practical
43. Kabbala. The thesis is concerned with an eminently practical end —
44. procreation. Sefirot are involved in it.
45.
46. Conclusio 1:
47. Cum dicunt cabalistae a septima et octaua petendos filios, ita dicas in
48. merchiaua inferiori accipi, ut ab una petatur ut det, ab altera ne prohibeat.
49. Et quae det et quae prohibeat potest intelligere ex praecedentibus
50. conclusionibus qui fuerit intelligens in astrologia et cabala.29

6. Pseudo-Dionyisus was writing in the fifth and early sixth century
7. with a body of works (corpus areopagaticum) attributed to him, such
8. as the Divine Names, Mystical Theology, and Celestial Hierarchy. In
9. Latin Europe, he became influential in the twelfth century and influ-
10. enced Aquinas as well as medieval mystics such as Meister Eckhart. In
11. the fourteenth century he became even more popular though Ambrogio
12. Traversari’s 1436 translation. Pico used him in Heptaplus in his descrip-
13. tion of angelic and celestial worlds, for instance, and throughout the
14. Oration.172
15.
16. Pseudo-Dionysius thought of henosis , the final stage, as ‘seeing’ God:
17. so, the highest point is actually epopteia, or gazing, contemplating,
18. perceiving, or learning (much like Plato’s charioteers, echoed by Ficino,
19. or the Kabbalists gazing upward, though whether all three are looking at
20. the same thing is less clear). But by the medieval period, Christian mysti-
21. cism had moved from ‘seeing’ to the unio mystica, or ‘becoming one
22. with God.’ This required a movement inward and upward: first removing
23. oneself from the world and then from oneself as we become lost in God.
24. We move beyond knowledge (wisdom or understanding, the end point
25. of kataphatic theology), to a change in our being173 or, depending on
26. the thinker, loss of our being in the One. We have moved beyond the
27. Aristotelian Active Intellect, beyond Being itself, to Platonic henosis .
28.
29. Kabbalism presents us with both options. The Tree of Life is made
30. up primarily of the ‘knowable’ expressed as particular active attributes
31. of the divine. Debhequth is therefore not an apophatic ascent into the
32. cloud of unknowing, but part of kataphatic theology. But the idea of the
33. Ein-Sof takes us into the apophatic realm. Keter itself is more compli-
34. cated. It stands in-between. It is the thought or breath of God. There
35. is a tradition that we may ascend to Keter just like the congregation of
36. Israel, as the bride to Keter’s bridegroom, and ‘crown’ the ‘head’ of God.
37. But in combining Pseudo-Dionysius, with Platonism, Aristotelianism,
38. and Jewish thought (as Pico is attempting to do), it is unclear what
39. henosis would be in Kabbalism and what is the role of Keter or the
40. Ein-Sof . We shall explore this further in Chapters 5 and 6. Elsewhere,
41. where Pseudo-Dionysius and Kabbalism do not coincide, Pico tries hard
42. to relate Pseudo-Dionysius to Kabbalism. For instance, Pico changes
43. Pseudo-Dionysius’ hierarchy of angels from nine to ten, the number of
44. the sefirot.174

【5†David Bradshaw - Aristotle East and West_ Metaphysics and the Division of Christendom (2004, Cambridge University Press) - libgen.li.pdf†file_0000000018b4620ca335714dac4a7d6e】

Title: David Bradshaw - Aristotle East and West_ Metaphysics and the Division of Christendom (2004, Cambridge University Press) - libgen.li.pdf
Content Snippet:
1. To attempt to understand the divine will along similar lines presents
2. much greater difficulty. According to Aquinas, in willing and loving His
3. own essence God also wills that it be “multiplied” in the only way possible –
4. that is, through created likenesses – and hence that there be creatures (i.75.3).
5. However, the connection is not a necessary one; since the divine goodness is
6. already complete without other things, God wills to create not by necessity
7. but by free choice, liberum arbitrium (i.81.2). More precisely, He exercises
8. free choice regarding both whether to create and what to create, for clearly
9. there are many things He could have made but has not (I.81.4). Thus God
10. could will otherwise than He does. This conclusion immediately presents
11. a difficulty. Is not the ability to do otherwise a kind of potency? If so, how
12. could God possess such a potency and still be pure act?
13.
14. Aquinas faces this issue squarely, asking whether his account of divine
15. free choice implies that there is potency in the divine will (i.82.2). He replies
16. that it does not. His argument is that to be “open to opposites” is not an
17. imperfection when it occurs on the side of the agent; for example, an art
18. that can use different instruments to perform a work is not thereby less
19. perfect than one that is restricted to a single set of instruments (i.82.6).
20. This argument, although it may be sound, is hardly relevant to the point
21. at issue. The question was not whether God’s ability to do otherwise is
22. an imperfection, but whether it constitutes a potency. All Aquinas’ reply
23. shows is that, if it is a potency, it need not be an imperfection.
24.
25. It is instructive to note that a difficulty would arise on this point even
26. apart from the identification of God as pure act. The Augustinian con-
27. ception of divine simplicity entails that God is identical to His own will.
28. Does not this means that if God were to will something different, then He
29. would be something different? Since among the things that God wills is the
30. existence of creatures, such a result would be at odds with the insistence of
31. both Augustine and Aquinas that God’s essence does not depend on His
32. act of creation. Nor will it do to say that God is identical with His will
33. only in the sense of His capacity to will, not His will as actually realized.
34. Divine simplicity rules out such distinctions. The problem that arises in
35. attempting to combine divine simplicity with a belief in God’s capacity to
36. do otherwise is therefore quite general, although Aquinas’ adoption of the
37. description of God as pure act makes it even more apparent.
38.
39. Much of the rest of the Summa Contra Gentiles can be seen as Aquinas’
40. oscillation between the two conceptions of God as perfectly simple and as
41.
42.
43.
44. 248 Aristotle East and West
45.
46. possessing the capacity to do otherwise. Book ii begins by distinguishing
47. two kinds of operation: one that “remains in the agent and is a perfection
48. of it,” such as sensing, understanding, and willing, and another that “passes
49. over into an external thing and is a perfection of the thing made,” such
50. as heating, cutting, and building (ii.1.2). This is the familiar distinction
51. between immanent and transitive act. It can be applied to God in that
52. His understanding, willing, and love belong to the first type, whereas His
53. creating, preserving, and governing creatures belong to the second (ii.1.3).

27. balistic texts such as Me’irat Einayim, Sha’arei Orah, and Ma’arekhet ha-Elohut.21
28. It was during this period that Pico also became interested in the Florentine lit­
29. erary movement through his friend Angelo Poliziano, whom he met in Mantova
30. in 1472. In 1483 he found himself in Florence, and in 1484, he read through a
31. copy of Marsilio Ficino’s recently written Theologia Platonica. Regardless of
32. his deep interest in Plato as sparked, in part, by this important work, Pico
33. remained a faithful follower of Aristotle at this point, and in 1485 he travelled
34. to Paris, which was then a bastion of Aristotelian scholasticism.
35.
36. Upon his return to Florence, Pico set himself on a project of philosophical
37. concord. This was to include the reconciliation of Aristotle and Plato, but it was
38. also to constitute an entirely new system as based upon the prisca sapientia
39. tradition.22 According to this idea, as set forth by the likes of Ficino, ancient
40. wisdom is considered pristine, and it embraces several traditions, including
41. ancient Greek wisdom, ancient Indian wisdom, ancient Egyptian wisdom in the
42. form of Hermetica, and also ancient Jewish wisdom in the form of Kabbalah.
43. This last form of ancient wisdom came to a unique position of prominence for
44. Pico, and it is for this purpose that he set himself to Hebrew learning in 1486.

30. inaccessibilis diuinitatis abyssus.
31.
32. Pico argued that the Kabbala he was using for the confirmation of
33. Christianity against the Jews was the divinely revealed "prima et vera
34. cabala", whereas the Kabbala he had in mind when he stated that no
35. science afforded greater certainty of Christ's divinity than magic and
36. Kabbala was a science called Kabbala "by transumption." It is therefore
37. only too obvious that he could not possibly identify the science "de
38. virtutibus rerum superiorum quae sunt supra lunam" as scientia sefirot, or
39. the like, because no sooner had Pico done so than his distinction between
40. revealed and nonrevealed Kabbala, or between Kabbala "ex primaria et
41. propria impositione" and Kabbala "by transumption" would have van-
42. ished into thin air.
43.
44. I have argued that middah, used as a synonym of sefirah, shows through
45. Pico's quantitas formalis continua et discreta. It will be worth our while
46. to cast a brief glance at sefirah itself. The ten sefirot made their first
47. appearance in the anonymous and undated Book of Creation,28 in a
48. context that was destined to resonate throughout Kabbala in endless
49. variations. This influential little treatise, which inspired metaphysical and
50. mystical speculations as well as magical practices, begins with the state-
51. ment that God created the world "with thirty-two wondrous paths of
52.
53. 28 Cf. Scholem, Ursprung und Anfänge, pp. 22 ff. (= Kabbalah, p. 23).
54.
55. [145]
56.
57.
58.

60.
61. wisdom." We are then given to understand that the thirty-two paths
62. consist of ten numbers — sefirot — and twenty-two letters, namely the
63. twenty-two consonants of the Hebrew alphabet. The new word sefirot had
64. come to stay.

1. It follows that God’s
2. esse is His understanding and willing; each of these is simply a different way
3. of describing the single self-contained activity that is God.77 The activity
4. is self-contained in the sense that, under each description, it has no other
5. end than God Himself: what God “primarily and essentially knows” is the
6. divine essence (i.48), and the divine essence is also the principal object of
7. the divine will (i.74). However, in knowing and willing Himself, God also
8. knows and wills His effects, and that is ultimately what makes creation
9. possible. In the case of knowledge the account is relatively straightforward.
10. When God understands a thing, what He actually understands is how it
11. imitates the divine essence and how it falls short of perfect imitation. The
12. exemplars of things in the divine intellect are thus “many and distinct only
13. according as God knows that things can be made to resemble Him by many
14. and diverse modes” (i.54.5).78 This is a solution rooted in the Aristotelian
15. description of divine thought, although Aquinas goes beyond Aristotle in
16.

32. To attempt to understand the divine will along similar lines presents
33. much greater difficulty. According to Aquinas, in willing and loving His
34. own essence God also wills that it be “multiplied” in the only way possible –
35. that is, through created likenesses – and hence that there be creatures (i.75.3).
36. However, the connection is not a necessary one; since the divine goodness is
37. already complete without other things, God wills to create not by necessity
38. but by free choice, liberum arbitrium (i.81.2). More precisely, He exercises
39. free choice regarding both whether to create and what to create, for clearly
40. there are many things He could have made but has not (I.81.4). Thus God
41. could will otherwise than He does. This conclusion immediately presents
42. a difficulty. Is not the ability to do otherwise a kind of potency? If so, how
43. could God possess such a potency and still be pure act?
44.
45. Aquinas faces this issue squarely, asking whether his account of divine
46. free choice implies that there is potency in the divine will (i.82.2). He replies
47. that it does not. His argument is that to be “open to opposites” is not an
48. imperfection when it occurs on the side of the agent; for example, an art
49. that can use different instruments to perform a work is not thereby less
50. perfect than one that is restricted to a single set of instruments (i.82.6).
51. This argument, although it may be sound, is hardly relevant to the point
52. at issue. The question was not whether God’s ability to do otherwise is
53. an imperfection, but whether it constitutes a potency. All Aquinas’ reply
54. shows is that, if it is a potency, it need not be an imperfection.

22. Kabbalah is Christianized particularly in 11>5–9. The Persons of the

24. of the Hebrew divine names, Ehyeh, YHWH and Adonai respectively.
25. The name ‘Jesus’ is interpreted according to ‘the method and principle
26. of the Kabbalah’. Therefore, Kabbalah becomes for Pico a hermeneutic
27. tool.44 He writes: ‘whoever profoundly and radically grasps the order
28. of the Hebrew language, and knows how to preserve that order pro-
29. portionally in the sciences, will possess the rule and pattern of perfectly
30. discovering everything knowable’.45 Contemplating Kabbalistic symbols
31. on the practical level, and constructing a system of layered meanings –
32. mythological, astrological and Christian – on the epistemological level,
33. eventually reveal universal philosophical principles. On an eschato-
34. logical level, they achieve a mystical alignment of the soul with the
35. multiple facets of realities represented by those symbols and meanings
36. thus reconfiguring the self for the reception of divine effusion.46 Each
37. level of reality is expressed using a different set of terms. Technical
38. descriptive terminology is a mundane form of expression that requires
39. the reasoning faculty; supplanting it by symbols and allegories creates a
40. linguistic manoeuvre that elevates the soul’s focus. Technical language is
41. still suitable for aetiological explanations. In the Commentary, discussing
42. the generation of created things, Pico writes that ‘for present purposes
43. we can use the following terms for them: causal being, formal being,
44. and participated being. The distinction can hardly be stated in less tech-
45. nical terms.’47 This is the language that has been used by Arabs, Latin
46. medieval cosmologists and philosophers, and to a large extent Ficino,
47. to describe the generative dynamics of the universe and the influences
48. of the celestial world on the world below.

50. Despite the mystical, Kabbalistic and exegetical mission of Pico, these

Assistant

The most recent scholarship — particularly by Sophia Howlett, Giulio Busi and Raphael Ebgi, and the foundational work of Chaim Wirszubski — shows that Pico’s use of Kabbalah and the sefirot was not a side interest but a metaphysical intervention in the Ficino–Thomist problem of form, act, and divine illumination.

1. Kabbalah as metaphysics of angelic forms


Wirszubski demonstrated that Pico equates metaphysica de intelligibilibus angelicisque formis with the science of the sefirot: the ten divine emanations are interpreted as angelic forms, mediating divine causality through formal structures. In his words, Pico’s scientia sephiroth “embraces the intelligibilia angelicisque formis metaphysica,” linking practical Kabbalah to “practicare totam metaphysicam formalem,” the exercise of knowing formal and intelligible being【226:15†Pico della Mirandola’s Encounter with Jewish Mysticism†L7-L41】. The sefirot thus become the metaphysical grammar through which divine act (energeia) flows into created intellects — a Thomistic idea of form-as-act refracted through Jewish cosmology.

2. Ficino, Dionysius, and the Thomist background


Howlett situates this move in Pico’s effort to reconcile Pseudo-Dionysius’s hierarchy of angelic participation with Kabbalistic emanation. Dionysius’s henosis or union with God is translated into a graded series of formal acts; Pico “changes Pseudo-Dionysius’ hierarchy of angels from nine to ten, the number of the sefirot,” thereby equating angelic intellects with divine attributes in the Tree of Life【226:2†Re-evaluating Pico†L29-L44】. For Pico, this links Thomistic actus essendi — God’s self-communicating being — with a Kabbalistic metaphysics of emanation. The ascent of intellect in De ente et uno mirrors this: created forms participate in divine unity not as separate hypostases (as Ficino’s Plotinian model suggested) but as energeiai within providential order.

3. Busi & Ebgi: autonomy and symbolism


Busi and Ebgi’s archival work on Pico’s Hebrew sources shows how independently he adapted them. They note Pico’s use of the Kabbalistic tsimtsum motif — “il Dio che abbandona, Colui che s’eclissa in solitaria retractio,” the divine self-withdrawal — as the metaphysical background for creation【226:0†Re-evaluating Pico†L24-L28】. The sefirot become “psychological attributes of the mysterious divine soul… coloring the inner life of emanation”【226:11†Re-evaluating Pico†L10-L17】. Pico mapped this onto the anima mundi and the angelic intellect: his tenfold adaptation of Dionysius’s orders aligns the hierarchy of intellects with divine self-articulation rather than a chain of being. Busi even finds Pico assigning each faculty of the soul to a sefirah: “Io adatto la nostra anima alle dieci sefirot… la settima verso le realtà superiori, l’ottava verso le inferiori, la nona a un misto di entrambe”【226:12†Giovanni Pico della Mirandola – Mito, magia, Qabbalah†L1-L10】.

4. From metaphysics to freedom of intellect


Against Ficino’s Neoplatonic determinism, Pico re-reads the sefirot and angelic hierarchies as expressions of divine free act. In De ente et uno, as Bradshaw’s Aristotelian context helps explain, act (energeia) and form coincide in God’s will, which remains free and self-contained【226:10†Aristotle East and West†L1-L8】. The Kabbalistic schema allows Pico to extend this freedom analogically to human intellect: to contemplate the sefirot is to know how causes interlock under providence, and so to act “not by compulsion but by participation in divine intellect.”

5. Summary insight


The fusion of Kabbalah, Thomism, and anti-Ficinian Platonism yields a new metaphysics of the angelic:
  • The sefirot = forms of divine act (energeiai) mediated by intellects.

  • Angels = living forms of divine causality, not hypostatic gods.

  • Human intellect = potential act seeking union through contemplation (debequt), echoing Dionysius’s epopteia.


Thus Pico’s engagement with the sefirot converts Ficino’s emanationist hierarchy into a theology of free creative intellect, where knowing the structure of creation — the “grammar of divine forms” — becomes both metaphysics and mystical ascent.

1. In medieval metaphysics, all created
2. things have a fixed ontological status in the universe. Created beings
3. form a hierarchy (the so-called “Great Chain of Being”), ascending from
4. a lower to a higher status based on their ontological composition – broadly
5. their composition of matter and spirit.28 This chain of created being orig-
6. inates from uncreated being, God. In this hierarchical conception of the
7. universe, the human person is in a fixed position between the angelic
8.
9. 28 See Edward P. Mahoney, “Giovanni Pico della Mirandola and Origen on Humans, Choice,
10. and Hierarchy,” Vivens homo 5 (1994): 359–76, at 360–1, 373–6.

19. and animal worlds. The human person was created “a little lower than
20. the angels,” to quote the Psalmist. While retaining much of this general
21. medieval metaphysics, Pico’s departs from it in a crucial respect. The onto-
22. logical status of the human person is not fixed. The essence of the human
23. person (if we can use the term “essence”) is freedom. Unlike the rest
24. of creation, the human person has the capacity to become what he or she
25. chooses to become. As Pico explains, “Oh great and wonderful happiness
26. of man! It is given him to have that which he chooses and to be that which
27. he wills. . . . At man’s birth, the Father placed in him every sort of seed
28. and sprouts of every kind of life.”29 Pico depicts God as speaking to Adam
29. as follows:
30.
31. A limited nature in other creatures is confined within the laws written down
32. by Us. In conformity with thy free judgment, in whose hands I have placed
33. thee, thou art confined by no bounds; and thou wilt fix limits of nature for
34. thyself. I have placed thee at the center of the world, that from there thou
35. mayest more conveniently look around and see whatsoever is in the world.
36. Neither heavenly nor earthly, neither mortal nor immortal have We made
37. thee. Thou, like a judge appointed for being honorable, art the molder and
38. maker of thyself; thou mayest sculpt thyself into whatever shape thou dost
39. prefer. Thou canst grow downward into the lower natures which are brutes.
40. Thou canst again grow upward from thy soul’s reason into higher natures
41. which are divine.30
42.
43. The human person is thus a “chameleon,” having a nature capable
44. of transforming itself into lower or higher forms in the Great Chain of
45. Being.
46.
47. Pico’s insistence on the freedom of the human person to fashion him-
48. self for better or worse was by no means a novel suggestion when Pico
49. proposed it. The idea was common among Neoplatonists of the day.31
50.

52. Chaldeans, and Arabs accepted this idea. Not surprisingly, the idea is

Title: (Critical Political Theory and Radical Practice) Sophia Howlett - Re-evaluating Pico_ Aristotelianism, Kabbalism, and Platonism in the Philosophy of Giovanni Pico della Mirandola-Palgrave Macmillan (2.pdf
Content Snippet:
1. It is in Pico’s metaphysics that this space for interrogation is most
2. obvious and the possibility of concord most alluring. We are forced to
3. reconsider each tradition in and of itself and in juxtaposition. How can
4. a hidden God ever ‘act’? Is the One part of apophatic or kataphatic
5. theology? Does the divine presence only reside in the angelic mind, or
6. does it truly extend to all worlds? How can emanation and creation
7. co-exist? How can we be subject to fate and have free will? And most
8. importantly, how can philosophy and theology - reason and faith - come
9. together? For Pico’s attempted concordance is a part of this larger histor-
10. ical project to connect reason with faith. But the questions it raises also
11. question the project itself: can we connect philosophy, theology and
12. religious practice?
13.
14.
15.
16. 5 PICO’S UNIVERSE 163
17.
18. For Pico the answer is ‘yes.’ There is no doubt that Pico believes he
19. is answering the questions his concordance raises. He is especially sure as
20. he believes the answers have always been present. His task is to reveal a
21. pre-existing structure: a structure built into the fabric of his universe. It
22. is a ladder from the root of the tree down to the earth. It is a ladder built
23. from the combination of philosophy, theology and religious practice. It is
24. revealed in Christianity, Jewish mysticism, Platonism, Aristotelianism and
25. Pythagorean mystical-mathematics, and we can climb it to God. Indeed,
26. we need that combination of reason and faith to make the climb. Through
27. the practice of moral and natural philosophy, understanding of theology
28. and the ardor of faith, we can achieve proximity to the root or crown.
29. This is kataphatic mysticism: mystical experience based on the affirmative
30. understanding of what God is. With the support of God’s grace, we can
31. define and draw together the attributes of the divine until we arrive at a
32. vision of God, perhaps even ‘cleaving’ to the divine forever. Pico’s struc-
33. ture is a puzzle, but it also a ladder; if we can but understand, we can find
34. our way home.

36. nature (indiscretae opus imaginis) who must fashion himself according to

39. they lack any fixed place (certa sedes) in the order of creation.89 While

41. restrictions. In his creation account, Pico has God explain to the first

12. view that humans have no determining principle (4).

19. 136 M. V. Dougherty
20.
21. being as a “great miracle” precisely because miracles are traditionally
22. understood to be events that operate outside the limitation of a nature,
23. or, collectively, outside the order of nature. As a miraculous event appears
24. to be a transgression of a nature or the laws of nature, so does a human
25. being appear to escape the limitations or boundaries present to all other
26. created beings.
27.
28. Having contended that human beings have no intrinsic determining
29. principle, Pico declares that human beings are free to choose from exist-
30. ing natures present in creation. Pico presents what could be styled a moral
31. ontology, since he asserts that the human acquisition of a nature will fol-
32. low from the actions a human being performs. Pico sets forth a fivefold
33. range of options open to human beings, arguing that humans can seek
34. to live vegetative, sensitive, rational, angelic, or divine lives, correspond-
35. ing to the existing natures of plants, earthly beasts, heavenly animals,
36. angels, and God.97 All options are not presented as equal, since Pico
37. clearly condemns a life of beastly concerns as an unfitting condition for
38. human beings.98 Having set forth this view about human metaphysical
39. indeterminacy or multipotentiality, Pico marshals forth extrinsic confir-
40. mations of his view from a great diversity of texts and traditions; in light of
41. the discussion above, I consider these confirmatory appeals to be dialec-
42. tical. Pico does not present his views concerning the human condition
43. as some kind of distillation or broad induction derived from accounts he
44. has read but rather he appeals to authorities as extrinsic corroboration of
45. the views he has already discovered and set forth. In support of his views
46. about the human condition, Pico appeals explicitly to the testimonies
47. he finds in Islamic, Hebrew, and Christian religious writings, passages
48. from classical Latin and Greek poetry, pre-Socratic philosophical texts,
49. Hermetic writings, and points of Chaldean theology.99 The diverse range
50. of sources he presents in the Oratio as a dialectical confirmation of his
51. views on the human condition no doubt was intended as a foretaste of
52. his upcoming defense of the 900 wide-ranging theses drawn from equally
53. varied sources.

1. When Pico cites the line “A great
2. miracle, O Asclepius, is the human being” (magnum, o Asclepi, miracu-
3. lum est homo), he does so as a confirmation of the sententia of Abdul the
4. Saracen on the distinguished condition of human beings, and the appeal
5. to Abdul the Saracen is given to support Pico’s own forthcoming views
6. on the human condition.130 As a dialectician in the general Aristotelian
7. sense, Pico feels free to modify or stress opinions according to the partic-
8. ular needs of his argument. Pico’s freedom to do so is perhaps premised
9. on his distinction between res and verba, a distinction that allows him to
10. adapt (or even manipulate) opinions to confirm his views, even when
11. doing so requires that he ascribe metaphorical or allegorical readings
12. to the authoritative citations he gathers to support his project. In using
13. these methods, Pico exhibits the standard interpretive techniques proper
14. to the dialectical tradition.
15.
16. V. Deificatio
17.
18. I have discussed above the first two parts of the Oratio, focusing on Pico’s
19. defense of the unique condition of human beings in the order of creation
20. and his threefold philosophical curriculum that serves as a propaedeutic
21. to sacred theology. As mentioned above, the bulk of the scholarly interest
22. in the Oratio has generally focused on the first part, and in anthologizing
23. Pico’s work it has not been uncommon for editors to present the first part
24.

35. of attention that the later parts traditionally have received, a hermeneutic
36. approach to the text that can account for the unity of the Oratio seems in
37. order. A reading that exhibits the unity between the sections can be ben-
38. eficial, especially if it limits the conflicting interpretations that surround
39. Pico’s Oratio, and a commitment to showing the congruence of Pico’s
40. philosophical anthropology and his philosophical curriculum will likely
41. improve our understanding of the motivations for his Roman project.
42.
43. There is one theme present in both the first and second parts of the
44. Oratio that I would like to propose as a key for demonstrating the unity of
45. Pico’s philosophical anthropology and his threefold philosophical cur-
46. riculum. The theme is that of ultimate human unity with God, which
47. Pico identifies with a strong version of deification.131 Both parts of the
48. Oratio identify the state of deification as the goal of human endeavors; in
49. the first part, Pico sets forth a metaphysical account of how deification is
50. possible, while in the second part, he presents a curriculum for bringing
51. about that deification. We have noted above that Pico’s defense of a five-
52. fold range of options open to human beings terminates with the highest
53. option, which is unity with God. Pico, as shown in this passage, clearly
54. privileges this option among the other four:

9. Hebrew and Kabbalistic literature had as great an effect on Pico’s interpre-
10. tation of the Kabbalah as the Kabbalistic texts in Mithridates’ translation he
11. consulted. Evidence, therefore, suggests that by 1493, when he started working
12. on his last major treatise, the Disputationes adversus astrologiam divinatricem,
13. and after almost seven years of learning Hebrew, Pico was still not able to read
14. Kabbalistic texts without assistance.
15.
16. Pico’s interest in magic, astrology and the Kabbalah was motivated by
17. his desire to achieve a more profound understanding of Christian theology.
18. However, the bold equivalences he drew amongst pagan, Jewish and Christian
19. dogmas led the Church to condemn thirteen of his Conclusiones. To prove his
20. innocence, Pico wrote the Apologia, which examined the thirteen prohib-
21. ited conclusions in separate chapters. Pico’s attempt to comment on the 900
22. Conclusiones and to clarify all the condemned theses angered Innocent VIII,
23. who declared the whole text heretical and pursued Pico. Pico fled to France,
24. where he was arrested at the request of the papal nuncios and imprisoned at
25. the Vincennes Castle. After his extradition from France, Pico spent some time
26. in prison in Rome until Lorenzo de’ Medici stepped up to save him from an
27. inquisitorial trial. In 1488, Pico was released and moved to Florence, where he
28. stayed, apart from short periods of leave, until his untimely death in 1494.
29.
30. The 900 Conclusiones59 was preceded by a preface now known as the Oratio
31. de hominis dignitate, in which Pico gives an early account of his views on
32. magic and astrology. Drawing on the traditional division between good and
33. bad magic, Pico contrasts the illicit form of magic based on demonic incan-
34. tations, which is now commonly referred to as ‘black or demonic magic’, to

6. university. It was there that he met the Jewish Averroist Elijah Delmedigo of
7. Crete, who eventually furnished Pico with a bibliography that included kab­
8. balistic texts such as Me’irat Einayim, Sha’arei Orah, and Ma’arekhet ha-Elohut.21
9. It was during this period that Pico also became interested in the Florentine lit­
10. erary movement through his friend Angelo Poliziano, whom he met in Mantova
11. in 1472. In 1483 he found himself in Florence, and in 1484, he read through a
12. copy of Marsilio Ficino’s recently written Theologia Platonica. Regardless of
13. his deep interest in Plato as sparked, in part, by this important work, Pico
14. remained a faithful follower of Aristotle at this point, and in 1485 he travelled
15. to Paris, which was then a bastion of Aristotelian scholasticism.
16.
17. Upon his return to Florence, Pico set himself on a project of philosophical
18. concord. This was to include the reconciliation of Aristotle and Plato, but it was
19. also to constitute an entirely new system as based upon the prisca sapientia
20. tradition.22 According to this idea, as set forth by the likes of Ficino, ancient
21. wisdom is considered pristine, and it embraces several traditions, including
22. ancient Greek wisdom, ancient Indian wisdom, ancient Egyptian wisdom in the
23. form of Hermetica, and also ancient Jewish wisdom in the form of Kabbalah.
24. This last form of ancient wisdom came to a unique position of prominence for
25. Pico, and it is for this purpose that he set himself to Hebrew learning in 1486.
26. It is also in this light that he composed his nine­hundred Conclusiones that
27. he planned to defend in a magnificent self­sponsored conference in Rome,
28. well over one­hundred and twenty of which were on specifically kabbalistic
29. themes. In this same regard, Pico’s famed Oration, which was originally penned
30. as an introduction to the planned conference, is very kabbalistically tinged.23
31.
32. A papal commission deemed thirteen of Pico’s conclusiones heretical and
33. prevented the planned conference from taking place. Pico wrote an Apologia

1. Above this is
2. the darkness, until it is illuminated by the rays of spiritual con­
3. cepts by which he sees and contemplates everything. It is
4. written, however, "upon the face of the deep," not "upon the
5. deep," because the same place is one of darkness and of light.
6. The light of intelligible forms covers the face, the exterior of
7. the angelic intelligence, because their qualities are accidental
8. to it and do not pertain to its essence. After the darkness has
9. been driven way, Moses adds whatever may occur before the
10. light arises by saying, "And the Spirit of God moved over the
11. waters."
12.
13. What will the Spirit of the Lord be other than the spirit of
14. love? We cannot with propriety say that the spirit of knowledge
15. is the Spirit of the Lord, because knowledge sometimes leads
16. away from God. Love, however, always leads us to God. If it is
17. not borne upon the deep, light will not be made, since just as
18. the eye is not filled with light unless turned toward the sun,
19. so an angel is not filled with the spiritual light unless turned
20. toward God. This turning movement is not, and can not be,
21. anything in the angelic nature but the motion of love.
22.
23. Therefore it was the Spirit of the Lord, the spirit of love, that
24. was borne upon the deep, that is, upon the angelic intellect
25. (for love follows understanding). Driven and excited by it, the
26. mind of the angel turns toward God. God said "Be light made,"
27. and light was made in the angel, the light of intelligible forms;
28. and the evening and the morning were one day since, as
29. Averroes shows, from the intellect and the intelligible is made
30.
31.
32.
33. 110 HEPTAPLUS
34.
35. a greater unity than from matter and form, because, as the same
36. author affirms and as Moses the Egyptian also writes, truth is
37. grasped far better by angels than by men.5 To pass over those
38. writers, let this reason be enough for us-that intelligible
39. species are united to angelic minds by eternal links and an in­
40. divisible bond, not a vague and customary one as happens with
41. the human intellect.
42.
43. Chapter Three
44.
45. We have seen the nature of the angels created by God, turned
46. to God by the spirit of love, and then enlightened by him and
47. perfected by the light of intelligible forms. Let us now see into
48. what ranks the angelic armies are divided.
49.
50. We read that the firmament was placed in the midst of the
51. waters, by which are indicated to us the three hierarchies of
52. angels (for thus we shall always call them, by the customary
53. word). The first and last of these are designated by the waters,
54. the former by those above the heavens, the latter by those which
55. are under the heavens; the middle one dividing them is called
56. the firmament. All this, if we consider the nature and duties of
57. the three hierarchies, could not be more in accord with the
58. teaching of Dionysius. Since, as he writes,6 the highest hierarchy
59. has leisure only for contemplation, it is properly symbolized by
60. the waters that are placed above the heavens, that is, above all
61. action in regard to worldly things, whether heavenly or earthly,
62. and they praise God unceasingly with everlasting sound. Since
63. the middle rank is assigned to the work of the heavens, it could
64. not be more fittingly symbolized than by the firmament, that is,
65. the sky. The final hierarchy, although by nature it is above
66. everybody and above the heavens, nevertheless has charge of
67. things under the heavens.

51. A SPEECH BY

53. GIOVANNI PICO DELLA MIRANDOLA,
54. Prince of Concord
55.
56. Most venerable fathers, I have read in the records of the Ara­
57. bians that Abdul the Saracen, on being asked what thing on,
58. so to speak, the world's stage, he viewed as most greatly worthy
59. of wonder, answered that he viewed nothing more wonderful
60. than man. And Mercury's, "a great wonder, Asclepius, is man!"
61. agrees with that opinion.1 On thinking over the reason for these
62. sayings, I was not satisfied by the many assertions made by many
63. men concerning the outstandingness of human nature: that
64. man is the messenger between creatures, familiar with the
65. upper and king of the lower; by the sharpsightedness of the
66. senses, by the hunting-power of reason, and by the light of
67. intelligence, the interpreter of nature; the part in between the
68. standstill of eternity and the flow of time; and, as the Persians
69. say, the bond tying the world together, nay, the nuptial bond;
70. and, according to David, "a little lower than the angels."2
71. These reasons are great but not the chief ones, that is, they are
72. not reasons for a lawful claim to the highest wonder as to a
73. prerogative. Why should we not wonder more at the angels
74. themselves and at the very blessed heavenly choirs?
75.
76. Finally, it seemed to me that I understood why man is
77. the animal that is most happy, and is therefore worthy of
78. all wonder; and lastly, what the state is that is allotted to man
79. in the succession of things, and that is capable of arousing envy
80. not only in the brutes but also in the stars and even in minds
81. beyond the world. It is wonderful and beyond belief. For this
82. is the reason why man is rightly said and thought to be a great

Assistant

Across Pico’s corpus — Oratio, Conclusiones cabalisticae, De ente et uno, and the Heptaplus — his language about creation, intellect, and angelic hierarchy consistently reworks Kabbalistic and Dionysian sources to reject Ficino’s necessitarian Neoplatonism and to affirm divine freedom.

1. Freedom as the grammar of creation


In the Oratio, Pico declares that God “restricted [man] by no limits” and placed him “in whose hands I have set thee” (in cuius manu te posui), so that each soul may define its own form “according to free judgment”【233:4†M. V. Dougherty - Pico della Mirandola_ New Essays (Cambridge Companions to Philosophy) (2007).pdf†L44-L49】. Amos Edelheit notes that this vocabulary (arbitrium, not libertas) reflects Pico’s Thomistic anthropology: divine act (actus purus) communicates to the intellect a freedom to act, not self-determining autonomy【233:12†(Brill's Studies in Intellectual History 230) Amos Edelheit - Scholastic Florence_ Moral Psychology in the Quattrocento-Brill (2014).pdf†L15-L26】. Thus “to be free” means to share in God’s energeia — a participation in divine operation rather than independence from it.

2. Kabbalah and angelic mediation as metaphysics of act


In his Conclusiones cabalisticae, Pico writes that “whoever operates in the Cabala without mixture … will die from the death of the kiss” (morietur ex binsica), describing mystical union as an act of divine communication rather than emanation【233:9†(Critical Political Theory and Radical Practice) Sophia Howlett - Re-evaluating Pico_ Aristotelianism, Kabbalism, and Platonism in the Philosophy of Giovanni Pico della Mirandola-Palgrave Macmillan (2.pdf†L46-L51】. Howlett interprets this as Pico’s attempt to articulate a metaphysics where “the divine presence … truly extends to all worlds” and the sefirot form “a ladder … built from philosophy, theology, and religious practice” toward the root of being【233:3†(Critical Political Theory and Radical Practice) Sophia Howlett - Re-evaluating Pico_ Aristotelianism, Kabbalism, and Platonism in the Philosophy of Giovanni Pico della Mirandola-Palgrave Macmillan (2.pdf†L18-L28】. The sefirot therefore become signs of actus Dei — free, creative operations rather than deterministic hypostases.

3. Angelic intellect and free act


In the Heptaplus Pico describes the angels’ illumination:
“The Spirit of the Lord … the spirit of love … was borne upon the deep, that is, upon the angelic intellect … Driven and excited by it, the mind of the angel turns toward God. … God said ‘Be light made,’ and light was made in the angel”【233:13†Heptaplus, Pico della Mirandola - On the Dignity of Man - Being and One- (1965).pdf†L13-L27】.

Here the angelic mind is not a fixed emanation but a dynamic turning — a motion of love that exemplifies how intellect participates in God’s energeia. Edelheit glosses this as Pico’s “Aristotelianization of the miraculous,” where divine act expresses itself through hierarchical form–matter relations rather than through Neoplatonic overflow.

4. Against Ficino’s determinism


Ovanes Akopyan and Brian Ogren both underline that Pico’s engagement with Kabbalah and Dionysius was an explicit response to Ficino’s Plotinian theology of necessity: Pico “sought to reconcile creation with freedom, not emanation,” transforming the prisca theologia into a theology of divine volition【233:11†(Supplements to the journal of Jewish thought and philosophy Volume 27) Abravanel...Ogren...Pico della Mirandola...The beginning of the wor.pdf†L17-L27】. In De ente et uno, his distinction between ens and unum redefines unity as an act of intellect — the same logic that structures the sefirotic ascent.

5. Synthesis


Thus, in Pico’s own words and his modern interpreters’ terms:
  • “God said, ‘Be light made,’ and light was made in the angel.” — creation as free act, mirrored in intellect.

  • “Thou art confined by no bounds … thou wilt fix limits of nature for thyself.” — human freedom as participation in that same creative causality.

  • The sefirot and hierarchies of angels are not deterministic intermediaries but expressions of divine will in actu.


In short, against Ficino’s Neoplatonic determinism, Pico re-reads the sefirot and angelic orders as manifestations of God’s creative energeia — the grammar of providential freedom within which intellect and love cooperate in the unfolding of creation.
